title: 'One Night in Old Havana' bringing all things vintage Cuba to Oxford
author: Staff Writer
content:
'One Night in Old Havana' bringing all things vintage Cuba to Oxford

 May 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Oxford Community Center will host a "One Night in Old Havana" event on Saturday, June 1, at 6:30 p.m.The event will mirror a Cuban social club from the 1950 with salsa music, neon lights, cigars, Latin-inspired food and vintage cars. There will be a cigar lounge on the OCC's patio.
The 'Old Havana' event will also feature signature cocktails featuring locally based Lyon Rum.
The music portion will include various singers, salsa dancers and a group lesson from dance instructor and champion dancer Scott Lazarovs.
"We look forward to transporting you back to 'One Night in Old Havana," said OCC Executive Director Liza Ledford. "This will be an immersive experience filled with tropical cocktails, live music, and plenty of salsa dancing. It promises to be a wonderfully entertaining evening supporting our mission."
Attendees can break out their best cocktail party attire or get vintage wear from The Factory in Easton along styling packages.
"1950s Havana is calling you," said event chair and Oxford resident Jennifer Leps. "We look forward to whisking you away to another time and place. Salsa rhythms will spill out onto the patio cigar bar, while inside, a mesmerizing display of song and dance unfolds. Prepare to be transported to one night to remember!
The tickets are $75 with an open bar and appetizers from The Ivy and hand-rolled cigars from Port of Call Cigars.
"Come in costume, stay for the performances, and experience an unforgettable evening while supporting our 501c3's work to bring the community together," Ledford said.
Styling sessions cost $250 "with The Factory's professional costumers and stylists. The hour includes a full period costume for the event, hair & make up consultation, self care party favors and Cuban inspired cocktails & snacks. Each guest will receive a bespoke floral headpiece made by our costumers that compliments their look," according an announcement from the Oxford Community Center
For more: https://oxfordcc.org/ 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Love and light': 'Dancing Crab' christened, readies for more events
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Love and light': 'Dancing Crab' christened, readies for more events

 May 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 339
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Two row clubs showed up in Betterton on Saturday, May 18, to test their canoeing skills: Kent Island Outrigger Canoe Club and New Hope Canoe Club Ministry Atlantic.They had their vessels in the water despite dark clouds threatening. Two members from Philadelphia also joined the Kent Island team.
When the sun peeked out, pastor of New Hope, David Schofield blessed the maiden voyage of Kent Island's newest canoe.
President of the Kent Island team, Michelle Reid said, "This is a great opportunity for the two clubs to come together, kick off our season, have some fun and experience the nice exercise here, and just get out there and do some paddling."
All of the canoes are named a Hawaiian name, and carrying on that tradition, all affiliates formed a big circle around the new canoe and prayed over it, blessing its first time going out.
"The idea here is love and light. We can all agree that's a good thing," Schofield said.
The name they gave it was Hula Papa'i, meaning Dancing Crab.
Once the Dancing Crab was christened, all canoes were in the water.
They traveled six miles along the Sassafras River Trail to Lloyd's Creek and back as part of their Hawaiian voyage paddle.
Member of the Kent Island Outrigger Canoe Club Doug Klepfer found it peaceful, enjoying nature, "spotting beautiful eagles and blue herons along the way."
The water was calm, he said, and after the rain, they had the whole river to themselves, no boat traffic.
The first journey of the Hula Papa'i (Dancing Crab) sliced through the water with great stability, quietness and speed, he said.
They returned to Betterton around 1:30 p.m., enjoying their team building exercise.
This is one of many events planned, Klepfer said. "We look forward to the Chesapeake Bay Paddle race around Kent Island on Saturday, July 20, offering a 35, 10, and three-mile paddle with a post paddle festival to help protect the bay."
Thw event takes place at the Kent Island Yacht Club and everyone at all levels are welcome to register, Klepfer said. For more information visit baypaddle.org 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bookplate to welcome Sue Ellen Thompson May 29
author: Staff Writer
content:
Bookplate to welcome Sue Ellen Thompson May 29

 May 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 411
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Bookplate in Chestertown is continuing its 2024 season of author lectures on May 29 with poet Sue Ellen Thompson for a 6 p.m. event at The Kitchen and Pub at The Imperial Hotel.As the title poem reminds us, "For each of us/ there is a place,/ a period of time,// a lover's face/ that we must veer away from…".
Sea Nettles is a book of poems about what we are often reluctant to confront: the memories that still trouble us and the losses we would just as soon forget.
Former friends, old lovers, and mortality make frequent appearances, along with migrating birds and rising waters. Behind these poems lurks the knowledge that none of us can know what fate has in store for us.
As the opening poem warns, "For you, the Universe has something else in mind."
"I love how this collection gives us decades of insight into a family, offers epiphanies that are only available after many years have gone by.
These are personal poems with a wide perspective, intimate poems that take the long view. Each poem is like a stepping stone that bridges the present and the past. It feels appropriate, then, that this collection features poems from two previous collections, providing a richer understanding of the relationships we've explored in the first half of the book.
These are efficient, muscular poems with sensual, unusual language. This collection provides, as the poet writes, "a sudden intrusion of daylight" in which I found myself drawn in by love, disappointment, and the truth of just how much we need each other to meet ourselves." wrote Rosemerry Wahtola Trommer, author of Hush.
Thompson is the author of six books of poetry and the editor of The Autumn House Anthology of Contemporary American Poetry. Her work has been included in the Best American Poetry series, read on National Public Radio more than a dozen times by Garrison Keillor, and has been nominated twice for the Pulitzer Prize.
She teaches workshops at The Writer's Center in Bethesda and was the recipient of the 2010 Maryland Author Prize from the Maryland Library Association.
The Bookplate will continue its event series with a reservation only author lecture at The Lawrence Wetlands Preserve on June 12 as author Christopher Tilghman will be discussing his new book On The Tobacco Coast.
These events are free and open to the public. For more event details contact The Bookplate at 410-778-4167 or contact@thebookplate.net. The Kitchen at The Imperial is located at 208 High street in Chestertown. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Circus comes to Easton
author: Tom McCall
content:
Circus comes to Easton

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The big tent reached 100 feet into the sky with blue and yellow stripes as the Zerbini Family Circus came to the Talbot Agricultural and Education Center on May 22 and 23.The circus brought parading ponies, gravity-defying acrobats and zany clowns. The audience of all ages was rapt.
There was a palpable sense of joy as the ringmaster announced each act in a booming voice.
Children had their faces painted like butterflies and queued to hold a real albino snake. One happy grandmother from Trappe, waving at her grandson, said, "I am already in for $100, but it is OK."
In the darkened tent, the spectacle glowed on the children's faces.
The balancing act was like a surfer on a board. He placed seven cylinders beneath his board and stood 30 feet above the ground wobbling. The crowd was in awe of this seemingly dangerous act. He dismounted with his arms up in victory.
There was a 20-foot inflatable koala bear teetering around the ring and providing photo ops for children.
There were two clowns that were supported by timely sound effects. The whole tent was laughing with them and at them.
Horses pranced and jumped and put their forward hoof on stands in unison. Mini donkeys performed the same tricks.
Most of the performers are from Mexico but are based in Florida, according to employees of the circus, and tour the East Coast.
They travel from Rock Hall to Collcoon to Woodstown, performing two or three shows in each spot, and then roll it up and head to the next town.

title: Time to get crabby: Annual Lions Club festival on tap
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Time to get crabby: Annual Lions Club festival on tap

 May 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 38th annual St. Mary's County Crab Festival will be held Saturday, June 8. at the St. Mary's County Fairgrounds in Leonardtown.The crabs are the main attraction on Saturday at the fairgrounds. But there will also be live music provided by a pair of local bands — "Totally Stoked" and "Reagan Years" — food vendors and, fittingly, a crab-picking contest that will serve a duel purpose of providing competitive entertainment and crab meat for those who indulge.
George Kirby has been associated with the Leonardtown Lions Club for the past decade and now he is among the committee members who are seeking to make the annual crab festival even more festive each year. In recent years, Kirby noted several new items have been added to the entertainment venue and each of them has been received in appreciable fashion.
"One thing that we added a few years ago, and it has become really popular, is the crab-picking contest," Kirby said. "We started a new tradition last year. Instead of just giving away a trophy to the winner, we have a big trophy with the name of each annual winner engraved on it. It started last year and we'll keep adding a name to it each year."
In addition to the crab-picking contest, the St. Mary's County Crab Festival also features a classic car show, homemade craft exhibits, a petting zoo, a face painter and free hearing and vision screenings, all of which debuted a year ago and are free to the public.
"I think we're expecting about 30 to 40 cars for the show," Kirby said. "There are a lot more car shows around now, so that number could be a little lower. But we're still going to have a contest with judges and trophies to the winners. ... Our health screenings are free and they're important."
While there are a bevy of eating and entertainment options for patrons throughout the eight-hour outing, the crab-picking contest has evolved into a must-see event. Hardly a subjective viewing event, the champion of the crab-picking contest is the individual who picks the most crab meat during a brief, contentious, four-minute window, and then is immortalized on a trophy that could someday emulate the Stanley Cup.
"I hope in my heart that people come out because the Leonardtown Lions Club is a good community service group and we'll use all the money we get to give back to the community," Kirby said. "And a good humanitarian fundraiser is for some people worth coming to just to sit around and say 'I helped.' We do really good things and part of that depends on people coming. We just want people to have a good time."
If you go
The 38th annual St. Mary's County Crab Festival will take place this Saturday, June 8, from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. at the St. Mary's County Fairgrounds, located at 42455 Fairgrounds Road in Leonardtown.
This event will feature hot crabs, an animal zoo, jump houses, crafts, car shows, a crab-picking contest, free vision and hearing screenings and performances from local bands Totally Stoked (noon-3 p.m.) and Reagan Years (4-7 p.m.).
Tickets for the event are $10, while children under 12 get in free. For more information, view the website at https://e-clubhouse.org/sites/leonardtownmd or call 301-997-5779.

title: Fun on a bun: hamburgers for summer days
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Fun on a bun: hamburgers for summer days

 June 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last week we explored hotdogs, so I decided we could not leave out burgers since both are extremely popular year-round but even more so in the summer.There is just no better smell going through the neighborhood than the smells of burgers on a grill.
Mr. Fletcher Davis of Athens, Texas made some of the first burgers in his small cafe, and the customers went wild over this great sandwich. It was in the 1880s, and the popularity of the burger grew so much that Davis carried the "burger" to share with the world at the 1904 World's Fair in St. Louis, Missouri.
There is nothing else to say except get out your grill or your iron fry pan or whatever you use to cook burgers and try some of today's recipes.
Whenever I hear the word burgers, I immediately start dicing onions, slicing tomatoes, washing lettuce, making sure I have cheese and fresh mustard, ketchup and relish — don't forget the soft buns. Enjoy.
CLASSIC CHEESEBURGER1 pound ground chuck (80% lean), 1 pound ground sirloin, sea salt, freshly cracked black pepper, 4 or 8 brioche burger buns, 1/3 cup yellow mustard, 1 tbsp butter, 8 slices American cheese, 4 to 8 (1/4-inch-thick) tomato slices, 4 to 8 (1/4-inch-thick) red onion slices, 8 pickle slices, 8 burger-size lettuce leaves.
In a large bowl, combine the ground chuck and sirloin and mix gently but thoroughly. Divide into eight equal portions and shape them into burger patties. Season both sides with salt and pepper and refrigerate for 30 minutes. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Heat a large skillet over medium heat. Split and toast the buns in the pan until toasty and golden brown. Set aside. Remove the burgers from the fridge and place a thumbprint in the center of each patty.
Smear 1 tsp of the mustard on both sides of each patty. Melt the butter in the preheated pan and, working in batches, fry the burgers for 3 to 4 minutes on each side, until a dark brown crust begins to form. The result: perfectly juicy medium-cooked burgers. For folks who prefer their burgers a little more well done, fry for 5 to 6 minutes per side. Transfer the patties to a baking sheet as they're done. Top each with cheese and place in the oven to melt, 2 to 3 minutes. Build the burgers on the toasted buns with 1 or 2 burger patties, a slice of tomato, pickles, a slice of red onion and lettuce. Top each with ketchup or mayo. Serve immediately.
CHEDDAR AND ONION SMASH BURGER16 thin bread-and-butter or dill pickle slices (patted dry), four 4-inch potato buns (buttered and toasted), 1 1/4 pounds ground beef chuck, salt and freshly ground pepper, 2 small onions (sliced paper thin), 4 ounces sharp cheddar cheese (sliced).
Heat a cast-iron griddle until very hot. Layer the pickle slices on the bottom buns. Without overworking the meat, loosely form it into four balls and place them on the griddle. Cook the meatballs over moderately high heat for 30 seconds. Using a sturdy large spatula, flatten each ball into a 5-inch round patty. Season the patties with salt and pepper and cook for 2 minutes, until well seared. Press a handful of sliced onions onto each patty. Using the spatula, carefully flip each burger so the onions are on the bottom. Top with the cheese and cook for 2 minutes. Cover with a roasting pan and cook just until the cheese is melted, 1 minute more. Transfer the burgers with the onions to the buns and add any additional toppings you like.
TEXAS BURGERSColeslaw: 3/4 cup mayonnaise, 1/2 small onion (finely shredded), 3 tbsps cider vinegar, 2 tbsps sugar, 2 tsps celery seeds, 8 cups shredded green cabbage ,1 large carrot (finely shredded), salt and freshly ground pepper. Burgers: 2 pounds ground beef chuck, vegetable oil for rubbing, salt and freshly ground pepper, 3/4 cup barbecue sauce, 4 hamburger buns (split), sliced pickles.
In a large bowl, whisk the mayonnaise with the onion, vinegar, sugar and celery seeds. Add the shredded cabbage and carrot, season with salt and pepper and toss well. Let stand until slightly softened, about 25 minutes. Light a grill. Form the beef into four patties; rub with oil and season with salt and pepper. Sear over high heat, turning once, for 5 minutes for medium-rare. Brush with 1/2 cup of the barbecue sauce and grill until glazed, about 1 minute per side. Grill the buns and brush them with the remaining barbecue sauce. Top with the burgers, pickles and coleslaw and serve.
BLACK BEAN BURGERS1/4 cup dried bread crumbs, 1/4 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp ground coriander, 3 cups cooked black beans, 1/4 cup light mayonnaise, salt, pepper, 2 large stalks celery, 1 chipotle chile in adobo, 4 green-leaf lettuce leaves, 4 whole wheat hamburger buns, 4 slices of a ripe tomato.
In a food processor with a knife blade attached, pulse bread crumbs, cumin, coriander, two-thirds of beans, 2 tbsps mayonnaise, 1/4 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper until well blended. Transfer to a large bowl. Stir in celery and remaining whole beans until well combined. Divide into 4 portions and shape into patties. Lightly coat a 12-inch nonstick skillet with nonstick cooking spray. Heat on medium 1 minute, then add patties. Cook 10 to 12 minutes or until browned on both sides, carefully turning once. Meanwhile, in a small bowl, combine chipotle chile and remaining 2 tbsps mayonnaise until well mixed. Place 1 lettuce leaf on bottom of each bun; top with patty, then tomato slice. Divide chipotle mayonnaise among burgers and replace tops of buns to serve.
BACON AND CHEESE FILLED BURGER3 tbsps dark brown sugar, 1 1/2 tsp paprika, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp chipotle powder, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp fresh-ground pepper, 1 pound ground beef, 1/2 cup shredded sharp cheddar cheese, 6 slices bacon (cooked and crumbled), 4 rolls.
Heat grill to medium. Combine the sugar, spices, salt and pepper in a small bowl and set aside. Form the beef into 8 equal patties. Toss the cheese and crumbled bacon together and place an equal amount on four of the patties. Place the remaining patties over the cheese and bacon and pinch the edges to seal. Generously pat each burger with the reserved spice mixture. Grill to desired doneness, about 5 minutes per side for medium.
SHANNON'S JALAPENO BURGERSThis last burger recipe is my daughter in law Shannon's creations. Shannon assured me the secret here is that you grill this on charcoal, not gas. The smoke helps bring out the flavor in this next burger.
3 pounds grass-fed ground beef (preferably 80/20 or 85/15), 4 jalapeno peppers (diced), 4 garlic cloves (minced), 1 onion (diced), 8 slices of pepper jack or ghost pepper cheese, a pack of buns of your choice.
Prepare the grill for cooking on high heat. I let the coals get gray and orange from the heat. Mix jalapeno pepper, garlic, onion and ground beef in a bowl. Separate beef mixture into about seven equal bundles. Place a thick slice of pepper jack cheese into the center of each beef bundle (about the size of a thick butter pat). Form bundles into patties. Brush grill grate with oil. Grill hamburger patties 5 minutes per side.
When you place the patties on the grill, the juices will cause the fire to flame up, try to watch it so they don't burn. Move the patties around for direct and indirect heat patterns if you must. I like mine medium rare so around 5 minutes is perfect. At this point, you can add the cheese to the burgers while they are still grilling, but you must really watch to make sure the burgers don't burn or remove burgers from the grill and top with pepper jack cheese. You can take your buns, split them, and smear butter olive oil on each side. Place them face down on another part of the grill for maybe 30 seconds to get a food toasting. Serve with condiments of your choice. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Explore Maryland: Discover diverse tunes at Mulberry festival
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Explore Maryland: Discover diverse tunes at Mulberry festival

 June 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 583
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Friday evening, June 14, for one night only the Townhouse Green on the campus of the St. Mary's College of Maryland will host the annual Mulberry Music Festival, which will feature a quintet of superb performers providing the entertainment.Each year the Mulberry Music Festival not only highlights the talents of those performers, but serves as a testament to President Tuajuanda Jordan, who was instrumental in its inception. Accomplished musician Gabe Stillman is the festival headliner and will also feature performances from Walking Eagle, Everyday Everybody and Shamans of Sound with Carly Harvey, a 2007 St. Mary's College alumna, serving as mistress of ceremonies.
"At St. Mary's College, we value our liberal arts foundation — the diversity of thought and expression, creativity and respect for self and others," Jordan said. "We teach students how to express themselves in order to add color and life to our world in a way that only each unique individual can. In this spirit of creativity, I initiated the Mulberry Music Festival in order to bring people together around the universal language that is music."
Headlining the Mulberry Music Festival is Stillman, a graduate of Boston's Berkley College of Music whose honors include an invitation to support ZZ Top, Eric Gales, Blues Traveler, George Thorogood and several others. Stillman was a Blues Music Award nominee in the Best New Emerging Artist album category, and the Gabe Stillman Band was selected as the Best Blues Band by the third annual Central PA Music Awards.
Another prominent performer on Friday evening is Walking Eagle, an artist from Northern Virginia whose debut album "As Is" was released in the spring of 2023, and his version of "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was released last October. Walking Eagles was a season 24 contestant on NBC's "The Voice" and currently has two new singles that will be released this year. He believes that music is fun, life-giving and spiritual and a gift that he is eager to share with everyone.
Joining the entertainment is Shamans of Sound, a reggae group that seeks to unite listeners through peace, love and social consciousness. Comprised of nearly a dozen members from the Washington, D.C. area, Shamans of Sound has earned its reputation as one of the city's finest reggae performing acts, seeking to rebuild the vibe and help heal the nation together from its brand of musical performances.
Also performing on Friday is Everyday Everybody, a nine-member group that has been performing together since 2012 and often produces an upbeat, retro groove sound influenced by Funk and Soul, Jazz, Afro-funk and Motown-era pop. The combination of their sound and energetic live performances have earned them numerous awards, including Best Local Original Band and Best Funk group by the Washington Area Music Association.
Spectators are encouraged to bring lawn chairs, blankets and food, although there will be food vendors on hand, although guests are reminded that pets are strictly prohibited from attending this event.
If you go
The Mulberry Music Festival will be held on the Townhouse Green on the campus of the St. Mary's College of Maryland located at 47645 College Drive, St. Mary's City, on Friday, June 14, from 6 to 9 p.m.
This event is free to the public and will feature performances from Gabe Stillman, Walking Eagle, Everyday Everybody and Shamans of Sound with Carly Harvey serving as mistress of ceremonies. Guests are encouraged to bring lawn chairs, blankets and food although there will be vendors on site, although pets are strictly prohibited from this event.
For more information visit www.smcm.edu/mulberry-music-festival/.

title: Rapper Travis Scott arrested after Miami Beach police say he drunkenly yelled at people on a yacht

 Miami Beach police say rapper Travis Scott was arrested on misdemeanor charges of trespassing and public intoxication. Police say Scott was drunkenly yelling at people on a yacht at the city marina and disobeyed their order to leave early Thursday, June 20.The 33-year-old Scott, who is one of the biggest names in hip-hop, posted his $650 bond and was released from jail before noon. His attorney says the arrest stemmed from a misunderstanding.
After his release, he posted on the social platform X, "Lol."
His attorney, Bradford Cohen, said in a statement that Scott was "detained due to a misunderstanding."
Ten people were fatally crushed at a 2021 Scott concert at Houston's Astroworld amusement park when the crowd surged. The final lawsuit in those cases was settled last month. After a police investigation, a grand jury declined to indict Scott.
Scott has two children with his former girlfriend, media personality and businesswoman Kylie Jenner.

title: Teen prepares for National American Miss Pageant
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Teen prepares for National American Miss Pageant

 June 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 446
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — What does snakehead fishing, towing boats and being an Eagle Scout have to do with pageantry? Rising senior at Kent Island High School Madison Mitchell is the answer.At 17 years old, Mitchell is already an active member of her community.
She is a junior member of the American Legion Auxiliary, where she organizes and carries out events like the Mother's and Father's Day brunches. She is also a founding member of the KI Scouts of America chapter, where she has earned over 60 merit badges.
Her Eagle Scout project provided six pressure-treated benches to the Blue Heron Nature Preserve. In addition, Mitchell also loves fishing and is a part of the KI Fisherman's Club, where she helps with events like the Fishing Flea Market for about 2,800 people.
Excitement came in the mail when Mitchell received an invitation for an open call for the National American Miss Contest.
"I'm trying to get more out of my comfort zone. When I got the open call, I wanted to try," she said.
Two days after her open call, Mitchell found out she was a state finalist for the National American Miss Pageant for 16 to 18 year-olds.
While many beauty pageants focus on judging outward physical appearances, the National American Miss Pageant organization focuses on "creating future leaders and equipping them with real-world skills to make their dreams a reality. The program is based on inner beauty, as well as poise and presentation, and offers an 'All-America' spirit of fun for family and friends."
Mike Mitchell, Madison's father, describes his daughter as "a good kid who is shy and close with her family. She has been a leader in her Eagle Scouting and is well-organized with structuring events, programs, and event coordinating. She has great follow-through."
Mitchell shines through her community service as she received many awards to date including a Governor's Citation for "outstanding services for the citizens of (Maryland)," a Congressional award for service, as well as many Eagle Scout awards.
Now, Mitchell prepares for the pageant on Aug. 17 to 19, in Reston, Virginia. Events will include a formal wear competition, an interview, a personal introduction and optional pay-to-participate events that include Top Model Search, Runway Model, Casual Wear and more.
As one of the only Queen Anne's County finalists, she hopes that this experience will not only take her "out of her comfort zone but will also boost her confidence and public speaking."
In the near future, Mitchell aspires to encourage "youth empowerment and support those in need." If she wins, she said she would, "visit school field days to volunteer, read books to local schools, and donate (her) time to community events."
To support Mitchell's fundraising efforts, visit https://iam.buzz/5vrz5m or email mmitchell@lrwillsonandsons.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Madison Mitchell's participation in the National American Miss Pageant, an entertainment event emphasizing personal development and competition. While her community involvement ties to 'Local Life,' the primary context is the pageant as an entertainment activity. 'Arts & Culture' is less fitting as the story centers on competition rather than cultural expression.

 Historic Brampton 1860 in Chestertown will open its doors on Sunday, June 30 from noon to 2:30 p.m. for ticketed visitors to get a glimpse at its grounds and learn what about its upscale accommodations, as well as weekend event rental packages for weddings, special occasions, and corporate retreats.The event will be hosted by the inn's proprietors, Hilari and David Rinehart. They purchased the inn in 2020.
"Brampton is a beautiful retreat for our guests where peace and tranquility, gracious hospitality, fine food, and comfortable accommodations are at the forefront of everything we do. That is what we fell in love with as guests and our expectations were exceeded with every visit," said David Rinehart.
"We decided that if we could do the same in our next chapter in life, we could positively impact others the way we were impacted. We are so excited to be caretakers of Brampton and continue its traditions."
Accommodations include suits in the Manor house and estate cottages featuring seating areas, working fireplaces, soaking tubs, steam showers, and views of the country estate's gardens, meadows, and natural landscape. There are also two pet-friendly accommodations.
The Brampton, which was built in 1860, features a daily tea-time and ice cream social on Saturdays.
Brampton 1860 is located at 25227 Chestertown Road, Chestertown. For tickets and additional information, visit https://rb.gy/vx0oqh, bramptoninn.com, or call 410-778-1860.

 Paul Comfort, a renowned public transportation leader, has achieved a remarkable feat with his latest book, "The New Future of Public Transportation." The book has soared to number one on Amazon's New Best Sellers list in the Mass Transit and Sustainable Agriculture categories.A Queen Anne's County resident, this is Comfort's sixth book on public transportation.
In this highly anticipated second edition, Comfort brings together 30 new, expertly crafted chapters from leading figures in the transit industry. From hydrogen-fueled buses to AI-driven advancements and cybersecurity, the book provides unparalleled insights into the future of transit. As the world grapples with post-COVID complexities, innovative solutions are essential to address infrastructure challenges and workforce shortages. Comfort explores how AI is revolutionizing transit planning, ultimately enhancing outcomes for riders. The book also delves into cutting-edge transit technology, including autonomous vehicles and zero-emission initiatives, with a strong focus on sustainability and customer experience.
Whether you're a seasoned professional or new to the field, "The New Future of Public Transportation" serves as a roadmap to success, empowering readers to drive positive change within their organizations. Comfort's comprehensive approach ensures that readers gain a broad understanding of current trends across the transit industry from a global perspective.

Kat Melton will direct CHT's November production with Michael Casey serving as musical director.
According to the theater:
"Auditions will be held in the theater (103 Walnut Street) on Sunday, August 4, from 1-3 p.m. and on Monday and Tuesday (August 5 & 6) 6:30-8 p.m. in the CHT office directly across from the theatre.  The Historic Brampton 1860 Inn in Chestertown will host the next in a series of 'Dining Under the Stars' dining events Tuesday, July 30 event beginning at 6 p.m.The 'By Land & Sea' -themed dinner will be hosted by the Inn's proprietors, Hilari and David Rinehart, who have partnered with several local businesses to provide cuisine, wine pairings, and entertainment. Guests can make reservations now.
"We have been working with Brampton 1860 for the last year; first in conjunction with a dinner cruise boat we operate (Chester River Packet) and more recently with the outdoor dinner program that Hilari has designed. It has been an ideal partnership. We have complementary strengths and bring them to these events. We believe that, in addition to benefiting both of our operations, we are adding an element to the Chestertown community," said Kelley McIntire, owner of Occasions Catering.
"It's a great example of the 'rising tide theory,' she adds. "In addition, the 'crew' at Brampton (Hilari, Dave, Donna, et. al) has been fun to work with."
"Dinner guests can expect an elevated farm-to-table experience starting with a welcome glass of Crow Vineyard and Winery Sparkling Barbera and an appetizer-infused cocktail hour followed by dinner on the Renaissance Garden Terrace. The menu has been crafted to include a first course of heirloom tomato gazpacho, followed by a salad of baby greens including a Champagne vinaigrette. The main course will be a jumbo lump crab cake with lemon aioli and filet mignon with a reduction and corn salsa accompaniment. A dessert of sweet blueberry crumble with homemade ice cream will follow," according to an announcement from the inn.
The evening's wine pairings will be presented by James Glendinning of J L Beverage Marketing of Baltimore, (Glendinning Wine & Spirits) and the evening's piano entertainment will be performed by concert pianist Michael Casey of Rock Hall.
"We just started working with James Glendinning," said Hilari Reinhart. "We were pleased to learn he supports several other small businesses on the Eastern Shore in their fine wine and spirit collections. He's extremely knowledgeable and has helped us select a great selection of wines and spirits not found just anywhere. He also helped us identify a great selection to pair with our Dining Under the Stars dinners. It's a fun pairing we have worked out."
Brampton 1860 is located at 25227 Chestertown Rd., Chestertown. For tickets and additional information, visit rb.gy/wk414r, bramptoninn.com, or call 410-778-1860.

Advanced tickets are $60 with a VIP package costing $100 per person. For more: https://whcp.org/events/

title: Tapping away: Author pens children's book using 'early 100-year old Royal typewriter'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Tapping away: Author pens children's book using 'early 100-year old Royal typewriter'

 July 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 693
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Author David Wright recently published his first book, "Marty McSwirl," through Dorrance Publishing.Wright grew up in Sudbury, Mass., graduated from the Air Force Academy in 2000 and have been serving since. He has flown the F-15, F-22 and A-10 and is currently the deputy commander of the 175th Wing, Maryland Air National Guard.
He and his family live in North Beach.
The 30-page book retails for $39 — the eBook is $34 — and is available at https://bookstore.dorrancepublishing.com/.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?It was [Sudbury, Mass.- based Josiah Haynes Elementary School teacher Lee] Jones, my fourth grade and to this day, favorite teacher, who inspired me to be a writer. Despite my rambunctious nature which was not ideally suited to being a student, he managed to tease out a bit of creativity. I must have a penchant for alliterative titles because my favorite project that year was story about a Viking named Pudgy Pinkinson. Yet I think my path was set when Mr. Jones assigned us to create an auto-biography, the last chapter being a prediction of what we would be in the future. In that last chapter I said I would go to the Air Force Academy, become a fighter pilot, and finally become an author. Thus far the first two have come true and I suppose that "Marty McSwirl" is the first step towards making the latter come to fruition.
What inspires you to write?My children John, Anna and Andrew and a lone, tired-looking squirrel inspired me to write "Marty McSwirl." Years ago, I had just finished raking leaves and the kiddos immediately began rollicking in the pile, exactly the way kids should. Despite the chaos, a squirrel joined the fray, apparently looking for acorns. I thought to myself, "He must be a tired dad squirrel gathering food for a big family," and thus was born "Marty McSwirl".
Do you consider writing to be a career?Not yet, but like my fourth grade autobiography predicted, I hope it will be one day.
What kind of writing process do you use?I sit down at my grandmother's old roll-top desk, slide a piece of paper into my nearly 100-year old Royal typewriter, and tap away. I started using a typewriter years ago after reading an opinion in the newspaper lamenting the lost art of letter-writing. Sharing an admiration for things that have stood the test of time, I determined to resurrect that lost art, yet my handwriting is terrible. So I bought an old typewriter and now, when I sit down in front of the Royal, I drift away to wherever my imagination leads me.
How did you publish your book?
After writing "Marty McSwirl," it lay dormant for years, gathering dust among the pile of unpublished works in a desk drawer. Eventually, I applied for a copyright through the Library of Congress and once granted, a number of publishing companies contacted me asking if I would like to publish. I ended up choosing Dorrance Publishing, who walked me through the project.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?Julia Donaldson is the first author who comes to mind. I've been reading to the kids every night since birth and they always responded best to books that told a good story in the form of a poem. When I began writing "Marty McSwirl" it was with my kids in mind, hoping to create a book that I could one day read to them before bed.
What are you working on now?I have a few unpublished works ready for an eager illustrator and book agent.
Please include a brief description of your bookMarty McSwirl is the tale of a squirrel who invents an acorn harvester with the help of some friends. Their efforts meet with success and Marty decides to share the fruits of his labor with family, friends and neighbors. In essence, the story is a woodland creature Thanksgiving origin story.
Please include an excerpt from the book"When Marty came back with his acorn sack at the end of each long day,
Mrs. McSwirl was there with a hug,
His children snuggled upon the rug,
But despite all his care, the cupboard lay bare, he must find an easier way." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an author's children's book publication, writing process, and personal story, aligning with the 'Entertainment' topic as it highlights creative work and authorship. While 'Arts & Culture' is relevant due to the book's narrative, the article's structure as a profile piece in the 'Entertainment' section of the newspaper reinforces this classification.

title: Elkton Music Hall celebrates first anniversary
author: Lilly Howard Special to the Cecil Whig / Star Democrat
content:
Elkton Music Hall celebrates first anniversary

 July 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard Special to the Cecil Whig / Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Elkton Music Hall celebrated its one year anniversary on last month with the same band that played during the hall's debut, Cosmic Guilt. Over the past year, owners Ric Cunningham and Katie Salsbury have welcomed over 500 musicians and guests to the venue while seeing audiences grow as more bands come to play.Cunningham and Salsbury moved here eight years ago from Washington D.C., and fell in love with Elkton's small town vibes. After getting exhausted from traveling miles to see live music, the couple decided to launch their dream business right here in Elkton and bring the music to the people.
"I think the biggest accomplishments are seeing people having a good time and getting to meet so many people here locally and people that are traveling in and just love music and get what we're trying to do here. At the end of the day, it's a lot of hard work, but seeing the people smiling and singing along, dancing like that is the single most greatest compliment, you know, seeing it working," said Cunningham.
Elkton Music Hall has a 300 person capacity, and has had three sold out shows, including their fourth show ever last summer when Sungold performed.
For the first time in his career, booking agent Ron Ozer is working with over 500 agents worldwide to cull musicians to Elkton Music Hall. His goal is to keep booking shows, because the more people that come through the venue the more visibility they have. They've received great feedback from the bands. Since opening, folk legend Tom Paxton performed and told the crowd to look at their website and get tickets to a show by someone they've never heard of, because that is how he got famous, according to Ozer who was working that night.
"They take care of the artists, they respect the artists. Which you don't get too often. So the hospitality of everyone in town is wonderful, it's just got that really good little small town feel. I like playing gigs in small towns where you get to talk to almost every single person there," said lead singer of Cosmic Guilt, James Everhart.
Elkton Music Hall brings the town to life as the bands draw in a big crowd that fills the restaurants and bars with business around showtime.
Everhart feels honored to have been the first band to open for EMH and was excited to play their anniversary show.
"It's always an honor when I get asked to do something like that because that's that community's baby. Everyone there in that town, they were all so proud of it and still are. And it was very flattering to be asked to step out on their first night and receive their trust," said Everhart when reflecting on their opening show last summer.
Lead vocalist in one of the opening bands, Kid Davis and the Bullets, Michael Davis is a long time favorite musician of Everhart and even played at his wedding. Everheart plans on helping produce the Bullets next album. Being some of each other's favorite musicians, they love working together and had a blast performing on Saturday at Elkton Music Hall.
"There's no reason to do it if you're not having fun," said Davis.
There is more music overflowing from downtown Elkton, to catch the next show visit their website. Maybe you'll find your new favorite artist. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Elkton Music Hall's anniversary celebration, highlighting live music events, local artists, and the venue's role in community engagement. While there are cultural and local elements, the primary emphasis is on entertainment through music performances.

title: 'California Dreamin' concert goers ride the wave of good vibes
author: ADRIAN COTTON Special to the Star Democrat
content:
'California Dreamin' concert goers ride the wave of good vibes

 August 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ADRIAN COTTON Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 475
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — The dream was alive in Rock Hall, as the sounds of the '60s and the '70s filled the air.On Sunday, Mark Einstein, Clark Bjorke, Brian Cole, Dave Fife, Meghan First, Richard Geller, Don and Julie Gill, Stu Gray, Matt Mielnick, Bob Miller, Barbara Parker, Dave Sharp, Antoinette Smith, Bob and Laura Taylor, Steve Tremills, and Greg Zane came together as the Mainstay Players for an event called "California Dreamin'."
Community members and friends from far and wide came out to celebrate the music of a bygone era. It was a packed house of over 100 attendees.
Held on the corner of Main Street and Sharp Street in Rock Hall, this event paid tribute to the icons of Laurel Canyon, inviting guests to a time when California was the epicenter of rock and roll.
According to the host of the event, WCTR's Sunday morning on-air personality Ya Buddy Emerson, "everyone in attendance had a great time. There were smiles all over the building. Not a single person left without getting their money's worth."
Emerson added people were already asking when the next tribute show would be.
Following a few announcements from the man who was instrumental in organizing the event, guitarist and vocalist Mark Einstein, Emerson kicked off the show with an introduction.
Following the intro, the concert opened up with, "Mr. Tambourine Man," originally performed by The Byrds.
The format of the first set saw various combinations of The Mainstay Players performing songs such as "Love the One You're With" by Stephen Stills, "Crazy Love" by POCO and "Suite: Judy Blues Eyes" by Crosby, Stills and Nash.
Throughout the night, the host would jump onstage with a joke, funny story or game.
During intermission, t-shirts were sold and guests were allowed to partake in some free oysters. There were also beverages and desserts available.
After intermission, Emerson opened the second half of show with a little bit of history that vividly described Laurel Canyon, before Stu Gray and Meghan First performed a beautiful rendition of Crosby, Stills and Nash's "Guinevere."
The second half of the show featured songs like, "Big Yellow Taxi" by Joni Mitchell; "Teach Your Children" by Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young; and "These Day" by Jackson Browne. The finale of the show had the Mainstay Players came together, and with some prompting, everyone in attendance stood and sang "California Dreamin'" by The Mamas and The Papas.
The hard work put in by everyone, including a month's worth of rehearsals, paid off. Mainstay community members are already cooking up the next tribute show. A few ideas being thrown about are a Bob Dylan tribute or even a tribute to Motown.
One thing that's for sure is that if the next event is anything like this one, a good time will be had by all.
To find more information about the Mainstay, as well a video of this event and other events, visit mainstayrockhall.org 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Local Life is a secondary consideration due to the community-centric nature, but the core subject is entertainment.

title: The Caroline/Dorechester fair: a fair too big for one county
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
The Caroline/Dorechester fair: a fair too big for one county

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline/Dorchester County Fair is coming to the Shore. This upcoming week, residents of the two counties and travelers far and wide will come together to experience the fair's many events, including fun games, live music, animal shows and more.Commonly known as "the fair too big for one county," this annual event will be hosted at the Caroline County 4-H Park from Wednesday, Aug. 7, to Saturday, Aug. 10.
The event is put on by 4-H, a youth development organization, and Agricultural FFA Education, a youth agricultural education program.
John "Mitchell" Conneely, president of fair board, said this fair is a generational event. As a kid he would come to this fair and now he sees his children going to the same fair he grew up loving.
Conneely said he enjoys working with 4-H and the effort they put into hosting events for young people.
"Myself and the board members have some connections with 4-H, whether its children or grandchildren in 4-H," Conneely said. "We all try to make the fair bigger and better and with more enjoyment for the community."
Featured entertainment will include Jones Boys, Amish Outlaws and The Reagan Years. The fair will have a mechanical bull, a children's day program, a video game trailer and horse trick riding.
Included events are the Royal Pageant — Fair Little, Princess and Queen; the 4-H Cake Auction; the Youth Alpaca Fun Show; the Dress a Goat Contest; the Greased Pig Contest; a kids pedal tractor; baby contests; a youth pet show and the Livestock auction of 4-H and FFA livestock projects.

title: America's favorite hobbies revealed: Our ten favorite ways to spend free time
author: Melanie Allen Wealth of Geeks
content:
America's favorite hobbies revealed: Our ten favorite ways to spend free time

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Melanie Allen Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 836
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Americans spend more than five hours every day on leisure activities and hobbies, ranking second only to sleep in the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics' 2023 time use survey.Though we all love leisure time, we don't spend it the same way. Some pastimes are far more popular than others.
America's Favorite Hobbies
A Statista survey of more than 60,000 Americans determined which hobbies we love the most.
Discover something new to try as we explore America's favorite pastimes.
Because respondents could choose more than one hobby, reported percentages surpassed 100.
Cooking/Baking
Cooking and baking top the list of America's favorite hobbies. Two in five respondents (41%) spend their free time in the kitchen.
Tiffany McCauley of The Gracious Pantry explains why she loves cooking so much. "Cooking is therapeutic for me," she says. "To be able to tune out the world and all its problems, turn on some music, and just let myself have 30-60 minutes of creativity with my food simply soothes my soul."
McCauley adds that sampling her creations is an added bonus. "Ending up with a dish that tastes amazing is a whole new level of comfort on top of the stress relief. The entire process is basically an escape with a delicious finale."
Reading
Americans love relaxing with a good book — 37% of respondents report reading as a pastime. Good reads come in many forms and can transport audiences to new worlds, educate, motivate, enlighten, and excite.
Reading has immeasurable benefits: it enhances creativity, reduces stress, and provides much-needed stimulation as we age. Additionally, increased internet and library access means reading comes at little to no cost to many.
Pets
Americans rank spending time with pets among their favorite hobbies. Around 35% spend free time caring for furry friends. These figures are unsurprising as 95% of pet owners consider their pets family.
Interacting with animals isn't just a fun hobby; moving and exercising with a pet positively benefits animal and human health and wellness. Animals provide companionship, reduce stress, keep humans active, and stimulate the production of feel-good chemicals like oxytocin.
Video Games
About one-third of all Americans unwind with their favorite video games.
Gaming provides a fantastic escape from real life. Players can be the hero one day and an evil villain the next. Some games build critical life skills, like team building, problem-solving, and enhanced focus.
Outdoor Activities
More than 30% of survey respondents said they engage in outdoor activities. In 2019, the National Recreation and Parks Association surveyed people to learn what "outdoor activities" they prefer.
The survey found that most (58%) consider outdoor gatherings with family and friends — playing games, barbecuing, or having a picnic — their favorite outdoor activity. Nearly half (48%) said they enjoy going to the pool, while 45% reported hiking as their favorite outdoor activity.
Shopping
Nearly one-third of Americans spend their free time shopping.
Critics may say shopping isn't a hobby, but for many, activities performed to relax count as hobbies, which means shopping fits the bill.
Unfortunately, unmanaged retail therapy can lead to overspending.
Traveling
Around 29% cite travel as their preferred hobby, though this and other more expensive interests would likely attract more people if they weren't as cost-prohibitive. A 2023 travel study says more than 50% of non-travelers report they can't afford to travel or can't take time off work.
Traveling is a fantastic hobby because it allows us to visit bucket list destinations, learn about different cultures, and experience the world from a fresh perspective.
Arts/Crafts/DIY
Around 25% of respondents report enjoying arts, crafts, and DIY activities in their free time, such as sewing, woodworking, drawing, painting, and other hands-on tasks.
Photography and writing scored high enough to merit their own categories, with 19% of respondents saying they spent time on each activity.
Arts and crafts are ideal hobbies for those with little time, money, or space. Anyone can start drawing with just a pencil and paper, crochet with a needle and yarn, or make paper mâché crafts with old paper and flour.
Socializing
Friendships are crucial to health and happiness. Studies show that people with thriving social lives are happier, healthier, and live longer than those who spend time in solitude.
Despite its importance, only 26% of respondents reported socializing as a hobby.
Board Games
About 26% of respondents enjoy playing board games during downtime. Tabletop games span several genres, including traditional offerings like Monopoly, solo games like puzzles, trading card games like Magic: The Gathering, and roleplaying games like Dungeons & Dragons.
Playing board games has many benefits, including education, cognitive improvement in older adults, and improvement of ADHD symptoms in children.
More Favorite Pastimes
Americans enjoy a wide variety of activities. Approximately one-fifth of survey respondents participate in hobbies like gardening, meditation, working on old cars, fitness, photography, and writing.
Health Benefits of Hobbies
Engaging in fulfilling hobbies is crucial to health, happiness, and overall life satisfaction. Many of America's most popular hobbies have well-documented impacts on health and wellness. Hobbies, in general, tend to reduce stress, decrease loneliness, and promote overall well-being.
There's no greater time than the present to start a new hobby and inject more happiness into your life.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on leisure activities and hobbies Americans enjoy, including entertainment-related pursuits like reading, video games, and socializing. While it touches on health benefits, the core subject aligns with entertainment and lifestyle topics. The publication's section is listed as 'Entertainment,' reinforcing this classification.

title: Young filmmakers find inspiration on the Shore
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News
content:
Young filmmakers find inspiration on the Shore

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News | Section: Entertainment 
 
 964
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The picturesque scenic byways, rural farmland, and winding pathways of Kent County have proven to be an advantageous creative backdrop for a pair of young filmmakers who have their sights set on making their mark in the ever-changing landscape of independent filmmaking.Recently, the pair compiled the portfolio of short film projects that they already have under their belts, cut trailers, and built an online home for their production company, Moosehead Pictures, a venture that was two-and-a-half years in the making.
Their personal narrative about how they got here, however, winds half-way around the world and back, and may have never turned out to be a story worth telling if not for the pandemic, as Will Freda of Chestertown and Vanessa Grapes, a native of Sterling, Virginia tell it. The couple met while teaching abroad in Thailand on a one-year Fulbright Scholarships prior to the COVID-19 outbreak.
Now both in their late 20s, the couple clicked easily over their love of cinema and enjoyed taking in many films together during their time in Thailand. They bonded over their struggle to learn the language and they developed friendships with locals there that they are certain will endure despite the distance.
Distance would also play a starring role in the relationship at this point, as once their Fulbright year was over, the couple would need to go where their careers were taking them. Will's would take him to China and Vanessa was hired to teach English at the high school level back in Virginia. They committed to making a go of a long-distance relationship, seeing each other whenever their schedules could align.
While Freda was teaching middle school history in China, he learned his twin brother, James, coincidently, was also in China at that time studying for his master's degree. And it would be while the three of them were vacationing in Slovenia that the pandemic broke out and the travel restrictions kicked in. The brothers, unable to get back to Shanghai, returned to the States, and to Maine where James was currently living, and where they both grew up.
Like many people enduring COVID at the time, it provided them the opportunity to re-examine their lives and re-connect as brothers over aspects of their shared childhoods. Part of that time as teenagers, Will said, was spent spitballing ideas for movie scripts.
"I just think it's interesting that COVID is what forced them to be living together and really explore what they wanted out of life," Vanessa said.
The brothers were all-in and made a commitment to pursue filmmaking, and they founded their company, Moosehead Pictures while riding out the Pandemic in Moosehead Lake, Maine.
From there it has been a whirlwind of learning the industry from square one. Challenges came fast and furiously in the form of learning which cameras worked best for them, the dynamics of shooting in different locations and under varying conditions related to light and surroundings, and the aspects of casting and securing locations for shooting.
And like most independent filmmakers, this team started out on a shoestring using mostly their own money to produce their first short, Jess at Christmastime, which was shot on location in Brooklyn, N.Y. They found that attending independent film festivals was a great way to meet like minds and learn how films were financed. They were also able to tap into some independent filmmaker resources, like the New England Film Industry, to get their first project produced.
For that first film, Vanessa said, she played the role of observer and basically helped out with whatever she could on set to support Will in his cinematic efforts. Going forward, she is flexing her artistic and creative muscles for their current project by designing a series of dramatic masks to be worn by some of the lead actors for their first feature film, Sol Sillion, for which they have already shot their "proof of concept" scenes.
While they described their first two films as "a slice of life" narratives, they are now leaning in and creating what they described as "elevated" or "intellectual" horror films. The change in direction to the horror genre was a pragmatic one, they said.
"There's more money for low-budget horror films than there are for other genres… for whatever reason, horror films get bought a lot for distribution because there's a big audience for them," explains Will, who described the feature, Sol Sillion, as a take on Alice in Wonderland.
"If Alice walked into a pagan horror film," he added.
The team hopes to shoot the rest of this project at the end of the year in and around Kent County once they have raised the necessary capital to produce it. They are hopeful their growing body of work will resonate with potential investors in the arts who appreciate the passion and dedication it takes to create these works.
In addition to financing, the couple said they are always on the look-out for others who share their passion for film and wish to become part of something unique. Whether they would like to become extras, set-builders, artists, painters, or even dancers, the team is hoping interested local parties will reach out to them via their website.
Meanwhile, the couple has some short- and long-term goals. This January they will return to the film festival circuit to show the full version of their film short, Rachel in Vacationland. (All of their trailers, including Bug Brain, their first horror film shot on location in Kent County, are available for viewing on moosedeadpictures.com.)
And 'big picture', the couple hopes to one-day return to where it all began, Thailand.
"We have a script for a movie that we would like to make in Thailand," said Vanessa. "So, we would like to live in Thailand for a few years filming that, and then settle down somewhere and have kids. So, we have a whole dream." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on young filmmakers creating independent films, their production company, and their work in the entertainment industry. While Arts & Culture is related to filmmaking as an art form, the direct context of entertainment media and film festivals aligns more closely with the 'Entertainment' category.

title: Explore Maryland: Film festival returns after hiatus
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Explore Maryland: Film festival returns after hiatus

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Film buffs rejoice as the Southern Maryland Film Festival returns to the area following a four-year hiatus.This year's festival will be held from 10 a.m. to 10:30 p.m. Saturday, Aug. 17, at R/C Theatres' Lexington Exchange Movies 12, located at 44800 Oak Crest Drive in California.
"We are so excited; the hiatus was painful," Film Festival Representative Maria Fleming Maria Fleming said. "Getting restarted has been a little painful but it definitely has been a passion project and a labor of love."
Members of the public can meet the filmmakers 6 to 7:30 p.m. at Taphouse 1637, located at 23418 Three Notch Road in California.
Guests will be able to attend a round-robin discussion on Independent Filmmaking in the 21st Century, including topics like scouting locations, the use of drones, and the public's obsession with zombies anyway?
In addition, the jury award winner will be announced. Food and beverages will be available for purchase.
Thirty films will be shown throughout the day in 90-and 180-minute blocks and will be divided by theme: Family-Friendly (suitable for all ages), Southern Maryland Heritage (featuring a documentary on guitarist Danny Gatton), Maryland-made Exhibition Films (including an award-winning animated short), Love and Relationships (from first dates to seasoned marriages), Suspense (to keep viewers on the edge of their seats), and Mature (films that contain more graphic language, mature themes and depictions of violence).
Examples of Family-Friendly movies include " Bucket Hat," "Bicycle," "Return to Sender" and "Waiting for a Friend," in which an elderly woman is stood up on a picnic by her friend, although someone else shows up.
Some of the American Heritage films include "Maryland's Wild Oyster Harvest" and "Shifting Tides" about a set of multi-generational watermen based in St. Mary's County, Maryland, and asks how each are adapting to the rising costs, increased regulation, and growing effects of climate change.
Suspense Films include "The Nightmare Within," "Chain Letter" and "Overdue," about a group of teens who begin disappearing in the library, and they're about to find out why. The film was produced by the Charles County Public Library Film Club for Teens.
Maryland-Made films include "Bucket Hat" and "The Tower Road Bus," about Dotson Burns, Jr., who was on the frontlines of school integration as a teacher and then as the first Black principal of a majority-white school in Prince George's County.
Love and Relationships selections include "Philadelphia, My Love," "Replace Me" and "Don't Jump!"
Mature Audience films consist of "Arterial Motive" and "Zombies Are Real," in which an avid Zombie fan finally gets to fight in the ultimate apocalypse.
"Every year we are so surprised at the quality of films we get," Fleming said, "and the ability to share that with the local community and for filmmakers to see their projects up on the big screen. I find that magical."
Tickets will be $9 per block per person regardless of age, length of movie block or number of tickets purchased.
Seating is limited and assigned, and most movies will be shown only once and Fleming said "make sure you buy your tickets early."
Almost all of the films were produced by local and regional filmmakers. The festival's selected films represent a variety of genres and range in length and subject matter, including some content that may not be suitable for all viewers, so attendees are encouraged to read the film descriptions provided on the festival and theatre websites before finalizing their purchase.
For more information on the Southern Maryland Film Festival, email smdfilmfest@gmail.com or go to somdfilmfest.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the return of a film festival, detailing event schedules, film screenings, and community engagement, which aligns directly with the 'Entertainment' topic. While 'Arts & Culture' is a close secondary option, the explicit mention of the event as a festival and its entertainment-focused activities make 'Entertainment' the best fit.

title: QAC unveils 2024 visitors guide
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC unveils 2024 visitors guide

 August 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Highlighting local sites, cuisine, and the great outdoors, the Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development presents 2024 Official Visitors Guide to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners July 9.Heather Tinelli, economic and tourism development director and April Plum of marketing and destination development specialist presented the newly developed visitors guide.
This year's comprehensive visitors guide has been a collaboration with county departments, various stakeholders and showcases the work of local photographers, Plum said.
The visitors guide includes all the information you'd need to visit the eclectic world of Queen Anne's County and top features this year include South Island and Cross Island Trail maps, complete with fold out tearable maps.
Working with Geographic Information Systems (GIS), and parks and recreation the guide highlights how to have a wonderful day out on the water including information on waterways and the best places to launch a boat, she said.
The guide is available in both print and digital to highlight the highly requested aspects for all visitors.
The guide also highlights county landmarks and interviews local experts covering topics such as birding and fishing.
"So that visitors can hear it directly from the experts," she said.
A digital version of the guide is available at https://visitqueenannes.com/visitors-guide.

title: 'Bigger than any July Fourth show anyone has seen': PyroJam brings fireworks and music
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
'Bigger than any July Fourth show anyone has seen': PyroJam brings fireworks and music

 August 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 588
 Words 

 Read News Document

 From the late afternoon into the evening and well after sunset, the third annual PyroJam at Jefferson Patterson Park and Museum on St. Leonard on Saturday is expected to light up the sky in southern Calvert County.Organizers for the event promise to deliver a show that will rock the day and shock the night. In all, six fireworks shows will be offered with three different local bands providing the musical entertainment on stage from 3 to 8:30 p.m., with the fireworks show lasting from 8:45 to 10:30 p.m. Advertised as a "rain or shine" event, severe weather could potentially postpone the event until Sunday evening at 8 p.m.
Billed as a total adventure for all of your senses, the PyroJam will offer a fireworks competition that is a much more difficult chore than the average Independence Day fireworks show that onlookers are accustomed to witnessing at ball parks and other outdoor venues. PyroJam organizer Tim Jameson noted the response from the two previous shows at Jefferson Patterson Park was so overwhelming that tickets for this year's event have been selling rapidly.
"The first two years went very well and this one is on pace to be even more popular than they were," Jameson said. "The competition is going to be tremendous. We have over 120 specialists from nearly 30 countries competing for spots in the final. There are three shows that make up the competition then the judges will determine the top three finalists for the grand finale, which promises to be even bigger than any July Fourth show anyone has seen."
Gates open at 2:30 p.m. and three musical groups will take the stage for performances beginning at 3. Loose Change will perform first, followed by Blair's West at 4:45 p.m. then First To Eleven at 7 p.m. The National Anthem will be performed at 8:30 p.m., followed by an appetizing opening fireworks display at 8:45 p.m. that will give onlookers a mild glimpse of what to expect in the main event.
In essence, the fireworks show is divided into three competitions for spots in the grand finale, with the first show getting under way at 9 p.m., followed by the second show at 9:20 p.m. and the third at 9:40 p.m. A panel of judges will select the top three performers based on various criteria and the finale at 10 p.m. is provide to take onlookers on an emotional roller coaster courtesy of the musical accompaniment to the numerous fireworks on display.
General admission parking is free, but there is a preferred parking option of $30 for those want to park close and be among the first to leave the venue. Organizers have noted on their website that all parking areas are within 2-6 minutes of the event.
If you go
The PyroJam musical and fireworks show is set for this Saturday, Aug. 24, from 3 to 10:30 pm. at Jefferson Patterson Park and Museum, located at 10515 Mackall Road in St. Leonard. In all, there will be a total of six fireworks shows starting at 8:30 p.m., with music provided by three local bands. There are also food trucks and an area for kids.
Tickets are $45 in advance, $50 standard, $55 for hurry up and $60 for last chance. VIP pass available early for $150 or at the gate for $160 for those who would also prefer a catered dinner and unlimited non-alcoholic drinks and one alcoholic beverage for those 21 years of age and older. A military discount of 10% is available on all tickets.
For more information, go to www.pyrojamusa.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a fireworks and music event (PyroJam) with entertainment elements, including live bands, competitions, and a focus on sensory experiences. The section label 'Entertainment' and content about performances align most directly with this topic.

title: CBMM to hold Charity Boat Auction Aug. 31
author: Staff Writer
content:
CBMM to hold Charity Boat Auction Aug. 31

 August 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 199
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St. Michaels will hold its annual Charity Boat Auction on Saturday, Aug. 31."Dozens of boats and watercraft, ranging in size and performance, will be auctioned off to the highest bidders. New this year, there will be reserves on several top-quality vessels, while the rest will be offered with no minimum," CBMM said in an announcement.
Doors will open at 8 a.m. and the auction begins at 11 a.m.
For the official rules, auction details, absentee bidding protocols, and inventory updates, visit cbmm.org/CharityBoatAuction.
CBMM accepts and sells boats via it Charity Boat Donation Program, year-round.
"Every sale directly supports CBMM's mission to explore and preserve the history, environment, and culture of the entire Chesapeake Bay region and make this resource available to all," the museum said in a statement.
There will also be boating gear for sale as well as food trucks and beer at the Labor Day weekend event.
All registration for in-person bidding is handled on the day of the event. Registered bidders pay a $5 paddle fee and receive free admission.
For more check out: https://cbmm.org/event/charity-boat-auction/
If you have additional questions about the auction or available inventory, please contact CBMM's Charity Boat Donation team at boatdonation@cbmm.org or 410-310-5103.
