title: Upcoming Avalon shows: From Gershwin to guitar heroes
author: Staff Writer
content:
Upcoming Avalon shows: From Gershwin to guitar heroes

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are some of the upcoming shows at the Avalon Theatre and Stoltz Listening Room in downtown Easton. The summaries are from the Avalon. For more information (including for tickets) check out https://avalonfoundation.org/.Trae Sheehan
August 22
Doors: 7:30 pm Show: 8 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
Born in the heart of Appalachia, twenty-one year old Trae Sheehan grew up surrounded by music and family in his home state of West Virginia. A bona fide traveling entertainer, Trae has been touring North America in a minivan since high school, learning to put on the show nobody knew they needed. He pulls inspiration from legendary storytellers such as Bob Dylan, the Eagles, and Randy Newman to form his unique songwriting palette and deliver a sound that can only come from the deep roots of an old West Virginia soul. A homebody at heart, Trae spends his time off of the road writing and recording in his attic studio or singing on the roof.
Tommy Dorsey Orchestra
August 23
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
In Big Band history, the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra is recognized as one of the best all-around dance bands. It could swing with the best of them, and no other band could come close to Dorsey's when it came to playing ballads. Considered "The Sentimental Gentleman of Swing", Dorsey was a master at creating warm, sentimental, and always musical moods — at superb dancing and listening tempos. He sustained these moods through the arrangements of the likes of Paul Weston, Axel Stordahl and Sy Oliver, and he showcased singers like Frank Sinatra who could project them brilliantly. Dorsey's legacy continues today under Jeff Bush's leadership as the orchestra's Music Director. Jeff joined the band in 2000 when trombone legend Buddy Murrow was conductor, often playing many of the great Tommy Dorsey solos and fronting the band on occasion in Buddy's absence. After taking a break to begin graduate work at The Manhattan School of Music, Jeff has returned to lead one of the greatest big bands of all-time. https://www.tommydorseyorchestra.net
Trio Music: Apart and Together with Quinn Parsley, Nevin Dawson, and Ashley Watkins
August 30
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
Don't miss this eclectic summer's evening of music in the Stoltz highlighting three of the best musicians on the Eastern Shore today! Playing solo sets and as a trio, Nevin Dawson (viola, looper pedal), Quinn Parsley (classical guitar), and Ashley Watkins (flute) will play music from a wide variety of time periods and styles, including Bach, music from videogames, French Impressionism, original compositions, and more.
Dominick Farinacci's Rhapsody in Blue Revisited
August 31
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
Lovers of timeless classics will not want to miss this reimagining of the historic George Gershwin work 100 years after its premiere! Building on the memorable themes of "Rhapsody in Blue," Dominick Farinacci and his band will present a new interpretation of Gershwin's iconic work, supported by an incredible cast of jazz musicians spanning three generations. Farinacci's rendition of "Rhapsody's" ballad theme has captivated listeners, amassing over 3 million streams on Spotify. In addition to "Rhapsody in Blue", the concert will feature other beloved Gershwin classics and selections from his era, offering a rich and vibrant musical journey. https://www.dominickfarinacci.com/
Jake Shimabukuro
September 6
Doors 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
By now, if you know the 'ukulele, you might know the name, the innovator who is Jake Shimabukuro. He has captivated audiences around the world with his unique and dynamic style. With his mother as his first teacher of the instrument, Jake embraced a deep love and respect for the 'ukulele and has explored new and unexpected ways to push the boundaries of what was possible on the humble four-strings. Each album has showcased his mastery of the instrument and his ability to weave together diverse genres to create a cohesive and captivating musical experience. Enter his newest, and most personal album yet. "Grateful" is a coming home for Jake. With a literal who's who of Hawai'i-based musicians, this collection of songs is performed live, in-studio with Jake's friends, contemporaries, mentors, and heroes — all kanikapila-style in a return to his roots. "Grateful" is the follow-up to his critically acclaimed duets album with artists ranging from Willie Nelson, Ziggy Marley and Bette Midler to Jimmy Buffett, Jack Johnson and Kenny Loggins.
Hugh Ellis Bennett
September 6,
Doors: 7:30 p.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
North Carolina-based singer-songwriter Hugh Ellis Bennett improvises an indie/progressive bluegrass/folk sound through flatpicking and vocal melodies. The heartfelt musical style that results during Bennett's shows can't help but pull people together, despite their similarities or differences. Starting with a simple philosophy that assumes from dust to dust, we are all the same, Bennett sees his music acting as a thread that helps to hold us together and remind us of that crucial point in a world that seems to have forgotten it.
Caleb Stine
September 12
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
Caleb Stine is a singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and visual artist. Though he makes his living as a folk musician, Stine wouldn't call what he does a job; he considers it a calling. His work is part-mystic poet, part-traveling preacher. As Americana UK observed, "Stine's upfront personality [is] seeking to make a personal connection with everyone in the venue." The albums and shows are the tip of the iceberg; to get to where he is today, Stine has put in decades of daily practice, day jobs, and deep commitment to the craft of music. "There's an element of endurance to almost everything I do," says Stine, who plays 100+ shows a year, has released 14 albums of original music, and shares a series of viral Instagram videos called "Caleb Stine Says Keep Going," encouraging followers to dig deep into a creative practice of their own. It's his love of music that shines through his shows, imbuing them with a communal joy that spans generations and celebrates life at its most essential. https://calebstine.com/
James McMurtry with BettySoo
September 13
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
"The simple fact is that James McMurtry may be the truest, fiercest songwriter of his generation..." Stephen King in Entertainment Weekly James McMurtry, the acclaimed singer, songwriter, and guitarist, began his interest in music at the age of seven when his father, novelist Larry McMurtry, gave him his first guitar. McMurtry's mother, an English professor, taught him how to play it. "My mother taught me three chords," he recalls, "and the rest I just stole as I went along. I learned everything by ear or by watching people." After 20 years in rock, folk, and Americana, McMurtry's most recent effort, "The Horses and the Hounds" (2021), backs personal narratives with effortless elegance and endless energy. The collection, which McMurtry says has "the ghost of Warren Zevon stomping around among the guitar tracks," spotlights a seasoned tunesmith in peak form as he turns toward reflection and revelation. He will be joined on the Avalon stage by Betty Soo, a world-class vocalist who "may well have the most gorgeous voice in Texas …if not in all contemporary folk — its purity and strength can be downright devastating." (Acoustic Guitar) https://www.jamesmcmurtry.com/ https://bettysoo.com/
Comedy @ the Stoltz with Jared Stern
September 14
Two Shows — Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m. Doors: 9 p.m.; Show: 9:30 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
Headliner Jared Stern has been making complete strangers laugh at him for twenty years and counting. Voted the 2023 (and 2013) Best Comedian in D.C. by the readers of the Washington City Paper, he was a featured performer at last year's North Carolina Comedy Festival. Other comedy shows where he has performed include the 2017 What A Joke Fest, the 2018 LaughFest, and the 2019 Oak City Comedy Festival. The Stoltz show, which also features Baltimore comic Jim Meyer, is hosted by Ryan Finch. https://jaredstern.com/
Bombadil "Dancing in Color"
September 18
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
In this collaboration between the folk-pop band Bombadil and contemporary dancer Madison Rivis, Madison has choreographed movements for herself and the band using their latest album "In Color" as inspiration. Bombadil in turn taught Madison how to play and sing the songs. During the show, the three members move seamlessly from instruments to dancing. Costume changes highlight the lyrics and movements of the show. There are hip-hop dance routines with drum loops and quiet ballads with precise gestures inspired by the Martha Graham technique. Expect three-part harmony, tap-dancing, and stories about gardening and being a parent in this unique evening of entertainment. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article explicitly lists upcoming entertainment events (music shows, performances) at local venues, with a clear 'Entertainment' section header. While Arts & Culture is related, the direct focus on performances aligns most precisely with 'Entertainment.'

title: 'They Live': A cult favorite alien invasion movie unlike any other
author: Richard Chachowsk Wealth of Geeks
content:
'They Live': A cult favorite alien invasion movie unlike any other

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Richard Chachowsk Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1592
 Words 

 Read News Document

 John Carpenter is a man of many creative talents. A prolific filmmaker, a proficient composer, and an occasional actor, Carpenter has earned avid acclaim as one of the most lauded directors of the 1980s. Graduating from an indie background with projects like Dark Star and Assault on Precinct 13, Carpenter gained a newfound level of attention with his revolutionary 1978 slasher film, Halloween.From there, the cult filmmaker only enjoyed increased popularity throughout the remainder of the decade, culminating in fan-favorite movies like The Thing, Escape from New York, Big Trouble in Little China, and The Fog, among many others.
Nestled somewhere in the middle of Carpenter's sprawling filmography is a 1988 oddity by the name of They Live. A rip-roaring sci-fi comedy with an endearing message behind it, They Live might not be the first movie people think of when they hear Carpenter's name, but rest assured, it's assuredly among his finest films.
Overarchingly comical yet also surprisingly thought-provoking in its thematic subjects, T hey Live is a masterclass in science fiction subtly wrapped around an over-the-top '80s movie. Without it, who knows what the current state of sci-fi might even be, with They Live helping to lay the groundwork for such later classics as The Matrix years down the line.
What Is 'They Live' About?Set against the hustle and bustle of downtown Los Angeles, They Live tells the story of the ambiguously-named Nada (Roddy Piper), an unemployed drifter struggling to find work in La La Land. As he wanders in search of employment, Nada soon comes across a mysterious pair of sunglasses that allow him to see an alternative version of his surroundings. Presented through crisp black-and-white visuals, this alternative reality offers a glimpse into the world as it truly is: a hellish dystopia where alien invaders have successfully conquered humanity.
Disguising themselves as average people living amongst us, these sinister alien overlords have managed to avoid detection by carefully constructing a reality for their hapless human adversaries. Distracting humankind long enough to transform Earth into the suitable living environment, these aliens hide behind their meticulous-curated reality when it comes to battling humans, using mass deception as their primary means of conquest.
A film that in many ways could have only been made in the '80s, They Live was very much a product of its time. Designed as a satirical treatment of '80s-era classism and socioeconomic policies, Carpenter provided a damning portrait of social phenomena that was only just starting to gain traction in American culture, including mass consumerism, corporate greed, and Americans' growing obsession with material goods. Of course, Carpenter never tips his hand too much when it comes to his thematic subjects, balancing out his topical motifs with cliched action, kitschy humor, and enough '80s one-liners to fill the script for an Arnold Schwarzenegger movie.
Between the witty one-liners and extensive action, Carpenter might have assumed he had a hit on his hands when the movie hit theaters in the fall of 1988. Unfortunately, most critics and casual viewers lambasted They Live for its attempts at social commentary, along with its tough-talking dialogue and equally ham-fisted acting.
A critical failure that quickly faded into the pop culture zeitgeist, They Live 's esteem would only grow more favorable over time, contributing to its continued cult status today.
At the time, it's fair to say that most people simply didn't know what to make of a film as delightfully strange as They Live. After all, how many movies have a powerful critique of '80s capitalism and a comically drawn-out brawl that lasts a whopping six and a half minutes?
It's more than likely that the movie's satirical elements were simply too ahead of its day and age. In the decades since, contemporary viewers have hailed the film as a brilliant takedown of '80s consumer culture, as well as the ever-widening disparity between the wealthy elite and the lower-income working class. Yet, for all its social critiques, it's hard to take any movie seriously that includes Roddy Piper saying, "Mama don't like tattletales" with a straight face.
How 'They Live' Subverts the Standard Alien Invasion PremiseIn more recent decades, more appreciative viewers continue to praise They Live for its effective satirical undertones. Perhaps most famously, the film has directly influenced the widely known Andre the Giant Has a Posse campaign — a street art movement that uses the movie's line "Obey" as its foremost rallying crew. Shepard Fairey, the creator of the campaign, has even gone on record to say of They Live, "The movie has a very strong message about the power of commercialism and the way that people are manipulated by advertising."
As profound They Live 's attack on the capitalist system is, it's also worth mentioning the movie's radical take on the stereotypical alien invasion vehicle. In the decades prior, most sci-fi films featured a more outright depiction of alien attacks, with our extraterrestrial nemeses using technologically advanced weaponry and military superiority to bend humanity to its will. In They Live, Carpenter trades in unique gadgetry for a far more insidious contraption: mass manipulation.
Rather than relying on ray guns and deadly lasers to subdue humankind, They Live 's alien adversaries employ mass media, advertisements, and material possessions to lull humans into a more docile state. Controlling us through subliminal messages that encourage everyone to "consume," "conform," "reproduce," and — most importantly — "obey," these aliens have learned that it's far easier to trick humans than it is to face them in a physical conflict.
As a result, Carpenter paints these alien overlords as the secret society controlling our every thought, turning the greatest aspects of our society (wealth, entertainment, and fulfilling careers) against us.
How 'They Live' Forever Changed Science FictionThrough this new, subtler depiction of an alien invasion, Carpenter managed to add a fresh new spin on age-old story concept in science fiction. Sure, movies like Invasion of the Body Snatchers had pioneered the idea of disguised aliens living among us, but Carpenter took that idea one step further. Rather than aliens replacing us outright, Carpenter wondered aloud whether those same aliens could manipulate us into becoming our own worst enemies.
Lulled into a false sense of security through careful manipulation and rampant consumerism, They Live 's alien invasion succeeds because humanity wants to be tricked. So long as we're free to acquire wealth, power, and the pursuit of individual happiness, why should we care about aliens exploiting us for their own gain? I mean, let's be honest, doesn't that essentially describe the average American workplace?
It was a bold concept that proved somewhat too sardonic and cynical for the happy-go-lucky days of Ronald Reagan's America. Yet it's for this very reason that They Live remains every bit as enjoyable now as it did three decades ago.
Mixing humor and action together with some ever-present topical discussions, Carpenter offered a far different kind of alien invasion than audiences had ever seen before. While viewers at the time might not have appreciated it, the themes examined in the film ended up resonating with viewers in each subsequent decade, stylistically informing later films like 1999's The Matrix.
On the surface, it's hard to see any similarity at all between the Wachowskis' original Matrix film and Carpenter's work on They Live. In the case of the former, the Wachowskis dovetailed classic kung fu action with a rogue A.I. unit as sinister and omnipresent as Terminator 's Skynet. With the latter, Carpenter used tongue-in-cheek comedy and outlandish action to lampoon the traditional alien invasion film. Only when you examine each movie more closely do the resemblances start to emerge (not unlike Nada's first glimpse at the monochrome world beyond our own).
The Matrix tells the story of Keanu Reeve's Thomas Anderson, a computer programmer by day and hacker extraordinaire by night. Using the criminal alias "Neo," Anderson uncovers the dark secret surrounding the seemingly ordinary world around him: that it is, in fact, a hyper realistic construct created by machines to keep humans at bay. Awakening from this artificial reality, Neo joins a group of resistance fighters attempting to destroy their robotic counterparts, freeing humanity from the yoke of their oppressors.
Again, it's difficult to see the similarities between The Matrix and They Live, but they are indeed present. Like the alien antagonists in They Live, The Matrix 's machines rely on a carefully-curated depiction of reality to subdue humankind, distracting us with our seemingly mundane surroundings as they use us as a literal power source.
Using deception and manipulation in lieu of outright violence, The Matrix 's antagonists need humanity to believe in the Matrix to ensure their survival — an attribute shared by the conniving aliens in They Live. In the case of each film, The Matrix and They Live even recruit human collaborators to their cause, promising them a chance for a heightened version of their artificial reality. (In the case of The Matrix, said collaborator takes the form of Cyrus, while in They Live, it's Holly.)
While it's highly unlikely the Wachowskis looked to They Live as its primary source of inspiration, the influences are certainly ingrained in the film, nestled alongside the repeated references to Ghost in the Shell, Akira, and the filmography of Bruce Lee.
They Live might veer towards political satire and The Matrix might opt for more an existential approach, but the core ideas are the same in each film. For this reason alone, They Live would be worth remembering. On the other hand, admiring its narrative influence on The Matrix is just one more reason to love this under-appreciated 1988 action comedy, along with its effective humor, satisfying performances, and Carpenter's characteristically vibrant imagination. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a retrospective analysis of the 1988 film 'They Live,' focusing on its cultural impact, themes, and influence on science fiction. It falls under 'Entertainment' as it discusses a movie's legacy, director, and its place in pop culture. 'Arts & Culture' is a secondary consideration but less specific than 'Entertainment' given the content's focus on film as an entertainment medium.

title: World's top winemaking countries: 11 best wineries around the globe to visit
author: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks
content:
World's top winemaking countries: 11 best wineries around the globe to visit

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 2023, France officially overtook Italy as the top provider of wine on the planet.A new report from Statista estimates France made 48 million hectoliters of wine that year. That accounts for more than 20% of global production. Italy fell behind, but still produced an impressive 16.1% of the worldwide wine supply in 2023, while Spain was responsible for 13.6%.
Most of the world's wineries reside in areas with a mild Mediterranean climate. Weather, terrain, and soil quality are all significant factors in a vineyard's success.
Those looking to expand their knowledge of and appreciation for fine wines can embark on an epic odyssey through the world's top wine-producing countries. Wine tasting is a fun year-round activity you can do at home or abroad. Even better, you can kick back with a glass of vino now, while you plan a journey to enjoy the scenery at the best wineries across the world.
World's 11 Best Wineries To Visit This SeasonStatista identifies the top winemaking countries around the globe according to the total wine produced in 2023. From the mountains of Europe to the valleys of South America, these are 11 essential wineries to visit this season.
Château de L'Engarran, FranceAs the world's top producer of wine, it's unsurprising that France boasts many renowned wineries. If you only have time for one French vineyard visit, consider Château de l'Engarran. This opulent, centuries-old estate sits on the outskirts of Montpellier.
Guests must reserve a guided tour to explore the privately owned castle, cellar, and gardens. In addition to tastings, Château de l'Engarran offers an informative winemaking history museum and a shop where visitors can purchase the estate's wine and local food products.
Antinori Nel Chianti Classico, Italy
Tuscany is among the world's best vacation spots for wine connoisseurs. While there, tour the one-of-a-kind Antinori nel Chianti Classico winery. The Antinoris, a 26-generation Tuscan family, established the vineyard in 2012. They took special care in building the eco-conscious winery with only locally sourced materials.
In 2022, a group of 500 wine and travel experts named Antinori nel Chianti Classico the world's best vineyard, based on its incredible family legacy, innovative design, and thoughtfully crafted wines. To experience this unique operation, book a winery tasting tour and sample three to seven wines. After, catch lunch at the on-site restaurant, Rinuccio 1180.
Bodegas Muga, SpainVisit Bodegas Muga to immerse yourself in La Rioja, Spain's premiere winemaking region. In 1932, members of two local families founded the winery, which now comprises roughly 25,000 square meters. Bodegas Muga combines traditional and modern winemaking techniques to create its signature white, red, and rosé wines.
Activities at Bodegas Muga include an introductory wine-tasting course, guided winery tours, Segway tours through the vineyard, and hot air balloon rides. Skip the slingback heels in favor of comfortable yet stylish shoes, such as sturdy boots or sneakers, as you'll spend much time walking over rough, uneven terrain.
Round Pond Estate, United StatesNapa Valley is a top U.S. wine region, and Round Pond Estate is among the finest local wineries. The estate describes itself as "a destination that promises an immersive, unforgettable experience for wine lovers and travelers alike." This community-driven winemaker specializes in luxurious wines guests can enjoy alongside estate chef-prepared seasonal meals.
According to Round Pond Estate, it uses "one of Napa Valley's only two working olive mills" to produce exceptional olive oils. This California winery is top-notch in every regard, from the property's understated elegance to its breathtaking Mayacamas Mountains landscape.
Madrone Cellars & Cider, United StatesThe Pacific Northwest is another North American winemaking hub, and Washington's Madrone Cellars & Cider is hard to beat. Madrone gives guests an authentic taste of coastal life at its Friday Harbor wine bar and San Juan Island vineyard. Despite being relatively new to the scene, opening in 2017, Madrone has already secured its place among the best wineries statewide.
Shaun and Amy Salamida, a husband and wife duo passionate about natural winemaking, oversee Madrone. The couple believes in producing wines with minimal intervention to allow the fruit's pure flavors to shine. They source all their winemaking grapes from Eastern Washington, emphasizing a commitment to locally grown ingredients and sustainable farming practices.
Viña Santa Cruz, ChileViña Santa Cruz is a must-visit for wine lovers. This Colchagua Valley winery is the first in Chile to be 100% solar-powered. Viña Santa Cruz's mission is to unite the body and soul by educating visitors about the distinct cultures influencing its wines.
Embark on an unforgettable adventure aboard the winery's Swiss cable car and discover the Hill of Cultures, paying homage to the Aymara, Mapuche, and Rapa Nui civilizations. Other unique attractions include carriage rides through the vineyards and stargazing at the on-site astronomical center. These immersive experiences will deepen your appreciation for Viña Santa Cruz's flavorful wine varieties.
Vergelegen Wine Estate, South AfricaSince 1700, the Vergelegen Wine Estate has been at the forefront of South Africa's winemaking industry. Its rich heritage is evident in the sprawling gardens, forests, and central homestead. Vergelegen boasts 21 unique soil types ideal for producing house cabernet sauvignon, merlot, and malbec blends, among others.
From cellar tours to wildlife watching in the Vergelegen Nature Reserve, there's something to entice every guest. Once you taste the winery's iconic creations, you'll understand why it's been a Cape Town staple for centuries.
Audrey Wilkinson, Australia
Visit the Audrey Wilkinson property in Hunter Valley to learn more about Australian wine production. The vineyard's history stretches back to 1886, when the Wilkinson family first acquired the land. In the decades since, Audrey Wilkinson has established itself as a world-class winemaker.
Audrey Wilkinson's picturesque cellar is perched atop a mountain, offering 360-degree views of the valley below. Tasting options include picnics in the vineyard, artisanal cheese and chocolate pairings, and adventures through Hunter Valley Wildlife Park. With several on-site accommodations, Audrey Wilkinson is the ideal getaway for couples or friends who share a love for fine wine.
Bodega Los Toneles, ArgentinaArgentina's Mendoza region boasts many impressive wineries, but Bodega Los Toneles stands above the rest. The historic estate features a mouthwatering restaurant, a chic art gallery, and multiple tasting areas. As an official Cultural Heritage Site of Mendoza, Bodega Los Toneles is an excellent place to dive into Argentine traditions.
Bodega Los Toneles is renowned for its malbec and cabernet sauvignon, which guests can sample on a guided property tour. These unique experiences combine art, history, and winemaking for a one-of-a-kind visit. Tap into the past while savoring the present by enjoying a wine tasting at Bodega Los Toneles.
Weingut Kloster Marienthal, GermanyThe German Weingut Kloster Marienthal has a fascinating history as a former monastery. Various property owners have produced wine at the site for centuries, but it wasn't restored to its former glory until a group of winemakers acquired the estate in 2004. Today, Weingut Kloster Marienthal is a stunning example of 12th-century architecture.
Quality is paramount, as Weingut Kloster Marienthal only produces a small number of wines. Bundle up in tights and a lightweight jacket to descend into the cellar. Learn about the ancient building while sampling several wine varieties. From delicious food offerings to beautiful gardens, there's much to love about Weingut Kloster Marienthal.
Quinta Do Seixo, PortugalPortugal is famous for port wine, and Quinta do Seixo is one of the best places to sample the signature drink. Located in the heart of the Douro Valley, this 100-year-old vineyard makes exceptional tawny, white, ruby, and rosé port wines. Tour the historic winery and taste its iconic creations to gain a deeper appreciation for Portuguese wine.
At Quinta do Seixo, voyagers can enjoy breathtaking views of the Douro River while sipping on flavorful wines, strolling through serene vineyards, and dining on seasonal specialties. Visiting the property will transport wine lovers to a peaceful oasis honoring the past while embracing modernity. Varying tour options make Quinta do Seixo the perfect day trip for any group.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on wine tourism, highlighting winery visits and wine-related experiences as recreational activities. While agriculture and business/economy are tangentially related, the primary context aligns with entertainment due to its emphasis on travel, tasting, and leisure activities.

title: Glenn Miller Orchestra to perform at Avlaon
author: Staff Writer
content:
Glenn Miller Orchestra to perform at Avlaon

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 168
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Avalon Theatre in Easton is hosting a number of jazz, swing and big band performances through the end of the year.That includes a concert by the Glenn Miller Orchestra on Saturday, Sept. 21. Tickets are $35 The show starts at 7 p.m.
According to an announcement from the Avalon promoting the concert:
"The legendary Glenn Miller was one of the most successful of all dance bandleaders back in the Swing Era of the 1930s and '40s. A matchless string of hit records, the constant impact of radio broadcasts and the drawing power at theaters, hotels, and dance pavilion, built and sustained the momentum of popularity. Today, the 18-member ensemble continues to play many of the original Miller arrangements, from the swinging 'Chattanooga Choo Choo' to the beautiful 'Midnight Serenade.' It also plays some more modern selections arranged and performed in the Miller style and sound. Just as it was in Glenn's day, the Glenn Miller Orchestra today is still the most sought after big band in the world." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Swans, butterflies, elephants and the 'Art of Storytelling': Chesapeake Film Festival returning to Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
Swans, butterflies, elephants and the 'Art of Storytelling': Chesapeake Film Festival returning to Easton

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1825
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 17th Annual Chesapeake Film Festival will be held in Easton at the Ebenezer Theater from Friday, Sept. 27 through Sunday, Sept. 29.Here are some of the prime details for the annual event.
For ticket and event info: www. chesapeakefilmfestival.com
Location: Ebenezer Theater at the Prager Family Arts Center (17 S. Washington Street, Easton, Maryland)
Friday, Sept. 27 events Opening day film: "Call Me Dancer" (Noon)
The documentary film was directed by Leslie Shampaine and Pip Gilmour. According to a description from the festival the film features:
"Manish, a young and talented street dancer from the City of Dreams, Mumbai. He struggles against his parents' insistence that he follow a traditional path because they depend on their son's support. When he accidentally walks into an inner-city dance school and encounters a curmudgeonly 70-year old Israeli ballet master, a hunger develops within him. Ambitious and passionate, Manish is now determined to make it as a professional dancer, but the odds are stacked against him."
After the film, there will be Q&A with director Leslie Shampaine
2024 Women of Impact Award Short Film Block (2 p.m. to 4:15 p.m.)
A number of films will be featured Friday including:
"Dear Josephine" (directed by Amber Monet): "Josephine Baker was a global icon known for her iconic banana dance, but what many may not have know is how much Ms. Baker contributed to what we know today as classical ballet."
"Interception: Jayne Kennedy, American Sportscaster" (directed by Safiya Songhai): "When a bronze-skin bombshell rocks the world of Sunday Morning Football, millions tune in...but few know the tumultuous story of Jayne Kennedy, the first Black woman to boldly run interception on the racial lines of American sportscasting."
"Noisy" (directed by Cedric Hill): "Sam gets on the subway to get home. He catches the eye of April. The two of them discover they have way more in common than where they're heading. Sometimes you need a noisy place to have a quiet conversation."
"Superman Doesn't Steal" (directed by Tamika Lamison): "Based on true events this is a coming of age story, set during the 1970's as seen through the eyes of 9 year old Harriet & her brother, who are fascinated with superheroes. However, when they experience a troubling series of Page 3 events, the impact on their family leaves emotional scars and causes them both to grow up as they redefine their understanding of heroes, villains and Superman."
"Every Monday Night" (directed by Nate Houghteling): "In Berkeley, California, a group of men in their 70s and 80s work out some of life's biggest questions on the basketball court."
"Losing Blue" (directed by Leanne Allison): According to CFF, the film "explores the profound concept of losing a color, particularly focusing on the disappearance of the unique blues found in glacier-fed alpine lakes. These mesmerizing hues, shaped by geological processes over millions of years, are now under threat due to climate change. Through stunning cinematography, the film serves as a metaphor for the broader impacts of environmental degradation.
"Racing Rivals: Log Canoes of Chesapeake Bay": "Elegant and agile, propelled by outsized sails offset by nimble crew serving as human ballast, the iconic racing fleet of Chesapeake Bay log canoes embodies tradition, speed and grace. On breezy summer weekends, those that restore, race, and revere them are out to win, but not at the expense of these unique vessels. "Racing Rivals: Log Canoes of Chesapeake Bay" introduces us to this uniquely Chesapeake sport and the passionate sailors vying for coveted trophies."
The evening of Friday, Sept. 27, will also feature several environmental films. Those include:
"Chesapeake Rhythms" (directed by Dave Harp and written by Tom Horton): "A magnificent celebration of the native trumpet swans who migrate to the marshes of the Eastern Shore."
"Diary of an Elephant Orphan" (directed by Hermien Roelvert-Van Gils): "Over the past decade, Southern Africa has witnessed a surge in orphaned and displaced elephant calves due to increased poaching and human encroachment on their traditional habitats. This Page 4 crisis prompted the establishment of an orphanage with an adoptive family structure crucial for the well-being of these vulnerable elephants. Baby Khanyisa, a three-month-old albino calf rescued from a wire snare, becomes a focal point for hope as Adine and her team endeavor to save her life and integrate her into the Jabulani herd, which uniquely comprises mostly former orphans, offering a promising solution to the challenges of elephant rehabilitation in South Africa."
"Every Acre Counts" (directed by Andrea Campbell): "Farmers in the Chesapeake watershed are a critical part of the Bay's restoration and its future. In Every Acre Counts, four farmers from Maryland and Pennsylvania explain why farming is so important to them and how they're utilizing new technology and techniques to better care for the land."
Saturday, Sept. 28A number of films and documentaries will be featured including:
"A Photographic Memory" (directed by Rachel Elizabeth Seed): "A Photographic Memory is an intimate, genre-bending portrait of a daughter's attempt to piece together a portrait of her mother, an avant-garde journalist and a woman she never knew."
"ImPossible" (directed by Seckeita Lewis): "When a man with big dreams is diagnosed with a life-threatening illness, he forms an unbreakable bond with a widowed fast food worker to do the impossible; transform his life and pursue his passion of becoming a police officer."
"Chinese Painted Paper Cutting Folklife Apprenticeship": "Master artist Shanye Huang taught Chinese painted paper cutting to apprentice artist Etian Huang in a documentary by Wide Angle Youth Media for the Maryland State Arts Council. Funded by Maryland Traditions, Folklife Apprenticeships support the transmission of cultural traditions, enabling master and apprentice artists to collaborate for up to one year. Wide Angle Youth Media, a Baltimore-based production company, amplifies the voices of youth and equips them with media arts skills to document stories across social divides."
"Jamie Wyeth and the Unflinching Eye" (directed by Glenn Holsten): "Part of a three-generation dynasty of painters, Jamie Wyeth has carved out a singular path in the art world. His subjects include John F. Kennedy, Andy Warhol, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Rudolf Nureyev, animals on his farm and on islands of Maine, all through his unique, and sometimes unsettling, lens. Jamie Wyeth and the Unflinching Eye is the first feature length documentary that embraces the full scope of the American artist's life and work."
Sunday, Sept. 29"The Art of Storytelling" event will be held at the Talbot County Free Library from 10:30 a.m. to 11:45 a.m. The event is free and will feature filmmakers from the festival. The library is located at 100 W. Dover Street in Easton.
"Immerse yourself in the world of creating a strategy for your film as professional filmmakers and authors share their stories on the making of their films. Join Glenn Holsten, director of Jamie Wyeth and the "Unflinching Eye", Leslie Shampaine, director of "Call Me Dancer", Vincent de Paul, director of "The Genius of Gianni Versace", Rebekah Louisa Smith, the Film Festival doctor who will share strategies for distribution, Monda Raquel Webb, CFF Board Member and director of "Mother Knows Best" and "Zoo" will share details about what it takes to publish and Theodore Adams, III, CFF Board Member and director of "Tri", "Tyndall Typewriter" and other films will talk about his screenwriting experiences with new films "Shine Box" and "Breathe."
Films featured on Sunday, Sept. 29 include documentaries and short films, including some directed by students.
"Imaginarius" (directed by Juan Ignacio Bello): "Florencia, Amanda, Matias and Agustin, fantasize about the Total Solar Eclipse that will arrive at their quiet hometown, The Elqui Valley an astronomic hotspot near the Atacama Desert. Amid the unusual frenzy that surrounds their town, the kids dream about a more sustainable and brighter future."
"Truth Tellers" (directed by Richard Kane): "Truth Tellers is a film about political artist Robert Shetterly's "Americans Who Tell the Truth", a project that explores our Page 7 country's ongoing struggle to live up to our democratic ideals with those who are not afraid to speak the truth nor challenge the status quo."
"Missing Figure" (directed by Jeremiah Battle): "A young man makes a call to his father who is no longer in his life before his upcoming wrestling match."
"For the Love of the Game" (directed by Ollie Killip): "Towson University's Women's Basketball Team fight through their turbulent first season under their new management team. Experience the season as they do, with a look into the lives of the players, coaches and staff that make the team tick, and be ready to fall in love with the sport all over again."
"Dance Party" (directed by Lucy Saper): "Layers of colorful screen-printed and airbrushed collaged dancers come to life in this vibrant animation."
"Things I Wish I'd Said" (directed by Riley Frutiger): "Unable to sleep, a girl writes a letter trying to articulate the complex emotional turmoil towards her dead brother that's keeping her awake."
"Monarchs in Motion" (directed by Mason Mirabile): "Monarchs in Motion is a documentary featuring footage from the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserves in Michocan, Mexico. The film tells the story of the migratory Monarch and challenges across its migration from Canada to Mexico. The film features experts from WWF, Monarch Watch and Natural Habitat Adventures."
"Beauty" (directed by Carley Dernetz — In a visually engaging stop motion, a powerful slam poem delves into the weight of beauty standards and body image, as words cut out of paper are intertwined with images from Towson's literary magazine, revealing the struggle for self-acceptance in a world obsessed with appearance.
"Amathus" (directed by Lydia Mastrangelo): "Amathus is a retelling of the birth of Aphrodite that explores modern storytelling and femininity. "
"Portrait Day" (directed by Romina Melissa Nunez): "When a cat and dog are paired to draw each other for a class portrait assignment, total chaos ensues."
"Mary Through the Glass" (directed by Wyatt Cooper Carson): "Busy cars, dotted distant windows and aimless lights make up a city through the whimsical perspective of an indoor cat. "Mary" tells the story of a curious cat who finds the company of an imaginary friend more intriguing than the neighborhood cats, leading her to a new world."
"The Last Epic Ride" (directed by Rick Kain): "The Last Epic Ride is the story of a terminally ill man that, aided by his friends, goes for one last motorcycle ride along a familiar route. "
"Get on the Bus" (directed by Justinian Dispenza): "A journey involving over 50 individuals from Chestertown, MD, traveled to the Legacy Museum in Montgomery on August 25. Along the way, stops at significant civil rights locations in Birmingham, Selma, Montgomery, and Atlanta offered profound insights into often overlooked aspects of Black history and the contemporary African American experience. These experiences are captured in the documentary Get on the Bus!, which chronicles the transformative journey."
Closing Night Film
"In the Whale" (directed by David Abel): "An award-winning feature-length film. Arguably the greatest fish story ever told, though this one is true. It's the account of a man who survived to tell the tale of being swallowed by a whale, and what happened after he escaped. In the shark-filled waters off Cape Cod, Michael Packard has long tempted fate." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details the Chesapeake Film Festival, an event centered around cinematic works, storytelling, and artistic presentations. While it touches on cultural themes and local activities, the primary focus is on entertainment through film screenings and related events. The explicit mention of 'Entertainment' in the article's section header reinforces this classification.

title: Production of Shakespeare's Hamlet features1920s styles
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Production of Shakespeare's Hamlet features1920s styles

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those who enjoy plays by legendary playwright William Shakespeare will argue about which one of the Bard's works is truly best, and one of those plays typically in the discussion will be featured this month as the Twin Beach Players present "Hamlet" for eight shows beginning Friday, Sept. 20 in North Beach.Directed by Harvey Williams and Rachel Clites Cruz, who also plays the title character, the Twin Beach Players production of "Hamlet" will feature the numerous memorable characters and lines made famous by the Bard centuries ago although in costumes more reminiscent of the 1920s. In one scene, however, known as the play within the play, the characters don costumes more conducive to far more basic productions.
Its numerous characters and plot twists are accompanied by memorable lines such as "To thine own self be true" and "There are far more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy," and of course the engrossing soliloquy in which the title character initially asks, "To be or not to be, that is the question" as his madness approaches.
Williams, however, insisted that a hint of comedic tones were introduced to this version of the play.
"I've always loved Shakespeare," said Williams, who also plays King Claudius in addition to directing the play. "I've read 'Hamlet,' I've seen the play and the movies and I've always wanted to direct it. But for our version I wanted to have a 1920s theme, complete with the costumes and a lot of the characteristics of the era."
Cruz, who also admits a passion for performing in Shakespeare plays dating back to her youth, yields most of the directing chores to Williams for this version while also playing the title character.
Her willingness to assume the lead role came with the knowledge and understanding that Hamlet represents the ultimate challenge for any performer.
"Playing Hamlet is so challenging because his character is the epitome of all Shakespeare characters. He not only has the most lines and the most scenes, but he has seven soliloquies," she said. "But I've always wanted to play Hamlet and be a part of this production. This is only my second time actually being up on stage with Twin Beach Players, but we have an amazing cast and crew here."
Many of the Twin Beach Players regular performers each have key roles in "Hamlet," including Cruz as the title character and Williams as King Claudius and Alexys Adams as Ophelia, Aaliyah Roach as Laertes, Terri McKinstry as Polonius and V. Stardust as Horatio, although audience members will notice that, by design, three characters typically deemed male are played by actresses and intentionally dubbed as female.
Cruz and Williams both noted that the strength of the Twin Beach Players over the years has been its willingness to attract and develop younger performers, with Addie Quinn, still one year removed from her freshman year at Huntingtown High School, playing dual roles as Rosencrantz and Marcellus.
"I got into the theater mainly because my older brother was an actor," Quinn said. "I love working with the actors and directors here at Twin Beach Players. I usually have done other comedies, but I like being in something serious."
If you goThe Twin Beach Players production of Hamlet will run for eight shows at the North Beach Boys & Girls Club, located at 9021 Dayton Avenue in North Beach, from Sept. 20 to Oct. 5. Friday and Saturday shows will begin at 8 p.m. while the two Sunday shows on Sep. 22 and 29 will commence at 3 p.m.
Based on the timeless classic by William Shakespeare and directed by Harvey Williams and Rachel Clites Cruz, the TBP production of Hamlet will include the characters made famous by Shakespeare and will offer the same intensity and drama that onlookers have always expected from the show, but with 1920s attire and occasionally some comedic overtones.
Due to its adult content, dialogue and some scenes, however, this play is not recommended for children under 12 years of age.
For more information, go to twinbeachplayers.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a theatrical production of Shakespeare's Hamlet with 1920s styling, emphasizing performance aspects, directorial choices, and audience information. While Arts & Culture is related, the explicit section label 'Entertainment' and focus on live performance align most directly with the 'Entertainment' topic.

title: Fall Kickoff Weekend in Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
Fall Kickoff Weekend in Easton

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Words

 The days of summer are starting to be in the rear-view mirror with football, pumpkins and changing leaves taking the seasonal helm.Downtown Easton will be welcoming autumn and the days of pumpkin spice with a Fall Kickoff Weekend event Friday, Oct. 4 and Saturday, Oct. 5.

title: Jazz, Americana shows coming to Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
Jazz, Americana shows coming to Avalon

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Anthony "Turk" Cannon, a smooth jazz saxophonist from St. Michaels, will perform Friday, Oct. 4, at the Avalon Theatre in Easton.Cannon — who recently sold out tow shows at Blue's Alley in Washington D.C. — will perform with bassist J. Castro during his Avalon show.
According to an announcement from the Avalon promoting the show, "Cannon's love of music began at the age of nine, when he started playing the clarinet. Years later, holding a saxophone and breathing life into its soothing sounds, he discovered the soulful spark that ignites the palpable passion flowing from his horn each time he plays:
The Avalon said Castro is "renowned for his creativity in neo-soul, jazz, fusion and hip-hop."
"J Castro's music speaks of love and life's struggles. His improvisational chops to contemporary jazz elevates the mind of his listeners with a sound that pleases their ears and sets their toes tapping," the venue said.
Singer-songwriter Peter Bradley Adams will perform Saturday, Oct. 5 at the Avalon. The show starts at 7 p.m. Tickets are $30.
"Peter Bradley Adams, formerly one-half of the chamber Americana duo Eastmountainsouth, has gone on as a solo artist to scale back some of the 'mountain' and 'south' in his music for a more modern singer/songwriter approach," according to a concert announcement from the Avalon.
"Adams's musical journey delves into the nuances of tranquil and tumultuous romance, captivating audiences with emotionally charged lyrics. His brand of Americana nestles his often delicate, always heartfelt voice in the warm embrace of gentle guitar, tasteful dobro, subtle banjo, supportive bass, and unhurried percussion," the venue's announcement continued.
For more: https://www.peterbradleyadams.com/, https://avalonfoundation.org/, https://anthonycannon.com/ 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chesapeake Film Festival returns to Easton for 17th year
author: Tom McCall
content:
Chesapeake Film Festival returns to Easton for 17th year

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Entertainment 
 
 468
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Chesapeake Film Festival is bringing a wide array of features, shorts and documentaries to the Ebenezer Theater this weekend. It is the festival's 17th year, and the Friday evening VIP reception was sold out.The premier film, shown at noon Friday, was "Call Me Dancer," which is directed by Leslie Shampaine and Pip Gilmour.
Shampaine won a Fulbright Scholarship for her work on this film. The film was about a young man from the streets of Mumbai facing challenges to achieve his passion for ballet.
"The film was finished before I received the Fulbright," Shampaine said. "... My Fulbright was based on community impact in India for the film."
She said she is using the film to do a lot of outreach to underprivileged youth in India.
"One theme is everyone has a passion and the journey and obstacles that one goes through. Everyone has obstacles in their life. And the perseverance, hard work and hope that you need to keep going," Shampaine said.
John King, executive producer of the film, said it took over five years to complete.
"The biggest challenge was that this was an international production. The fact that it went from India, to the U.S., to Israel, to London and back to the U.S. And for independent documentaries raising the money is a challenge," King said.
Cid Collins Walker, executive director of the film festival, gave opening welcomes and introductions. This is her eighth year with the festival.
By the time the festival ends Sunday, 17 short and feature length films will have been screened in Easton. Filmmakers are coming from a variety of locales, from Chile, to Romania, to Los Angeles.
"As a producer of an event like this, you are always looking for a film that will grab the public's attention. A good opening film is really important. It is the first thing that people see," Collins Walker said.
Curating a film festival is an art in itself.
"I have learned over time that this is what the audience loves. The public loves to hear these stories right from the director or producer's mouth," Collins Walker said.
She said there is a driving purpose to her work.
"The arts are a great connecting force. It connects us all, and I believe we live in a fractured society, sadly. I like to produce these events to bring people together," Collins Walker said.
"The festival is good for the region. It is good for Talbot County. It is good for Chestertown. It is a hidden gem among our many arts celebrations. I would encourage people to check it out. I really love the way they highlight the unexpected," said Cassandra Vanhooser, director of the Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism.
The festival has more screenings and events planned for Saturday and Sunday. To see a schedule and learn more about the festival, visit chesapeakefilmfestival.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Chesapeake Film Festival, an event centered around showcasing films, documentaries, and filmmaker interactions. While it touches on arts and culture, the primary context is entertainment as the festival is described as an entertainment event with screenings, receptions, and public engagement.

author: Staff Writer

Guitar heroes: PRS Guitars artist program hits record high

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment

 Stevensville-based PRS Guitars announced its largest roster in the five-year history of the PRS Pulse Artist program. The program showcases influential guitar players affiliated with PRS via social media marketing and editorial content, links and offers them discounts with retailers and promotes them to sponsors and venues.PRS said the Pulse Artist Program is up 20% with the class of 2025 totaling 137 artists.
Four artists from the class of 2024 will be graduating to Official Artist status, an increased level of support, effective Oct. 15: Leoni Jane Kennedy (United Kingdom), Pannasit Sukahotu (Thailand), Tomo-Zo (Japan), and Dimitri Peters (United States).
"The global music scene is teeming with remarkable talent deserving widespread recognition," said PRS Guitars Director of Artist and Community Relations,Bev Fowler. "We created the PRS Pulse Artist program five years ago to highlight and support these up-and-coming guitar players. Through their various genres, they are expressing themselves through music that needs to be heard on a massive scale. The program also serves to connect these musicians with each other and to their local guitar dealers, increasing opportunities for development through community."
According to the Maryland company, the PRS Pulse Artist program helps guitar players form stronger relationships with their go-to retail store and each other. Through the program, artists are granted exclusive discounts on guitars, amps, and accessories through their local Authorized PRS Dealer.
"Becoming a PRS Pulse Artist opened so many doors to me, industry wise and for my mentality as a full-time musician and songwriter," said Leoni Jane Kennedy. "Having industry giants such as PRS supporting my creativity has not only been a dream come true, but has shown me what a team should really be. Now that I've graduated into the Official Artist roster, I feel I've achieved something so foundational to my career and I couldn't have asked for a better brand to represent and work with to show the world what I'm really made of. Thank you PRS!"
For more: www.prsguitars.com/artists.

title: 301 haunt conjures more attractions
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
301 haunt conjures more attractions

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 242
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GALENA — Back and more frightening than ever is 301 Devil's Playground, a haunted attraction running until Nov. 9, located at 13335 Alexander Road in Galena."Come visit the scariest Haunted Attractions on the Eastern Shore," their website states, and for good reason.
301 Devil's Playground is the brainchild of Peter Nau, and has been recognized as one of Frightfind's 2021 Top Haunted Houses.
This year, some favorites return. The journey into the House of Hell. Then a haunted 3-D clown experience. This is followed up by lots of chainsaw wielding maniacs, bumps in the dark, monsters waiting in the shadows and chilling twisted dark tunnels.
Also back, heckling crowds who are waiting in line is the character, Biting Bill. If you have thinner skin than Bill, you might want to plug your ears while waiting.
What's new this year is the Barnyard.
Latasha Pennick, one of the organizers, and Nau's daughter, said in addition to the Barnyard some other changes have been made throughout the haunt.
So those attending last year, may see some variations this year.
And for newcomers, Pennick has confidence they will enjoy it as well.
"They will be amazed by all the detail that was put into our haunt and the uniqueness of it," she said.
301 Devil's Playground has five terrifying haunted attractions that will bring your fears to life: House of Hell, The Harvest (haunted corn maze), 3-D Phobia, The Barn of Torture and The Barnyard — an all new attraction.
For tickets, visit 301devilsplayground.com/.

title: America's haunted tourism industry generates up to $500M annually: 12 spooky destinations to visit
author: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks
content:
America's haunted tourism industry generates up to $500M annually: 12 spooky destinations to visit

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1135
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every year, haunted tourism in the United States scares up profits of paranormal proportions.According to America Haunts, a group of 20 haunted attractions nationwide, the U.S. industry brings in between $300 and $500 million annually. Haunts throughout the country attract large crowds year-round, especially around Halloween.
In its 2023 Haunt Industry Report, HauntPay, a haunted attraction ticketing platform, reports 33% of haunts were expecting to receive upwards of 10,000 visitors, a notable increase from 2022. That year, 42% of haunted attractions saw visitor numbers between 1,000 and 5,000.
Venture beyond the grave and visit some of America's scariest real-life haunts to celebrate the season.
12 Terrifying Places in America to Embrace Your Spooky SideFrom abandoned prisons to historic homes and even a zoo, these are 12 of the scariest haunted locations in America worth visiting this month.
Eastern State Penitentiary, PennsylvaniaExplore the supposedly haunted grounds of Philadelphia's Eastern State Penitentiary — if you dare. This abandoned prison once held famous criminals like Al Capone and Willie Sutton before closing in 1971 and falling into disrepair.
"Visiting Eastern State Penitentiary is like stepping into a real-life horror movie," says Partners in Fire owner Melanie Allen. "The desolate, crumbling halls and long-abandoned rooms hold an unyielding tension."
Visitors can tour the prison year-round. The facility also hosts seasonal Halloween Nights, which feature haunted houses, spine-tingling tours, themed bars, and live entertainment.
The House of the Seven Gables, MassachusettsThe House of the Seven Gables, built in 1668, is among Salem's eeriest attractions. Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel of the same name mainstreamed the property.
The home is a must-visit for those interested in colonial architecture and Salem lore. Every October, tourists can enjoy autumnal storytelling performances that heighten the unsettling atmosphere ahead of Halloween.
Waverly Hills Sanatorium, KentuckyGhost-hunting enthusiasts flock to Waverly Hills Sanatorium, a former tuberculosis treatment center operational from 1910 to 1961.
Many visitors report supernatural encounters, from doors slamming on their own to sightings of a young ghost boy. Delve into the property's dark past on a guided tour, or pack a tote with essentials for a private overnight investigation.
Waverly Hills Sanatorium also hosts a terrifying haunted house during the fall, made scarier by the sanatorium's paranormal reputation.
Stanley Hotel, ColoradoThe Stanley Hotel opened in 1909 as a getaway for guests seeking upscale accommodations in Colorado's Rocky Mountains. Its reputation faltered in the 1970s, but one visit from author Stephen King changed everything. King later wrote his horror classic The Shining, drawing inspiration from Stanley Hotel.
Guests often claim to hear disembodied laughter, feel phantom touches, and sense ghostly presences. Amp up the scares during your overnight stay with a theatrical séance or nighttime tour.
Lincoln Park Zoo, IllinoisIn addition to the zoo animals you'd expect to see, Lincoln Park Zoo is reportedly home to several spirits. Lincoln Park was once the site of Chicago's official city cemetery, and some say thousands of bodies remain buried there today.
The zoo hosted its first official paranormal investigation in 2013 after reports of apparitions and disembodied voices in the Lion and Primate Houses.
October visitors can join an evening Haunted History Tour to learn more about the zoo's hauntings. Wear comfortable shoes like boots to enjoy the eerie surroundings while exploring the zoo after dark.
Ohio State Reformatory, OhioThe historic Ohio State Reformatory operated from 1896 to 1990 and is the ideal destination for supernatural lovers. Visitors may recognize it from The Shawshank Redemption, filmed there in 1993.
There have been many documented instances of dark figures and incorporeal voices at the Ohio State Reformatory, even among inmates before its closure.
The reformatory boasts an impressive program for those seeking a supernatural encounter, including group ghost tours and private, hours-long investigations.
The Mark Twain House, Connecticut
Step back in time at the Mark Twain House in Connecticut, where the famous writer and his family lived in the late 1800s.
This Victorian home is a hotspot for unexplained phenomena, including sightings of a ghostly woman in white — possibly the spirit of one of Twain's daughters who died there.
Guests eager to explore this haunt can embark on a Graveyard Shift Ghost Tour to learn the home's most fascinating tales from beyond the grave.
St. Augustine Lighthouse, Florida
The spirits of several young children who died there in 1873 supposedly haunt Florida's St. Augustine Lighthouse.
Some lighthouse employees and visitors claim to hear giggling and see ghostly apparitions, while others feel an otherworldly presence throughout the site.
Hear spine-chilling stories of the lighthouse's hauntings on a group tour, or bring ghost-hunting equipment to conduct a private nighttime investigation.
Winchester Mystery House, CaliforniaThe Winchester Mystery House is among San Jose's strangest attractions. The owner, arms company heiress Sarah Winchester, began the bizarre multi-decade renovation following her family's death. She expanded the home to 24,000 square feet, installing 160 bedrooms, 13 bathrooms, and six kitchens.
"Doors open to nothing, stairs lead to solid walls, and there seems to be an overall feeling of chaos and unsettling vibes that bothered me when visiting," explains Chantelle Kincy of Flannels or Flipflops.
Over the years, many guests have claimed to see specters and hear footsteps in the Winchester Mystery House. Visitors can see areas of the home on year-round guided tours or embark on a seasonal haunted maze through four of the mansion's floors.
Bonaventure Cemetery, GeorgiaWhile southern Georgia's Bonaventure Cemetery is among the world's most beautiful cemeteries, it's also incredibly unsettling.
"It was extremely quiet, and there was an overwhelming feeling of sadness as we walked around," Jessy Hamel of Brighter Things shares about her visit.
Various local legends surround the cemetery, including voodoo rituals and a child spirit that roams the grounds. In October, the cemetery allows guests to embark on a full moon tour, enhancing the creepy atmosphere.
The Conjuring House, Rhode IslandSee the terrifying real-life home that inspired The Conjuring movie universe. The house's haunted history stretches back centuries since its construction in the 1730s.
In the 1970s, the Perron family bought the home and immediately started having ghostly run-ins. At one point, famed paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren took an interest in the house.
According to the Perron family, at least two spirits — a married couple who passed away in the 1800s — haunt the house. Interest in the property spiked following the 2013 release of The Conjuring, a hit horror movie that spawned an entire franchise.
The current homeowner offers a variety of spooky experiences, from guided daytime tours to overnight investigations where you can bring a blanket and settle in for a night of ghost-hunting.
San Fernando Cathedral, TexasSan Fernando Cathedral, established in 1731, is a beautifully haunting church. It's the oldest of its kind in Texas and is said to be among San Antonio's most haunted locations.
Numerous bodies lie within the cathedral walls, and visitors have reported spectral sightings of dark silhouettes and mysterious orbs. Many San Antonio ghost tours visit the historic cathedral to highlight its storied past.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on haunted tourism as a form of entertainment, highlighting spooky destinations and Halloween-related attractions. While some locations have cultural or historical significance, the primary context is recreational and entertainment-driven, matching the 'Entertainment' category.

title: CBMM's OysterFest in St. Michaels
author: Staff Writer
content:
CBMM's OysterFest in St. Michaels

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's OysterFest is on Saturday, Oct. 26, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. in St. Michaels."At OysterFest, you're invited to enjoy oysters served a variety of ways, along with other local fare, craft beer, and spirits, plus fun for the whole family with live music on two stages, an oyster stew competition, a full schedule of demonstrations and presentations, children's activities, and more," CBMM said in an announcement promoting the local event.
Tickets are on sale now at cbmm.org/OysterFest, with discounted pricing for CBMM members.
The menu features oysters from the Talbot Watermen Association and several local oyster farms, with both raw and cooked options available.
There will also be local food vendors as well as craft beers and speciality cocktails.
"Don't miss your chance to buy an OysterFest mug and join the judging for the always-popular oyster stew competition. You'll sample offerings from area restaurants and then vote for your favorite to decide which chefs claim the coveted title and local bragging rights," CBMM's announcement reads.
There will also be music including from Swamp Donkey Newgrass and guest speakers
sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center through the Maryland Traditions Program of the Maryland State Arts Council.
Food historian Joyce White will discuss historical influences on Maryland's cuisine and her recent book "Cooking Maryland's Way: Voices of a Diverse Cuisine," and historian Eric Cheezum will share the incredible true story of the mysterious sea creature who captured the hearts and imaginations of the Bay region told in his book, "Chessie: A Cultural History of the Chesapeake Bay Sea Monster."
The American Chesapeake Club will be on hand to share demonstrations highlighting the retrieving abilities of its Chesapeake Bay retrievers, while Eric Jackson of Bay Fibers Studio will offer guests a free opportunity to create their own t-shirt designs.
Kids can explore life on the Bay through hands-on activities, including lawn games, model boat building, and more. The Phillips Wharf Fishmobile traveling aquarium will be on site, too.
To close out the day, cruise boat PATRIOT is offering a special OysterFest cruise on the Miles River as part of its final weekend of the 2024 season. Starting at 3:30 p.m., this 75-minute cruise features appetizers provided by Garden and Garnish, including oysters on the half shell. The cost is $62, with a $4 discount for CBMM members. Learn more and buy tickets at patriotcruises.com.
This year's OysterFest is generously sponsored by The Easton Group at Morgan Stanley, PNC Bank, RAUCH inc., and SafeTime by MAGI.
OysterFest tickets can be purchased in advance online or at the door. Admission is set at $22 for adults, $19 for seniors (65+) and students (17+), $10 for active and retired military members, and $9 for children ages 6-to-17, with all children 5-and-younger admitted free.
CBMM members receive discounted pricing to OysterFest and other annual festivals celebrating the best of the Bay throughout the year. Adult member tickets are $10, and all children of members (17-and-younger) receive free admission. CBMM members at the Family & Friends level and above can also receive the $10 discounted admission for two additional adult guests.
During the festival, additional free event parking will be available at St. Michaels Middle/High School, with a free service running to and from CBMM's waterfront campus.

title: 'Stage Fright' brings dark humor to Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Stage Fright' brings dark humor to Avalon

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — This Halloween, immerse yourself in a haunting, unforgettable journey as "Stage Fright: Curtain Call" returns to the Avalon Theatre from Wednesday, Oct. 23, to Sunday, Oct. 27. With shows at 6:30 p.m. each night and additional 9:30 p.m. performances on Thursday through Sunday, this locally written and directed show promises a macabre experience that blurs the lines between reality and delusion.The production is recommended for ages 16 and up; guests under 16 must be accompanied by a responsible guardian. Tickets are available through the Avalon Foundation website at avalonfoundation.org/event/stage-fright-curtain-call.
Set in 1997, "Stage Fright: Curtain Call" invites audiences into the dark, twisted world of Lou Baker, a 95-year-old former showman tormented by a violent past and spectral figures. Facing release from a psychiatric institution after over three decades, Lou's story unfolds through a captivating, immersive theater experience filled with unresolved mysteries, dark humor, and a chilling confrontation between past and present.
Inspired by real ghost stories, the experience features sound and lighting effects, unique smells, special themed drinks and specially crafted Lyon Rum cocktails, making it an evening attendees won't soon forget. Mature themes and extensive walking are part of this production.
"Stage Fright: Curtain Call" is the thrilling final act of a trilogy, with each installment having been set in a different era — 1927, 1964 and now, at the turn of the century in 1997. The production explores the final days of Lou Baker, who is "95 and can barely get out of bed on his own." When presented with one last chance to release the spirit of Marguerite, his long, lost love and the ghost of the Avalon Theatre, he is met with a harrowing twist in his spiraling and tortured tale.
Attendees are encouraged to dress up in their favorite '90s attire or Halloween costume. The play draws heavy inspiration from '90s MTV, and The Factory invites guests to arrive as their best Britney Spears, Madonna, Notorious B.I.G., Spice Girls, and other '90s celebrities.
Cecile Strom directs the production, with Talley Wilford as assistant director and Casey Rauch as writer and co-collaborator.
"A key element of The Factory's immersive productions is the integration of film," Director Cecile Storm said. "It adds depth, context, and atmosphere to the live experience. This production takes this idea to new heights. I don't want to give too much away, but expect the boundary between stage and screen to blur in exciting and unexpected ways."
Katie Cox stars in the leading role, supported by the Beauty Shop Quartet: Jennifer Madino as Marguerite Gardot, Grace Vorosmarti as Shirley Boudreaux, Maddie Megahan as Vivian Baker and Jeri Alexander as Minnie Valentine. Art and production are managed by Maggii Sarfaty, and Ray Nissen leads the music direction.
"The acting is captivating and intense. The music is well done and is such a nice touch to this already so creatively awesome haunted house-like experience," shared an audience member from a past production. Another remarked, "It was great to see how the connection is made and everything is so eerily familiar, seeing as it's about the ghost that has haunted the Avalon for many years right here in Easton." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Mommy's Adventures' takes young readers on a ride
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Mommy's Adventures' takes young readers on a ride

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Local author Morgan Glenn invites you to Rollercoaster Land. It's a magical destination where readers go on rollercoasters, enjoy slides, and ride the teacups, as any great amusement park should offer.But you need a mode of transportation usually involving wheels to get to Six Flags America.
But to get to Rollercoaster Land, you just need imagination and Glenn's storytelling.
"Mommy's Adventures," is her first book, self-published, inspired by life with her seven-year-old son, Wyatt.
"It starts out with the mother trying to get her son, Wyatt, to bed. Naturally, he doesn't want to go. So mom pulls out her magical handbag," Glenn explains.
Inside the bag are traveling goodies like sunscreen and a map. Mom utters a special rhyme, and like "The Wizard of Oz," they are whisked away, Rollercoaster Land being the first of what may be many magical locales.
The 30-page book is for ages 3-8, with colorful illustrations from Pakistani artist Ayshea Zaki.
Like the mom in her story, 31-year-old Glenn is being whisked away too. At the beginning of the month she had the joy of reading her book to kindergarteners in H.H. Garnet Elementary School.
And as a cafeteria worker at Rock Hall Elementary School, she has a captive audience, who, at times, are probably more insistent than traditional publishers.
"They're coming up to ask me, 'when's the next book coming out?'," Glenn laughed.
This one took her about six months to write and she's planning on having a table at the next Rock Hall Fall Fest, an event that features various vendors.
For the magic seekers interested in her book, they can find it at Amazon.com under "Mommy's Adventures."
And where are mommy and Wyatt off to for their next mystical journey?
"Maybe space," Glenn said with a smile. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: The English Beat, Marshall Crenshaw at Rams Head on Stage
author: Staff Writer
content:
The English Beat, Marshall Crenshaw at Rams Head on Stage

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The English Beat will be at the Rams Head on Stage in Annapolis for a show on Saturday, Nov. 16.The English Beat originally formed in 1978 in Birmingham, England, and became known for its mix of pop, rock, reggae and ska music. The group's members were also part of popular bands Fine Young Cannibals and General Public.
The current incarnation of the English Beat performing at Rams Head is led by vocalist and guitarist Dave Wakeling.
The Annapolis is for all ages and starts at 1 p.m.
For tickets, prices and more info: https://www.ramsheadonstage.com/ and http://englishbeat.net/
'SOMEDAY, SOMEWAY'
Rock 'n' roll stalwart Marshall Crenshaw will perform at Rams Head on Stage in Annapolis on Tuesday, Nov. 19.
Crenshaw's rock resume includes 13 albums, playing Buddy Holly in the movie "La Bamba" and the 1980s pop hit "Someday, Someway."
The Rams Head show starts at 7:30 p.m.
According to an announcement from Rams Head, Crenshaw's four-decade musical career includes "13 albums, Grammy and Golden Globe nominations, film and TV appearances (Buddy Holly in "La Bamba") and thousands of live performances. Marshall Crenshaw's musical output has maintained a consistent fidelity to the qualities of artfulness, craftsmanship and passion, and his efforts have been rewarded with the devotion of a broad and loyal fan base. Presently, along with touring around the country and the occasional recording project, other current projects include producing a documentary film-in progress about legendary record producer Tom Wilson."
"This is a road that I'd never imagined taking before, but it's been an incredible learning experience," Crenshaw said in the announcement.
For tickets, prices and show info: https://www.ramsheadonstage.com/
