title: Bistro St. Michaels takes top honors at OysterFest
author: Staff Writer
content:
Bistro St. Michaels takes top honors at OysterFest

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For the second time in three years, the culinary team from Bistro St. Michaels, led by Chef Doug Stewart, won the Oyster Stew Competition as part of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's annual OysterFest.After blind polling of 350 guests who sampled six different stews during the recent festival, Bistro St. Michaels earned the People's Choice Award for Stew A. The local eatery is a haven for oyster fans with oysters served fried, baked, and raw on the half shell, plus in stew and pot pie, on its menu.
"OysterFest is a great event to bring people together, both locals and people coming from out of town," Stewart said. "The Oyster Stew Competition is nice because it gives the local chefs an opportunity to have some camaraderie and fun. We look forward to it every year."
The Oaks Waterfront Inn and Chef Dave Donahue took second place with Stew E, while Gourmet by the Bay at the Village Shoppe, led by Sidney Trond, was third with Stew D. Ruse at Wildset (Stew B), Theo's Steakhouse (Stew C), and Hambleton House Catering & Events (Stew F) were also part of the fun.
CBMM was pleased to welcome more than 3,000 guests to celebrate OysterFest.
Up next, CBMM closes out its festival season with the Holiday Edition of the Eastern Sea Glass & Coastal Arts Festival on Saturday, Nov. 23, from 10am-4pm. Learn more and buy tickets at cbmm.org/SeaGlassFestival.

title: 'The stars aligned for us': Tall Ships festival delights
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News
content:
'The stars aligned for us': Tall Ships festival delights

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1419
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For anyone who has ever fantasized about having a sailing adventure aboard a schooner or skipjack on the high seas, the Sultana Downrigging Festival in Chestertown is the place to be. For that matter, it's also a great place to be if you're a fan of unique small craft adventures, model ship building, maritime and Kent County history, bluegrass music, and a variety of Chesapeake-themed foods—because this three-day event has it all and then some!Over the last several years, all these interests have culminated into one of the most popular waterfront festivals in the mid-Atlantic.
A brisk, sunny morning ushered in the day's plethora of activities, which for many, began with the African American History walking tour. Chestertown's old Customs House, now known as Washington College's Starr Center, was the tour's jumping off point which then continued along the waterfront and into notable parts of Chestertown.
The waterfront, said community historian and tour leader, Airlee Ringgold Johnson, has changed quite a bit over the last two centuries, despite its nostalgic appearance with this past weekend's docking of tall ships in the marina.
"Our harbor is remarkably different from the harbor of 19th century Chestertown. There was once a seafood factory, a tomato factory, a basket factory, and a fertilizer factory," she said. "And there was always traffic going up and down the river."
Painting a picture of the challenges of the day, Ringgold Johnson and Paula Reeder, a volunteer for the Chestertown Heartland Group, pointed out some of the town's unique homes and architecture as the group headed to the intersection of Water and Cannon Streets.
By 1871, they explained, Chestertown was home to many freed slaves, or slaves who were able to purchase their freedom from their owners. There were also many rules to be followed, which included not owning a gun, a dog, or a knife, and following strict curfews imposed upon African American residents at that time. It was also well known that this particular part of Water Street was home to the wealthiest residents of Chestertown; but as you head south on Water Street where it meets Cannon Street there was a virtual dividing line between the wealthy homeowners and many of the community's African American population who worked for them and resided in the blocks just beyond Cannon and into the community known as Scott's Point.
While history and education are certainly a big part of what the downrigging weekend is all about, it comes in many forms, including the activities found a few blocks closer to the center of town where the Sultana Education Foundation is located. The Holt Center was home on Saturday to a merry band of live animals at the Echoes of Nature Exhibit, which included various turtle species, a black snake, a broad-chested, red-tailed hawk, and even a cute, cuddly chinchilla. The kids also enjoyed live music and the creative adventure of making their own sailor hats.
Holt Center also buzzed with the enthusiasm of model boat and ship builders and their admirers and like-minded enthusiasts.
Further down Cross Street, impressions of the sea-faring life were on exhibit at the Massoni Art Gallery where artist, Marc Castelli, was in house to talk to art lovers about the stories behind his paintings as depicted in his "Merrier" series of watercolors. Castelli, who also lives what he paints, is well-known for his genuine and realistic depictions of the men and women who take to their local waterways to make a living.
Castelli's book, "Illustrating the New Treasure Island" was also part of a series of book talks featured over the weekend and organized by the Bookplate, which included Edward O. Murdy's, "Field Guide to Fishes of the Chesapeake Bay."
Back down at the marina, by mid-morning the sounds of the bluegrass band, Serene Green, were providing a melodic backdrop for the scores of Downrigging revelers out to tour the impressive collection of tall ships, small crafts, and collector's boats that were on display by private owners and organizations alike.
There were a total of nine amazing tall ships on display. Joining Chestertown's own Schooner Sultana, were several ships out of Baltimore including The Pride of Baltimore II, Lady Maryland, and the Sigsbee, and ships that came from as far away as Nantucket's Lynx and Key West's Bloodhound, a replica of one of the very first racing yachts of its era. Many of the ships took part in group sails down the Chester River that carried some 3,500 passengers over the course of the weekend.
The Bleinberger family of Kent Island, who said this was their second trip to Chestertown's Sultana Festival, enjoyed an on-deck tour of the vessel, Maryland Dove.
"You can't beat the weather, and you can't beat the beauty of the tall ships," said Morgan Bleinberger. The family, who are avid boaters and self-proclaimed fisherfolk, are also fans of live music, so the event seemed like the perfect afternoon out with the family.
"We love bluegrass, too," said Hans Bleinberger of the music at the event. "The weather was perfect, so the stars aligned for us."
Kent County resident, Pat Jewell, who was also attending the festival on Saturday with her son, Zach, said she wanted to bring Zach's daughter, Georgia, out to see the big boats. Having roots on the Eastern Shore, Jewell said she has been to the festival many times.
"I grew up in Calvert County, right on the water… and I sail." Relaying that love of the water and these beautiful vessels is something she said she hopes to instill in her granddaughter.
While Downrigging is truly a festival for kids of all ages, it also serves as a celebratory reminder of the mission the Sultana Educational Foundation (SEF) takes on every year to ensure that all of the area's public school children have the opportunity to explore and learn what an awesome and diverse resource we have in the Chesapeake Bay.
Over the course of the weekend, Drew McMullen, president and founder of the SEF, can be found down on docks amongst the ships and many other members of the organization that help educate and instruct upwards of 12,000 public school kids per year that come in from Kent County and various parts of the Eastern Shore.
"Our core mission—and we're coming up on our 30th anniversary—from the beginning, we have been laser focused on environmental literacy for kids. Getting kids out on the Chesapeake Bay; that's why we build the Sultana," said McMullen.
The schooner Sultana is a historically accurate replica of a Boston-built merchant vessel that served for four years as the smallest schooner ever commissioned in the British Royal Navy. This vessel now serves as a floating classroom that conveys not just a history, but experiences in team building, and a perspective on our regional waterways that they might not otherwise have.
The Foundation's mission, said McMullen, is reinforced in the sense that a child will experience an average of 35 days of environmental instruction as they progress from kindergarten through eighth grade. In addition to experiencing being aboard the Sultana, the organization provides all manner of programs and field trips that immerse kids in the ecosystem of the Chesapeake Bay and its inhabitants.
"And while their teachers are the real heroes, our job is to do all sorts of things that teachers can't do in the classroom."
This also could not be done, he said, without the help of an extensive network of volunteers; 137 in all, (85 who participate in the festival weekend alone) and the support of a wonderfully receptive and engaged community.
"A lot of this works because the whole community helps out, either by donation, or by donating a good or a service," he said. "For a small town like this to support an organization like ours, is not an easy thing."
Beyond the educational aspects, McMullen said, Downrigging is an event unlike any other, as it is the largest annual gathering of tall ships in the nation, and it helps bring together a specific group of enthusiasts who share a passion for the beauty and prestige of tall ships and the historical maritime aesthetic that embodies them.
"Some participants fly in from hundreds and hundreds of miles away just to be here every year."
Besides that, he added, the festival is a fitting way to close out the instructional year for them.
"This is a way to celebrate … we are almost to the end of the year. This is the Sultana's last sail of the year, and it's sort of a way for us to say, 'Yes, we took a lot of kids out, now let's celebrate and have some fun!'" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes the Sultana Downrigging Festival, a waterfront event featuring tall ships, maritime history, live music, art exhibits, and educational activities. While education and cultural elements are present, the primary focus is on the festival as an entertainment experience, supported by the article's section classification as 'Entertainment.'

title: World Waterfowl Calling Championships echo through Easton High auditorium
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
World Waterfowl Calling Championships echo through Easton High auditorium

 November 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Quacks, squeals and honks reverberated through Easton High School's auditorium Saturday night.The World Waterfowl Calling Championships, the final event of the Waterfowl Festival's Saturday schedule, brought waves of camo to the school for the event's seven competitions: the Jr. World Live Duck Calling Championship, the Jr. World Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Goose Calling Championship and the World Goose Calling Championship.
Winners of the different competitions took home a variety of prizes including plaques, money and — of course — decoys.
Contestant John Walls took home the big title of the night, World Goose Calling champion, which came with a $5,000 check. This is Walls' third World Goose Calling Championship win.
After yelling for joy with his fists in the air, Walls told emcee Dave Bloodsworth, "It's the Super Bowl, man." He thanked his friends and family before talking about celebration plans.
"I'm going to have a lot of fun tonight," he said. "It's a bad night to be a Busch Light."
Other champions of the night include Logan Heibner, 16, named Jr. World Live Duck Calling champion; JT Johnson, 15, named Jr. World Goose Calling champion; Chandler Martin and Slayton Gearin, named World Team Live Duck Calling champions; brothers Bryan and Bobby Heim, named World Team Live Goose Calling champions; Seth Fields, named World Live Duck Calling champion and Chance Wadsworth, named World Live Goose Calling champion.
After his win, Fields thanked his wife.
"For listening to all my routines in the kitchen," he said.
Bloodsworth said five judges in the back of the auditorium graded contestants on their routine, flow and sound throughout the night.
Before the competition began, junior callers Carter Whaley, 14, and Peter Aul, 16, sat on the stage, feeling both nervous and excited for the final competitions of the night to begin.
For Aul, who traveled from Pennsylvania for the championships, it was his first time at the Waterfowl Festival. He said he found out about the festival through buddies.
As for how he got into calling: "I just got a call and started running it better than everybody in my area and decided, you know what? I'm going to throw my name in." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article covers the World Waterfowl Calling Championships, a competitive event with entertainment value, held at a local venue. While it involves skill and competition (sports), the focus is on the event's spectacle and community engagement, aligning more with 'Entertainment' than traditional sports or local news.

title: Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Chris Moore has many titles to his name: Harvard University Graduate, director, producer of "American Pie" and "Good Will Hunting," and one of his favorites: Talbot County native.Moore, after making his name in Hollywood, is coming back to the Eastern Shore to hear from the locals who helped him fall in love with film.
At the Oxford Community Center Thursday, Nov. 21, he will seek to engage in valuable dialogue with residents to better understand what movie lovers from across the country are wanting to see from the film industry.
"I could have been originally from somewhere else where, honestly, I wouldn't care what they had to say, but the thing about Talbot County, and what I love about coming back to it… is that it's a real slice of America," Moore said.
Moore said he grew up going to the Avalon and loving the world that TV and movies took him to.
After studying American history at Harvard, where he met and worked with Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, he left for California, where he worked in the mailroom at an agency and later got promoted to literary agent before selling several scripts, including "The Stoned Age," "PCU," "Airheads" and "My Girl."
He later went on to produce 1999 film classic "American Pie," a breakout hit that launched Moore's career as a Hollywood producer.
But for Moore, a lot has changed since the 1990s, including the way that people watch films. Subscription-based streaming services have changed audiences' consumption of content by "over producing" content and making it difficult to gauge what people actually want to see, he said.
Moore said he wants to take a step back and go back to his roots to better understand how to give audiences quality content. And for him there's no better sounding board than the people of the Eastern Shore.
For Moore, the event on Thursday will be interactive, funny and most importantly informative of what he believes best represents American culture and audiences.
"I don't want people to think this is like going to a college lecture," Moore said. "We're going to have some fun and talk about movies and talk about entertainment, talk about fun stuff and in a way that people laugh and can engage and it can be a lively night." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a Hollywood producer's return to his hometown to engage with locals about film and entertainment, highlighting his career in the entertainment industry and his efforts to understand audience preferences for movies.

title: Hollywood producer hears from local moviegoers
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Hollywood producer hears from local moviegoers

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 684
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — A wave of laughter erupted at the Oxford Community Center on Thursday evening as a crowd watched video clips of a young Ben Affleck imitating an Eastern Shore accent in an effort to act as Chris Moore, a Hollywood film producer and Talbot County native.That evening, Moore led a discussion of the challenges faced by the movie industry, particularly the shift to streaming services and the decline of traditional theater attendance. Throughout the speech, he sought audience engagement and gathered information to better understand American audiences.
In an interview earlier in the week, Moore called the people of Talbot County "a real slice of America" whose input he valued greatly in examining the state of his industry.
"I'm going to talk about the movie business, but what I really want to talk about is how it's falling apart at the moment, and I'm trying to learn a little bit more," Moore said Thursday.
Moore spoke on the concerns he has with the quality of produced films. He asked the audience what they would like to see in newly released films and what it would take to get them to watch a film in person.
An array of answers came from several people, but the message remained consistent: people want quality films with quality stories.
Cid Collins Walker, executive director for the Chesapeake Film Festival, said she looks at hundreds of films every year and she relies on her knowledge to pick out films that stand out against the rest.
"I think you have to continue to take risks and find the best writers," Walk said. "I get all tons of scripts now. They're very exciting to read. Some of them, once again, are still works in progress, but I think you just need to encourage the process."
At some point in the event, Moore presented a Netflix home page filled with recommendations and shared research on why audiences get frustrated when they are offered too many choices. When audiences are presented with more than 5-6 options, consumers start to feel uncomfortable and have difficulty deciding.
"I think that the other problem is somehow the algorithm the menu uses is actually creating more frustration," Moore said. "So most likely, you're going to watch something that was on here that you've already seen or you're going to wait for the person that is sitting next to you, who's going to say, 'I want to watch this.' You're going to decide how much you hate it."
Art Murr, an attendee of the event, said he and his wife love movies and said he figured that Hollywood was confused about the vapid changes going through the industry.
"He's confirming (Hollywood) is confused," Murr said. "They should be confused, but we're not helping. And I do totally agree that there's way too many choices that if you're given like, four things, you choose one of the four things. If you're given 65 things … you have no idea, and you walk away, and you don't watch anything."
Liza Ledford, executive director of the Oxford Community Center and sister to Moore, said she worked in the film industry and with new technology it has drastically changed the communication between audiences and filmmakers.
"We lost a lot of our tools to vote," Ledford said. "What things we like, what things we don't like, and with the new restructuring of Hollywood, it's hard not to be able to trust Sony Classics or Fox Searchlights. The branding of different things has all become mesh together. So it's harder to know where to find certain types of things."
Toward the end of the event, Moore took the time to thank attendees for their participation and said that though movies are not essential for living they are important and their feedback helps the way the industry moves forward.
"I know the choices you make for what you watch," Moore said. "…But I know Hollywood and movies are less (important) than how you pay bills, your health, your kids (and) mental health. …but I do think it is nice to be surprised and happy and sort of snuck up on by a story that you're surprised by." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a Hollywood producer discussing movie industry challenges with local audiences, emphasizing entertainment industry trends, audience preferences, and cultural impact. While Arts & Culture is related, the direct focus on entertainment economics and audience engagement makes Entertainment the best fit.

title: Maryland author pens latest thriller
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland author pens latest thriller

 December 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 495
 Words 

 Read News Document

 R.J. Hinkemeyer recently published his latest book "False Trespass" on Nov. 18 on Amazon.The Dunkirk native writes mysteries that take place in his native state of Minnesota and his home state of Maryland and some of his previous books include "Confessions of the Soul: A Maryland Mystery," "Sins of Stone: A Marylan Mystery," "Shadows on the Soul: A Maryland Mystery" and "Snow Cover."
His books have won several literary contests sponsored by writing associations and his most recent novel — "False Trespass" — was a finalist for best mystery in the Pacific Northwest Writers Association's awards.
Hinkemeyer is a U.S. Army veteran and former federal official is a graduate of St. John's University in Minnesota and completed his graduate studies at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.
He grew up on a farm in Minnesota and enjoys the outdoors, his small garden, many pets and living in Southern Maryland. He is also an avid Baltimore Ravens, Baltimore Orioles, Bowie Bay Sox and U.S. Naval Academy sports fan.
The 223-page book is available at www.amazon.com.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
I was an English major in college who did a lot of writing during my career with the federal government. However, I didn't begin writing fiction seriously until after I retired several years ago. I had an older brother, Michael, who was a published author who encouraged me.
What inspires you to write?
I am interested in portraying principled individuals who confront the challenges and mysteries that life presents them.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
I'm not sure I would call it a career, but it is definitely more than a hobby.
What kind of writing process do you use?
I primarily use a computer to write, although I do edit my work on paper. Mornings are the best time for me to write when my mind is clear.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?
As a former English major, I have a lot of favorite authors. Over the holidays, I am looking forward to reading several new releases including "Grey Wolf" by Louise Penny and "The Mighty Red" by Louise Erdrich.
What are you working on now?
A thriller that takes place in the wetlands sanctuary of Jug Bay.
Please include a description of your book
A former county sheriff comes out of retirement when his grandson is suspected of shooting his own father.
Please include an excerpt from the book
"Drew shivered. He felt the cold deep in his bones. A lone snowflake brushed his cheek. Winter was coming. He wondered if Fletcher would stop by to see what he remembered. He wasn't certain what he could tell him. He was afraid he might have missed some signs over the years.
Maybe it would be best if he let things be, go home and start a fire in the fireplace. He didn't have all the answers and never had. Maybe it would be best if he let Fletcher solve his part of the puzzle. He was certain he had solved his." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local author's new thriller publication, details about his writing process, and mentions his literary achievements, all of which align with the Entertainment topic. The section classification as 'Entertainment' further supports this choice.

title: Embracing the spirit of Christmas
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Embracing the spirit of Christmas

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 622
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It was a cold few days earlier this month but Chestertown was armed with hot cider, mulled wine, beer, cocoa, music, an athletic activity, and all the Victorian-style costumes you could imagine to keep the chill at bay.Top hats, overcoats, bonnets and scarfs abounded.
The fashion of the Victorian era was once again adopted by Chestertown, as Mainstreet Chestertown put on the annual Dickens of a Christmas Festival Dec. 6 and 7 inspired by Charles Dickens beloved 1843 novella, "A Christmas Carol". The festival was sponsored by Main Street Chestertown, Rosin Creek Collaborative, 114 High and Molly's Place to name a few.
During the two-day event, couches were placed on High Street facing the music stage, in a homey atmosphere where one could meet friends and visitors of Chestertown, warming up by the fire barrels just a brisk walk away.
The event began Dec. 6 with the opening ceremony courtesy of Jimmy Kinstle portraying Dickens.
Kinstle introduced Queen Victoria who read off every child's name from Santa's nice list, courtesy of Santa's House next to Fountain Park.
Following, the audience was entertained by the Kent County High School Jazz Band, Garnet Elementary Chorus, River Voices and finally, The Devil's Brigade, formerly known as The American Rouges ending the night in a rowdy fashion.
Bonfires were lit, oysters and beer were served and food vendors were on hand. The new executive director for Main Street Chestertown, Sonny Huntzinger described the night as magical.
On Dec.7, 113 racers, contested the morning chill in the 5-K, Run/Walk and Kids' Fun Run, "Run like the Dickens" commentated by Kinstle, never breaking character.
Race coordinator Renee Bench and vice chair of the Board for Mainstreet Chestertown, pointed out there were not as many people as last year due to the weather, but was pleased to see the turnout all the same.
Finishing first for men's was Joshua Dorsey, winner for female's was Jamie Hicks, and Ethan McIntire, age 15, and C. Mann, age 8 finished first in their age range.
Over the day, the sun warmed the street and alcohol and food vendors opened up at noon. Music was performed throughout the day, traditional Irish songs to classic rock, and folk.
For kids, a petting zoo was situated over by Fountain Park as well as a puppet show performed by, Horns Punch and Judy Show.
For shoppers, the farmer's market was open, and further down was Heritage Village in the Bank, featuring a native flower farm, River Arts, WAC Women's League, Museum of Kent and Tarot readings.
For history buffs, the Holiday House tour afforded ticket buyers a journey to "festively decorated homes on Queen, Maple, High, Cannon and Water Street," as stated on the Chestertown website.
People could navigate the busy streets, seeing the homes in any order they wished.
Chestertown Police Chief Dixon, his crew in bobby hats, said over the two days there was an estimated 1,500-2,000 attendees and reported there were no incidents.
Huntzinger was thrilled by the efficiency in the planning process, having 25 years of experience in community development and other related fields. She noted that Main Street Chestertown Assistant Director Kelly Reed and a few volunteers planned the entire thing, while partnering with the Town of Chestertown.
She appreciated the hard work of them all, especially the Town's Streets and Public Works Department for setting up the stage among the many other tasks.
Huntzinger said all revenue, goes toward advancing Main Street's mission to promote and support a diverse range of educational, cultural entertainment and recreational activities.
Planning is a long process for such an event like this, Huntzinger acknowledged, and as much as they are looking forward to the next Dickens festival, she said they need more volunteers to sit in on committees and get involved.
If you have an interest in volunteering, contact the offices at 410-778-2991. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Uncork the perfect holiday feast with these wine-pairing secrets
author: Anne Jolly Food Drink Life
content:
Uncork the perfect holiday feast with these wine-pairing secrets

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Anne Jolly Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1030
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The holiday season is here, bringing festive gatherings and delicious meals. As you plan your celebrations, choosing the perfect wines to accompany your dishes can enhance the entire experience. Whether you're a wine novice or a seasoned enthusiast, these holiday wine pairing tips will make your celebrations unforgettable.With a few simple tips and secrets, you'll confidently pick winners every time. From classic turkey to creative desserts, there's a match for every course.
Tips for perfect holiday wine pairings
Here are the top tips for choosing wines to complement your holiday dishes and delight your guests. Understanding basic pairing principles will help you confidently navigate the world of holiday wines.
Create balance
One of the most important concepts in wine pairing is to create balance in flavor and intensity. Pair delicate foods with light and subtle wines, and rich and hearty dishes with robust, full-bodied wines.
Sweetness is another area where balance is an important consideration.To avoid flavor clashes, choose a wine that's as sweet or slightly sweeter than your dish.
Acidity is another important factor.Many holiday foods, like buttery mashed potatoes or juicy prime rib, are rich and fatty. High-acid wines can cut through these dishes, so you can taste each bite of food as if it were your first.
Finally, select wines that go with the herbs and spices in your dish rather than overpower them. When selecting a wine, focus on your dish's most prominent spices or herbs.
Add variety to your holiday wines
Don't forget sparkling wines - they're not just for toasts. They're versatile and can pair well with everything from appetizers to main courses to desserts.
Using regional wines is another way to add variety. Wines often pair well with foods from the same region. For example, serve Italian wines with Italian dishes.
When it comes to holiday wine pairing, there are tried and true favorites that you can count on. If you are in doubt, choose crowd-pleasing wines like pinot noir or sauvignon blanc. These classic wines pair well with a variety of holiday dishes.
Make sure you offer various non-alcoholic alternatives for your guests.Provide high-quality grape juices or non-alcoholic wines for those who don't drink alcohol.
Serving and enjoying holiday wine
Make sure you serve your wines at the right temperature. Serve white wines chilled and serve red wines slightly below room temperature. The correct temperature can significantly affect the taste and enjoyment of your wine.
Lastly, trust yourself and don't worry too much about the rules. If you enjoy a particular wine with a certain dish, then that's the perfect pairing for you.
Perfect wines for your holiday feast
Now that we've covered the essential tips for holiday wine pairing, let's review some specific recommendations for your holiday table. Whether you're serving a traditional roast turkey, a succulent ham or vegetarian options, there is a wine that will make your meal even better.
These are suggestions meant to inspire you, not strict rules. Experiment and choose the wine pairing that seems right for you and your guests.
Turkey or chicken
When serving roast turkey, choose a versatile chardonnay. Oaked, full-bodied chardonnays offer a richness that pairs well with white meat and many side dishes.
If you prefer red wine, a medium-bodied pinot noir goes well with the delicate poultry flavors. The wine's light to medium body and bright acidity pair well with both white and dark meat.
Ham
Holiday ham 's saltiness and subtle sweetness make for interesting wine pairings. A slightly sweet riesling is a fabulous choice. The wine's natural sweetness balances the ham's saltiness, while its crisp acidity cuts through the richness of the meat.
For red wine enthusiasts, a fruity zinfandel is a perfect match. Its bold berry flavors and hints of spice stand up well to the strong flavors of ham, especially if it's glazed or honey baked.
Beef
Bold red wines truly shine when it comes to beef. A full-bodied cabernet sauvignon is a classic choice for a beef roast like prime rib. The tannins in the wine help cut through the beef's richness.
Another outstanding option is a rich malbec. Malbec has a smooth texture that goes well with a tender, well-prepared roast. The wine's moderate acidity helps balance the richness of the meat.
Lamb
Lamb's rich, slightly gamey flavors are best paired with robust wines. Medium or full-bodied reds are ideal companions for this flavorful meat. A syrah's dark fruit and smoky character pair beautifully with grilled or roasted lamb.
Bordeaux blends, typically consisting of cabernet sauvignon, merlot and cabernet franc, are another fantastic choice. These wines provide a complex flavor and go especially well with lamb cooked with herbs like rosemary or thyme.
Pork
Pork's versatility allows for a range of wine pairings. Choose a medium-bodied red like merlot, which offers plum flavors that complement pork's lean meat.
Alternatively, a fuller-bodied white like viognier is the perfect choice for enhancing pork's subtle flavors. For pork dishes with fruity sauces or glazes, a pinot gris is an excellent choice, as its crisp acidity balances the sauce's sweetness.
Vegetarian dishes
Focus on the meal's dominant flavors, textures and cooking methods rather than defaulting to white wines. Mushrooms, with their earthy, umami flavors, pair well with light to medium-bodied red wines like pinot noir.
Crisp white wines work well with green vegetables and salads. A sauvignon blanc beautifully enhances the flavors of asparagus, bell peppers or zucchini dishes. Try a fuller-bodied white like a viognier or an unoaked chardonnay for roasted root vegetables.
Dessert
Pairing wines with desserts can be a delightful way to end a meal. The wine should be as sweet or sweeter as the dessert so it doesn't taste bitter or sour in comparison. Sauternes, a sweet white wine from Bordeaux, France, goes well with fruit-based desserts.
Ruby port is a classic choice for chocolate desserts. The wine's sweetness and body stand up to dark chocolate's intensity. Moscato d'Asti, a light, sweet and slightly sparkling wine, is perfect for lighter desserts. It pairs wonderfully with fresh fruit, light pastries or sorbet.
Toast to perfect pairings
Wine pairing is both an art and a science. These tips provide a foundation but trust your palate and experiment. After all, the most important part of any holiday gathering is the joy of sharing good food and drink with loved ones.
Anne Jolly is the creator of the food blog Upstate Ramblings. She loves cooking, especially for the holidays 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

The content is practical and celebratory, aligning with entertainment topics rather than food-specific categories like Agriculture or Health.

title: Full steam ahead: Festival of Trains awes visitors
author: Staff Writer
content:
Full steam ahead: Festival of Trains awes visitors

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS — The old outlets on Kent Island came to life with the lights and sounds of locomotives as train lovers young and old once again flocked to this year's Queen Anne's Railroad Society's Festival of Trains Dec. 3,4 and Dec 14 and 15.A favorite of enthusiasts for decades, the free annual festival had well over 1,000 people a day pack rooms to view the indoor train displays of various gauges and creative backdrops while learning information on the local history of railroads in the county.
A train display used to be part of an informational section of Queen Anne's Museum of Eastern Shore Life at the 4-H Park, but has since erupted to take on a life of its own, Queen Anne's Rail Road Society President Dan Worth said.
Queen Anne's County and the Eastern Shore of Maryland has a rich railroad history, connecting towns and major shipping areas. And are a tradition in every sense of the word, representing local history as well as being a fond memory to usher in the Christmas spirit for all ages, according to Worth.
Set up for the skillfully crafted displays begins in November.
An interactive scavenger hunt encouraged kids to explore the venue and note intrinsic details found within the train sets.
With a silent auction of historic train memorabilia and train kits for sale, all proceeds went toward the society's efforts to keep the spirit of local railroads alive and preserve the Centreville Station Freight Depot.
New this year, the Festival of Trains was also part of the 2024 Tour the Shore, a family oriented scavenger hunt for collectible stickers presented by local railroad clubs including Delmarva Model Railroad Club, Eagle Line Railroad, Rescue Fire Company, First State Model Railroad Club and Sudlersville Train Station Museum. This interactive partnership seeks to bring attention to the other clubs, layouts and historic stations on the Eastern Shore.
More information about the Queen Anne's County Railroad Society can be found at https://www.qarrs.org.

title: How long is too long for Christmas decorations
author: Michele Brosius Food Drink Life
content:
How long is too long for Christmas decorations

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michele Brosius Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 869
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The holiday season sparks lively discussions about traditions and preferences — from pumpkin spice to candy corn and the timing of Christmas decorations. Once the tree is up and the halls are decked, the question becomes how long holiday decorations should stay — is there a perfect timeline, or is it all about personal choice and sentimental value?For some, clearing the decorations right after New Year's symbolizes a fresh start. Others follow tradition and keep the festive spirit alive until the Twelfth Night on Jan. 5. Then, some stretch the season further — leaving lights aglow months after the holiday ends — prompting the age-old question: When to take down Christmas decorations?
Christmas decor through the ages
Once central to winter solstice celebrations, evergreen trees symbolized life during the darkest days. By the 16th century, candles were added to represent Christ's light, and the tradition spread through Europe and America, evolving with tinsel, glass ornaments and electric lights.
Today, Christmas decor reflects diverse styles, from traditional red and green to minimalist or trendy themes like pink Christmas. Whether rustic, glamorous or nature inspired, modern decorations allow for a personalized festive atmosphere.
Holiday decor: Tradition vs. personal preference
In some families, tradition dictates that all decorations come down on Epiphany, Jan. 6, marking the Twelfth Night when the Wise Men visited baby Jesus. Others prefer not to wait that long, taking down the tree the morning after Christmas and cleaning the house in time for New Year's Eve festivities.
You might be one of those people who would appreciate a year-round tree if you love Christmas, the holiday candies that come with it and the warm and cozy feeling of having a glowing tree in the corner of your room. The internet is full of year-round Christmas tree decor ideas like a sparkly heart-themed Valentine's Day tree or a pretty pastel tree to welcome spring.
According to a 2023 poll on Bob Vila, 16% of respondents said they take their Christmas decor down immediately following the holiday. Just over 60% of respondents said they typically leave decorations up until the conclusion of Epiphany — and the remainder — 21% of poll participants — indicated that they enjoy keeping their decorations in place at least until the end of January.
Multiple factors at play
For many, deciding when to take holiday decor down results from several factors. These include whether or not they need to get their closets or garage storage space back in order, the types of decor and if it's fragile or a family heirloom that requires greater care.
The availability of community recycling and environmental waste disposal can also be a factor for those opting for a real tree over an artificial one. The National Fire Protection Association reports that most Christmas tree fires occur in January, often due to dried-out trees that pose a heightened fire risk. Safety is key if you plan to keep your real tree up for an extended period.
Christmas tree safety
Proper care and precautions can help ensure Christmas tree safety throughout the holiday season. Water your tree daily to keep it from drying out and becoming a fire hazard. Position the tree away from heat sources like radiators or fireplaces, which can accelerate drying and increase risk. Check that all lights are in good condition, avoid any frayed cords or broken bulbs and always turn off the lights before leaving the house or going to bed.
Energy efficiency
Another important consideration is the higher energy bills in keeping Christmas tree lights and outdoor holiday lighting running throughout the day. While there are energy-efficient LED lights on the market, given the additional expenses acquired during the holiday season, keeping electricity bills down during this time can be a priority for some.
Caring for your Christmas decorations
When you finally put your decorations away, making them last will require proper care and storage. Wrap fragile decorations individually in tissue paper or bubble wrap, and store them in sturdy, divided containers to prevent breakage. Wrap string lights around cardboard or a spool to avoid tangling, and check for any damaged bulbs before storage.
Artificial trees should be disassembled and stored in their original box or a tree bag to protect against dust and moisture. Keep all decorations in a cool, dry space, away from extreme temperatures or humidity. Proper storage ensures your decorations stay in great condition for many holiday seasons to come.
When to take Christmas decorations down
Deciding when to take down Christmas decorations is a personal choice shaped by tradition, practicality and lifestyle. Whether you follow a historical timeline like Epiphany, embrace a New Year's refresh or extend the festive spirit, the key is finding what suits your home and schedule.
Your lifestyle and preferences will dictate the best answer to how long Christmas decorations should stay up, and when it comes down to it, if someone isn't contributing to the household or paying your energy bill, then their opinion on the topic shouldn't matter. Do what makes you and your family happy and let the grinches of the world scowl from afar.
Michele Brosius is the creator of Midlife Healthy Living where she expertly combines her love for cooking with budget-conscious nutrition strategies. Through her blog, she encourages women to embrace a healthier lifestyle with simple recipes and wellness tips. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses Christmas decoration traditions, personal preferences, and holiday practices, which align with 'Entertainment' as it relates to cultural customs and leisure activities. While 'Arts & Culture' is a close secondary option, the content focuses more on holiday traditions as a lifestyle choice rather than formal cultural or artistic practices.

title: Holidays on the Shore First Night Talbot, Ocean City fireworks and First Day Hikes highlight New Year’s events

 We've already seen plenty of cool and fun events this holiday season.Christmas in St. Michaels (including the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's Winter on the Chesapeake event) along with the Bluepoint Holiday Market at the Ebenezer Theater and the Avalon Theatre's production of "The Sound of Music" in Easton have already rung in the holidays.
But we are not done yet.
Christmas lights are still adorned throughout the Shore and New Year's Eve and New Year's Day events await.
Here are some of the upcoming events.
First Night Talbot in EastonThe Easton Economic Development Corp. and Union Baptist Church are putting on the free, family event to ring in the New Year.
The New Year's Eve event runs 6 p.m. through midnight.
First Night Talbot will also feature a Gospel Music Extravaganza at the Avalon Theatre from 10 p.m. to midnight. There will also be crab drops to ring in 2025 at 9 p.m. and midnight as well kids events and arts and craft.
A number of restaurants and hotels throughout the area have New Year's Eve special menus and events to celebrate 2024 and welcome 2025.
Those include the Ruse Restaurant at The Wildset Hotel and Bistro St. Michaels in St. Michaels.
For more: https://discovereaston.com/first-night-talbot/
Fireworks and fun in Ocean CityThere will also be plenty of New Year's Eve parties and events in Ocean City.
That includes two fireworks shows to ring in 2025 and celebrate Ocean City's 150th anniversary.
There will be fireworks downtown at the beach and Northside Park
"The downtown fireworks on the beach near Dorchester Street will be bigger and better than ever to usher in the 150th anniversary of the Town. A smaller fireworks display will be available uptown at Northside Park," the city said in an announcement.
"We can't think of a better way to ring in the new year and the Town's 150th anniversary than offering our residents and visitors two great fireworks shows," said Ocean City Mayor Rick Meehan. "Families can enjoy counting down to the new year with fireworks at midnight, whether you catch the large-scale show downtown on the beach or choose to enjoy the northern show from the perimeter of Northside Park."
There will be games at Fun City Arcade and live country music from the Dwayne Wilson Band at The Purple Moose on Ocean City's famed boardwalk.
The town will offer free bus service on New Year's Eve and into New Year's Day.
OC's Winterfest and its holiday lights run through Dec. 31 until 9:30 p.m and the Winterfest Model Train Display at OC's convention center is on display Wednesdays through Sundays until December 31, 5:30 — 9:00 p.m.
For more: https://www.ococean.com/
First Day HikesState parks across Maryland will host First Day Hikes from Dec. 31 through Jan. 2. They are part of national efforts to encourage hikes, walks and enjoying the outdoors to kick off the New Year.
On the Eastern Shore, there will be First Day hikes hosted at Martinak State Park in Denton, Tuckahoe State Park in Ridgley, Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad State Park in Church Creek, Cypress Branch State Park in Millington, Janes Island State Park in Crisfield, Assateague State Park in Berlin and the Bill Burton Fishing Pier State Park in Trappe.
Some of the hikes are self-guided and some include guided walks with rangers.
For more information check out https://dnr.maryland.gov/publiclands/pages/firstdayhikes.aspx

title: Upcoming shows at the Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
Upcoming shows at the Avalon

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 372
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Upcoming shows at the Avalon Theatre in Easton include an acoustic nod to to Southern Rock, a leading bluegrass and American roots group and a singer-songwriter duo.Here are some of the details.
CHESAPEAKE SONSThe Chesapeake Sons will perform an acoustic set at the Avalon Theatre in Easton on Friday, Jan. 3.
The show starts at 7 p.m. Tickets are $30 and $40.
"Chesapeake Sons owe their geographical roots to the Atlantic seaboard, but its sonic heritage connects the band firmly to The Black Crowes, the Allman Brothers Band, Lynyrd Skynyrd, and the Marshall Tucker Band," according to a show announcement from the Avalon.
"The Chesapeake Sons four-piece ensemble blends effusive melodies, fierce musicianship, convicted vocals, and smart lyrics in a diverse song stew that dips — in Southern-rock fashion — into rock, blues, country, gospel, and even psychedelia."
KEN & BRAD KOLODER QUARTETThe Ken & Brad Kolodner Quartet will perform Saturday, Jan, 4 at the Avalon. The show starts at 7 p.m. Tickets are $30.
"The dynamic father-son team Ken & Brad Kolodner weave together a captivating soundscape on hammered dulcimer and clawhammer banjo blurring the lines of Old-Time, Bluegrass and American Roots music," the Avalon said in an announcement.
"Regarded as one of the most influential hammered dulcimer players in North America, Baltimore's Ken Kolodner joined forces in 2009 with his son Brad Kolodner, a renowned clawhammer banjo player. They've sculpted their own brand of driving, innovative, tasteful acoustic roots music with a "creative curiosity that lets all listeners know that a passion for traditional music yet thrives in every generation."

title: 'Ziggy's World': Rock Hall artist keeps wheels turning on train display
author: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News
content:
'Ziggy's World': Rock Hall artist keeps wheels turning on train display

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News | Section: Entertainment 
 
 712
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When Ziggy Carter immigrated to the United States from Germany in 1960 at the age of 14, he carried with him two suitcases."In one suitcase were my clothes," Carter says. "In the other, smaller but somewhat heavier, were my electric trains."
A fascination with model trains has, obviously, been a lifelong obsession for Carter, and, until recently, finding a place to create a holiday display for his treasures was stretching into what seemed like a lifelong quest as well.
"For the last five years, I was always looking for a store window to use, but everyone was worried about liability or insurance," Carter says. "Then I asked Fresh Start and they said I could have their whole greenhouse. It's wonderful."
Carter, a multi-talented artist and builder, who has become a quaint, if quirky symbol of a town sometimes described the same way, finally found a place to unpack.
"He came to us in October with the train show idea and it was great timing," said Nina Flynn, the manager of Fresh Start, a produce-centric grocery near the central crossroads of Main and Sharp Streets. "Rich (owner Rich Seewald) and I did a little train set thing last year around the holidays and we underestimated how difficult it was. Ziggy said he could definitely do a better train show."
Well, yes. Carter's huge collection of trains and assorted paraphernalia now fill the 30-foot by 40-foot greenhouse at the rear of Fresh Start, a space that was available at this time of year. As many as eight trains whir around the intricate series of tracks; over bridges, around bends, and through Henry's Mountain, a large plaster eminence built at the request of local photographer JP Henry.
"He said he would like to see a mountain, so I had to build a mountain," Carter says.
The trains, which began operating the weekend after Thanksgiving, ran from noon to 4 p.m. on Saturdays and Sundays, through Sunday, Jan. 5. The expansive display itself can be seen during all regular store hours. More than 100 local businesses and individuals contributed funds to help Carter build the incredible show. He also invested more than $1,000 of his own money.
"Saturdays are a big day. We get a lot of kids and a lot of older people reminiscing about the old days and the trains they had around the Christmas tree," Carter says. "The kids like to chase the trains around the table, following them as they go."
Carter is best-known around Rock Hall for his artistic installations. He built the six-foot blue heron metal sculpture displayed outside Harbor Shack, and executed the whimsical storefront sign above the That Place On Main restaurant, and created the more-than-life-size depictions of Snoopy and Woodstock at the American Rock Hall Garage. Carter was also the featured artist for the 2024 Rock Hall FallFest promotional poster that was on display all over Kent County.
Rock Hall was not necessarily a destination for Carter when his sailboat broke down here 25 years ago, but he eventually made it his home.
"I was shipwrecked," he says. "I was only planning to stay for one night. I was sailing south from Maine on a 40-foot Hinckley, having come down through the canal, and was having engine problems, and some other problems as well."
After sorting those out, he decided to stay, and somehow the trains got here, too. Carter, who turned 78 last month, has been battling health problems as he worked to pull together the holiday display. He receives a chemotherapy treatment every two weeks, a course that will last through most of February. It is the main reason for the limited hours he is able to run the trains.
"It really knocks you, and I've lost 60 pounds," Carter says. "The doctors just say, 'We'll see how it goes.' What can you do? I'm enjoying what I'm doing here, and I've had a wonderful life with great adventures. No regrets at all."
The only regret might have been if his holiday train display, something he imagined in his fertile mind's eye for so long, had not become a reality. But here it is, chugging along literally the same way Carter is chugging along metaphorically. The layout is loud, and colorful, and full of action, surprises, and the delights for the season. Pretty much the same as him. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While Arts & Culture is relevant due to his artistic background, the primary context is a community entertainment event. The 'Entertainment' topic best captures the festive, interactive nature of the train display.

title: Casting call: Tred Avon Players holding auditions for ‘The Man from Earth’
author: Staff Writer
content:
Casting call: Tred Avon Players holding auditions for ‘The Man from Earth’

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Tred Avon Players theatrical company in Oxford is looking for actors "of all experience levels" to audition for roles in its upcoming production of the drama "The Man from Earth."The drama by Richard Schenman is based on a book by Jerome Bixby.
The Oxford production will be directed by Cecile Storm. It will run April 17 to 27 at the Oxford Community Center.
Auditions will be held at the Avalon Theatre in Easton at 6:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Jan. 14, and Wednesday, Jan. 15.
Play summary:After history professor John Oldman unexpectedly resigns from the University, his startled colleagues impulsively invite themselves to his home, pressing him for an explanation. But they're shocked to hear his reason for premature retirement: John claims he must move on because he is immortal, and cannot stay in one place for more than ten years without his secret being discovered. Tempers rise and emotions flow as John's fellow professors attempt to poke holes in his story, but it soon becomes clear that his tale is as impossible to disprove as it is to verify. What starts out as a friendly gathering soon builds to an unexpected and shattering climax. Acclaimed science fiction writer Jerome Bixby, writer of the original 'Star Trek' and 'The Twilight Zone', originally conceived this story back in the early 1960's. It would become his last great work.
"TAP will be casting 10 roles. All ages, genders, ethnicities, body types, abilities, and skill levels are welcome to audition and will be considered for roles," the drama group said in a press release.
Here are the roles:John: A history professor who resigns from his job to move to a new home. He claims to be immortal and must move every ten years to avoid being discovered.
Harry: A biology professor.
Edith: An art history professor.
Dan: An anthropologist.
Sandy: A historian who is in love with John.
Art: An archaeology professor.
Linda: A young student.
Will: A psychiatrist and physician.
Two Movers that will double as our orchestra.
Readings will be selected scenes from the script provided during the audition. You can reach director Cecile Storm by emailing hello@cecilestorm.com for any special accommodations.
Production crewTAP also needs a production crew for sets, lights, sound, costumes well as a stage crew. If you are interested, come to any audition to find out more information or send an email to hello@cecilestorm.com.
The nonprofit Tred Avon Players were founded in 1982. For more: www.tredavonplayers.org

title: Musical prodigies will perform at Chesapeake Music’s Interlude Concert
author: Staff Writer
content:
Musical prodigies will perform at Chesapeake Music’s Interlude Concert

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Music will hold an Interlude Concert on Sunday, Feb. 16 featuring pianist Janice Carissa, and violinist Stella Chen.The concert is at the Ebenezer Theater in Easton. Tickets are $50.
Chesapeake Music also offers free tickets for students and music educators, as well as a "buy-one-get-one" option for those who are new to Chesapeake Music and want to bring a friend, the local group said in an announcement.
Carissa began studying piano in Indonesia at the age of five with her self-taught pianist mother, according to the announcement.
She entered the Curtis Institute of Music at age 15, debuted with the Philadelphia Orchestra at age 16, and with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at age 19. Carissa studied under professors Gary Graffman and Robert McDonald and went on to receive her master's degree from the Juilliard School. She was recently named a Gilmore Young Artist and has won the Salon de Virtuosi Award and the American Protégé Star Performer Award.
She has performed Sydney Opera House to the Kennedy Center and Carnegie Hall.
Chen grew up in Silicon Valley and began playing the violin at age seven. She was Gramophone's 2023 Young Artist of the Year,
Chen won at the 2019 Queen Elisabeth International Violin Competition followed by the 2020 Avery Fisher Career Grant and the 2020 Lincoln Center Emerging Artist Award. She is the Inaugural recipient of the Robert Levin Award from Harvard University. Her mentors include Levin, Donald Weilerstein, Itzhak Perlman, Miriam Fried, and Catherine Cho.
Chen has performed as a soloist with the New York Philharmonic and the Chicago Symphony and appeared in venues such as Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, Vienna's Musikverein, and Berliner Philharmonie. She plays chamber music with Perlman, Weilerstein, and Levin.
In March of 2023, Chen produced a debut album called Stella X Schubert. Her instruments include the 1700 "ex-Petri" Stradivari and the 1708 "Huggins" Stradivari.
There will be solo and combined performances at the Feb. 16 concert.
To purchase tickets, visit Chesapeakemusic.org.

title: Maryland stories: Filmmaker's new movie aims to scare
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland stories: Filmmaker's new movie aims to scare

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the two decades since she graduated from Patuxent High School in southern Maryland, local actress, producer and writer Victoria (Fratz) Fradkin has developed a reputation among those familiar with horror films, and recently the newly christened mother unveiled her second such film in that genre.Fradkin, 37, a Maryland native who attended The Calverton School in Huntingtown as an eighth and ninth grader before transferring to Patuxent High, vaulted onto the scene nearly 10 years ago when her debut film, "Electric Love" (2018) won for best world premiere at the San Diego International Film Festival, followed three years later by her first horror film "Val" in 2021.
Last November, Fradkin and her husband, Aaron Fradkin, a Los Angeles-based writer and director originally from Massachusetts, collaborated on yet another foray into the horror genre with "Beezel," which was released last fall. Months later, only a week before Christmas, they welcomed their first child, a daughter, and the tandem has remained busy.
Her newest film was released on streaming services nationwide last fall.
"When we first started to make 'Beezel' I wanted to be able to tell the story in three parts and then weave it together through one thread," Fradkin, who now lives on the West Coast in California, said. "Of course, even after it's finished you never know how it's going to be received by the audience until you see it during the premiere. What I found most enjoyable was seeing and hearing the audience react in different scenes. It was pretty much the reactions that we were hoping for."
"Beezel" covers six tumultuous decades as three unwitting guests of a cursed New England home stumble upon a sinister secret dwelling beneath its floors — an eternal witch with an insatiable thirst for the souls of the living. In actuality, the film was set inside the crawl space of the very home in which Aaron Fradkin was raised and his parents made no changes to the eery setting.
Although she is trying to carve her own niche in the industry, especially among horror film makers, Fradkin admits there have been several influences along the way, including independent director Damien McCarthy known for "Oddity" and actress Naomi Watts, who has emerged as one of the leading ladies in the fright film set.
"I've tried my hand in acting, but I really feel more at home writing and producing," Fradkin said. "A lot of the success from horror movies stems from the setting. We filmed much of 'Beezel' in my husband's parents' old house in the crawl space. It was really creepy, but it wasn't a set, it was just that way. His parents have since sold that house, but the new owners kept the crawl space the same way. They always wanted to live in a haunted house."
"Beezel" follows on the heels of "Val," co-written by Fradkin and her husband, produced by Victoria Fradkin, who also played the role of "Jenny" while Misha Reeves played the title character. Zachary Mooren, Erik Griffin, Sufe Bradshaw and Kyle Howard also play primary roles in the Patuxent graduate's first foray into the horror genre.
"I want people to know that movie was an escape to go back into the movies of the 2000s," Fradkin said. "It doesn't take itself too seriously. We pretty much wrote the entire script with all of these actors in mind."

title: Local author asks, does a kitten belong in school?
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Local author asks, does a kitten belong in school?

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 477
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Growing up in Massachusetts, in the mid-80's, second-grader Nancy Mugele, now Head of Kent School, a private day school in Chestertown, had an adorable and stubborn gray kitten that followed her to class.The affectionate feline was called Jingles. Her unique personality left a big impression because years later, the kitten would be the subject of Mugele's first children's book, "Jingles Goes to School."
Late October, Bumble Bee Books, the children's publishing department of Olympia Publishers, put out the book and can now be purchased at Bumblebee Books website, on Amazon, and locally here at the Book Plate, in downtown Chestertown.
Mugele based her book off her childhood, even mentioning her home, the house with the red shutters at 19 Bonney Lane. That was where Jingles escaped from back then, braving the New England winters to follow Mugele to school. Mugele's mother had to place her infant son in a stroller to come pick up Jingles.
"That's not normal behavior for a cat," Mugele said laughing.
This amusing anecdote is the plot of the book.
In between the colorful illustrated pages, Jingles displays to Nancy's teacher, Miss Bevivino, her class, and the principal, Mr. Willett, her love of learning. At one point, Jingles even plays the piano, "learning to trill in all the right places," at the school concert.
Will Jingles earn the affection of some of her harshest critics, like the principal?
One thing is for sure, Jingles loves school, and so does her creator, the Head of Kent School of nine years with a career in education over 20 years.
"It's really remarkable, the transformative power of books," Mugele expressed.
She witnesses this on a weekly basis, reading Jingles' adventures to her pre-k, kindergarten, and first graders, seeing their reactions.
"They absolutely love it. They ask a lot of questions. It's such a thrill when I show them actual pictures of Jingles, and see how their imaginations expand."
From her enjoyment of reading aloud to her students, she pitched her story to eight publishers, and heard back from three of them — no small feat for a new author.
Olympia Publishers appreciated that Mugele drew from her own experiences. They took care of the artwork and distribution, leaving Mugele to dream up future stories for Jingles.
In the meantime, "Jingles Goes to School," will be coming out in hardback Jan. 30, and in the near future the author plans to do local book tours. She will also be doing one for a friend at Farley's Bookshop in Pennsylvania.
Her passion however is to visit schools, reading to the kids.
"It is one of my most important meetings throughout the week," Mugele said.
She hones her writing skills on her blog site nancymugele.com, while envisioning new adventures to pen.
And as she looks for more inspiration from her life, nobody is safe, especially her lovable black lab, "River."
"He won't mind one bit if I make him the star," Mugele said with a smile. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

For more and to RSVP: https://www.zachgalleryeaston.com/rsvp / https://www.meredithdavieshadaway.com/

title: Country Cooking: Super Bowl snacks
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Super Bowl snacks

 February 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1218
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Super Bowl LIX will be held at the Caesars Superdome in New Orleans, Louisiana kicking off at 6:30 p.m. on Feb. 9.This will be the 11th time that New Orleans has hosted the Super Bowl, tying with Miami for the most Super Bowl hosts.
Some Super Bowl facts: the Super Bowl decides which team becomes the National Football League champions. Since 2022, the games are played on the second Sunday in February. The Super Bowl is the final game of every NFL Season since 1966. The Super Bowl was supposedly named after a children's toy.
There are many gatherings and parties held on Super Bowl Sunday, and everyone has a favorite food they serve — from finger foods to snacks, pizzas, chili, soups, sandwiches and subs to wings.
No matter whether you prepare them at home, pick up a carry out or order home delivery, enjoy the gathering. May the best team win.
The Kansas City Chiefs
KANSAS CITY BRISKET BURNT ENDS
BEEF: 3-4 lb Chuck Roast, 2 tbsp favorite barbecue seasoning, 1 tbsp canola oil.
SAUCE: ¾ cup ketchup, ½ cup apple cider vinegar, 1.5 tbsp hot sauce, 1 tbsp brown sugar, ½ tbsp garlic paste, ½ tbsp Worcestershire sauce, salt to taste.
Cube your chuck roast into 1-inch cubes and place in a bowl. Lather with canola oil and then season with barbecue seasoning. Place the cubes onto a baking tray with about half an inch separation between each cube. Place in the fridge for 1 hour to set, then let come to room temperature 15 minutes before cooking. Preheat a grill or smoker using a two zone fire with Charcoal to 275 degrees. Two-zone fire: Coals spread along either side of the grill, with an empty space down the center, ideal for smoking and low-temperature cooking. Add some hickory chunks or chips for added smoke flavor. Place the beef onto the smoker to cook for about 1.5 hours until they begin to soften. As the beef smokes, heat up a medium high fire for the barbecue sauce. Add a skillet with the ingredients for the barbecue sauce and let simmer until thickened. Once warm and well incorporated, pull the barbecue sauce off the heat to cool. After 1.5 hours on the smoker, pull the beef off and place into a medium size foil bin. Top the burnt ends with the barbecue sauce and mix around. Cover the bin with aluminum foil and place back on the smoker to cook for another 2.5 hours. Add more barbecue sauce if needed so that there is a decent amount of liquid in order to break down the burnt ends. Once the burnt ends are tender and can easily break apart, pull them off and let cool for 10 minutes. Toss the cooled burnt ends in some of the foil bins sauce, season with a little more barbecue seasoning. To make the most authentic burnt ends at home, you will need a smoker but you can make them on a gas or charcoal grill.
The Philadelphia Eagles
PHILLY CHEESECAKE
1 1/2 cups Honey Maid graham cracker crumbs, ⅓ cup butter or margarine (melted), 4 (8-oz) packages Philadelphia cream cheese (softened), 1 cup and 3 tbsps sugar, 1 tsp vanilla, 4 eggs.
Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Mix crumbs, butter and 3 tbsps sugar until combined; press firmly onto the bottom of a 9-inch springform pan. Beat cream cheese, 1 cup sugar, and vanilla in a mixing bowl until smooth. Add eggs, one at a time, mixing on low speed until just blended. Pour over the crust. Bake in the preheated oven until the center is almost set, about 55 minutes. Loosen cake from the pan rim; cool before removing rim. Refrigerate for 4 hours before serving.
New Orleans
For the next two recipes, we are going to have a game of our own, Gumbo vs. Jambalaya.
Jambalaya is primarily a rice dish, while gumbo is more of a stew. Both are made with chicken, sausage and/or seafood.
GUMBO
ROUX: 1 cup all-purpose flour, 2/3 cup oil (vegetable or canola oil).
GUMBO: 1 bunch celery (diced, leaves and all), 1 green bell pepper (diced), 1 large yellow onion (diced), 1 bunch green onions (finely chopped), 1 bunch fresh chopped parsley, 2-3 cloves garlic, 1-2 tbsps Cajun seasoning, 6-8 cups chicken broth, 12 ounce package andouille sausages (sliced into coins), meat from 1 rotisserie chicken, 2 cups shrimp (pre-cooked), hot cooked rice for serving.
In a large, heavy bottom stock pot combine flour and oil. Cook on medium-low heat, stirring constantly for 30-45 minutes. This part takes patience — when it's finished it should be as dark as chocolate and have a soft, "cookie dough" consistency. Be careful not to let it burn. Feel free to add a little more flour or oil as needed to reach this consistency.In a separate skillet on medium-high heat, place the sausage slices in one layer in the pan. Brown them well on one side (2-3 minutes) and then use a fork to flip each over onto the other side to brown. Remove to a plate. Add ½ cup of the chicken broth to the hot skillet that had the sausage to deglaze the pan. Pour the broth and drippings into your large soup pot. Add remaining 5 ½ cups of chicken broth. Add veggies, parsley, garlic and roux to the pot and stir well. Bring to a boil over medium heat and boil for 5-7 minutes, or until the vegetables are slightly tender. Stir in Cajun seasoning to taste. Add chicken, sausage and shrimp. Taste and serve. At this point taste it and add more seasonings to your liking —salt, pepper, chicken bouillon paste, garlic, more Joe's stuff or more chicken broth — until you reach the perfect flavor. Serve warm over rice. (Tastes even better the next day).
JAMBALAYA
1 tbsp oil (vegetable or canola oil), 1 lb andouille sausage (cut into ¼ inch thick slices), 1 1/2 lbs boneless skinless chicken breasts (cut into bite-size pieces), 2 tbsps all-purpose flour, 2 tbsps butter, 1 yellow or white onion (chopped), 4 green onions (chopped), 4 cloves garlic (finely minced), 3 ribs celery (chopped), 1 green bell pepper (chopped), 1 1/2 tsps dried basil, 1 1/2 tsps Cajun seasoning, 1 tsp kosher salt, ½ tsp fresh ground black pepper, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper (optional add more for spice), 14.5-oz can diced tomatoes, 2 1/2 cups low-sodium chicken broth, 1 1/4 cup long-grain white rice.
In a large skillet with a fitted lid, add the oil over medium high heat. Once hot, add the chicken and cook, flipping once or twice to brown on all sides (don't cook chicken through). Remove to a bowl. Add sausage and cook until browned on both sides. Add to the bowl with the chicken. Reduce heat to medium and add butter and flour to the pan and stir well, scraping up any leftover browned bits from the pan. Add onion, garlic, celery, and bell peppers and sauté for 3 minutes. Add basil, cajun seasoning, diced tomatoes, salt and pepper and stir well to combine. Add chicken broth and rice and bring mixture to a gentle boil. Add reserved meat to the pan. Reduce heat, cover pan with fitted lid and cook for 20 minutes.Remove from heat, and rest with the lid on for 10 minutes. Then gently fluff with a fork and rest again for 5 minutes before serving. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While the Super Bowl is a sports event, the content centers on food culture and traditions associated with the occasion, aligning more with 'Entertainment' than 'Sports'.

title: 'Make Muskrat Great Again': Maggie’s Coleman Tavern in Rock Hall hosts annual cook-off
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Make Muskrat Great Again': Maggie’s Coleman Tavern in Rock Hall hosts annual cook-off

 February 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Earlier this month, Maggie's Coleman Tavern on Sharp Street in Rock Hall was once again celebrated the mighty muskrat, that is — by way of savory muskrat meat served in all kinds of unique ways. Maggie's threw their annual Muskrat Cook-Off, in its 10th year, where savory recipes featuring the web-footed critter were sampled and voted on.Around the table, muskrat meat was served alongside oysters by a man affectionately nicknamed as Capt. Jack Sparrow, next to him, Phat Daddy's served up barbecue for anyone not digging muskrat.
In the competition, muskrat meat, supplied by trapper Robert Smith, was sampled in quesadillas, mixed into stew, added to jalapeño and cheese, fried up on the grill with onions, or placed inside an egg roll.
"The meat's a little bit of an acquired taste, like beef, only if cows ate from the swamp," said one jovial man, sampling each station.
Owner of Maggie's Carolyn Jones presented first place to the all-female team declaring "Make muskrat great again!" with their swamp rat slider. Jones provided the red-capped team with a trophy created by Greg Jetton from Dirty Cat Garage.
Visiting friends with a bubbly, energetic spirit, Heather VanDerbeek, from Westchester, Pennsylvania, commended the women's set-up. "This is awesome! I tried all the samples, and this is the best. The food, the presentation and the energy is all there," she said.
Also receiving awards from Dirty Cat and coming in second were George Parker and Alex Cooper, with their muskrat cheesesteak egg rolls. In third, with their Hawaiian slider, was the team of Ben Hicks, Darrold Smith and Chuck Woodfield.
Although the weather was windy, with a chill in the air, camaraderie among competitors and tasters alike was warmly felt.
Friends, family, neighbors and quite a few tourists, sampled muskrat, listened to live music courtesy of The Everafter, and thrilled to watch their neighbors and friends receive awards.
"We work hard to play hard," Rock Hall Mayor James Cook said, counting around 150 to 200 people in attendance.
Jones was pleased with the turnout, noting this year they had a few less contestants than last, but enthusiasm for the event remained.
The festival, Jones said, came out of a bored day with the idea this would be a fun, creative way to escape the cabin fever of winter months.
But why muskrat? Why not oysters, crabs, or even white tailed deer?
Because muskrat, spotted along Maryland's lakes, ponds, swamps, marshes rivers and streams, was once a thriving industry on the Eastern Shore. During the Great Depression era, muskrat pelts were the mainstay of the winter economy after blue crab season ended, as stated in an article in Smithsonian Magazine titled "Muskrat Love."
Smith, known as "Trapper Bob" follows that time-honored tradition. In winter, when he cannot work his concrete business, he enjoys the extremely challenging work of trapping muskrat, coyote, fox, otter, possum, and other animals.
Although his muskrat meat has been sampled in the past cook-offs, this was his first year attending in person and he brought with him those pelts, drawing in many admirers. In only about two hours, he sold half of them, he said.
And will there be an 11th muskrat cook-off?
"As long as we can trap 'em," a resident holding a beer in one hand and a muskrat quesadilla in the other remarked. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
