title: Upcoming shows at the Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
Upcoming shows at the Avalon

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1125
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are some of the upcoming shows at the Avalon Theatre (including its Stoltz Listening Room) in Easton with descriptions of the acts from the music venue. For more: nhttps://avalonfoundation.org/.Jordan TiceThursday, February 20, 2025
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Jordan Tice is a singer, songwriter and guitarist who combines witty, well-crafted songs with deft fingerstyle and flatpick guitar playing. His performances have been compared to those of legends like Leo Kottke, John Hartford, and David Bromberg for their mix of virtuosity and playfulness and his songs have been compared to those of writers Bob Dylan and John Prine for their humor, introspection and philosophical nature. Folk fans might recognize Jordan as a member of the instrumental bluegrass supergroup, Hawktail, as well as his sideman work with many other artists in the folk/bluegrass genre such as Dave Rawlings, Andrew Marlin (Mandolin Orange), Yola, Tony Trischka, and comedian Steve Martin. https://www.jordantice.net/
Slambovian Circus of DreamsFriday, February 21, 2025
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Musical influences of Dylan, Bowie, Incredible String Band, Syd Barrett, and The Waterboys can be heard, yet the Slambovians' musicianship and critically acclaimed songwriting stand on their own. Joziah (the resident shaman of Slambovia), leads with vocals described as "soothing and bewitching as a snake oil tonic." Longtime bandmates Tink Lloyd (accordion, cello, mandolin, flute) and guitarist/mandolin wizard Sharkey McEwen bring their magic to the Slambovian brew with "a little help from their friends" — RJ McCarty (keys, bass, sax), Bob Torsello (bass), and Matthew Abourezk (drums).
This Woodstock-tinged psychedelia has a hint of southern rock and British folk combined with solid songwriting — a slice of Americana pie that is irresistible! The band's latest studio release, "A Very Unusual Head" is considered to be "their finest work to date" (Rock'n'Reel Magazine, UK). https://slambovia.com/
An Evening with Kathy MatteaSunday, February 23, 2025, 7 p.m.
Hailed by The Washington Post as "one of Nashville's finest song interpreters," Kathy Mattea has enjoyed much success and acclaim during her 40-year career in Country, Bluegrass and Folk music. Not only has Kathy had two Grammy wins, four CMA Awards, four #1 country singles, and five gold albums (plus a Platinum Greatest Hits collection), she now hosts "Mountain Stage," a live music program on West Virginia's Public Broadcasting that often features artists who have played at the Avalon. Kathy's latest album is "Pretty Bird", a wide-ranging collection of songs that chronicles the phase of her rededication to singing. https://www.mattea.com/
Woodshed Blues BandFriday, February 28, 7 p.m.
The Woodshed Blues Band consists of some of the Mid-Shore's finest musicians. Easton native Warren Brey ventured to Hollywood, where he wrote and recorded original music and found himself performing on Sunset Strip at the famous Whiskey–A-Go-Go and Roxy Theater night clubs.
Matt Redman, raised on a farm near Chestertown, began playing harmonica around the age of 16 and, during his senior year, played with local Kent County rock band, Eclipse. Since then he's won a harmonica-playing contest headlined by blues legend James Cotton.
Mike Horvath, new to the Eastern Shore, has performed all types of music all over the U.S. and Europe. He's played with symphony orchestras, theatre companies, jazz, rock, and blues groups as well as doing session work.
St. Michaels resident Terry Jones is known for his musical talents as a vocalist, guitarist and bassist, while local teacher Woody Lambert has performed as a keyboardist and vocalist with various musical groups on the Shore. https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=61566026330834
Newmyer Flyer's "Bleecker Street" (A Tribute)The Simon & Garfunkel Songbook
Saturday, March 1, 7 p.m.
Newmyer Flyer captures the essence of Simon & Garfunkel, the most successful music duo of all time, and for many "the sound of the 1960s". Enjoy live renditions of achingly beautiful tunes, meaningful lyrics, and vocal harmonies that soothe the soul on songs like 'Mrs Robinson', 'Bridge Over Troubled Water', 'Homeward Bound', 'The Sound Of Silence' and many more! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rl55sO00OZU
The Steel WheelsWednesday, March 5, 7 p.m.
Tickets: $30
Virginia-based folk-rock band The Steel Wheels have spent almost twenty years writing, recording, and touring, all the while constantly honing their evolving brand of American roots music. Through the years, The Steel Wheels have drawn on both traditional form and modern sounds to capture the beauty in all of life's varied trials and triumphs. And they are the founders and hosts of the Red Wing Roots Music Festival, a beloved staple of the Shenandoah Valley. In their latest album, Sideways, the band's signature close harmonies and propulsive mountain energy are something to be experienced live. https://www.thesteelwheels.com/
Post-Mardi Gras Louisiana Music Night with Philip Dutton & the AlligatorsFriday, March 7, 2025, 7 p.m.
The Mardi Gras party continues in the Avalon!
Philip Dutton & the Alligators serve up a zesty musical Jambalaya that brings Louisiana's Bayou right here to Maryland's Easton Shore.
Their inspiration comes from legendary acts like Professor Longhair, The Meters, Dr. John, Allen Toussant, Louis Armstrong, Jon Cleary, and so many others! https://www.facebook.com/philipduttonandthealligators/
Swamp DonkeyDance Floor Will Be Open
Saturday, March 8, 7 p.m.
Stretching the "grass" concept to the limit and offering a unique sound in the process, the Annapolis/Baltimore-based Electric Newgrass band, Swamp Donkey, delivers an exciting combination of original songs and unique covers that span many genres in a style they have made all their own. Swamp Donkey prides themselves on a big sound that you will likely not hear anywhere else! The band takes an intense and creative approach to their live performance that is riddled with surprises, mesh-ups, and lots of energy! Fans are sure to experience a "swamped-up" version of something that will keep them stomping their feet. https://www.swampdonkeymusic.com/
Ye VagabondsFriday, March 14, 2025, 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room, 40 E. Dover Street, Easton, MD
Not long after Irish brothers Brían and Diarmuid Mac Gloinn of Ye Vagabonds moved from their rural hometown Carlow to Dublin, the folk duo soon found themselves "at the fore of a new wave of Irish folk" (Irish Examiner). They quickly became known in the traditional Irish, blues and folk scenes in the city, playing folk songs as well as their own original material. Their blend of harmonic folk music is influenced by traditional Irish and European music, American old time, and the music of the 1960s folk revival. http://yevagabonds.com/
Comedy @ the Stoltz with LeClerc AndreTwo Shows with Opener (TBD)
Saturday, March 15, 7 p.m. and 9 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room, 40 E. Dover Street, Easton, MD Tickets: $25
New York stand-up comedian LeClerc Andre is quickly building a name for himself. With a quick wit and charm that's been dazzling clubs and colleges across the country, LeClerc was featured at Just For Laughs Comedy Festival as one of the New Faces of Comedy. This appearance spring-boarded him into his TV network debut on The Tonight Show w/Jimmy Fallon, as well as on NBC's "Bring the Funny".
His first comedy album, "I am LeClerc", recorded live at New York Comedy Club, was released in January 2023. Insta @leclercandre.

title: Sample spirits with planes at museum event
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Sample spirits with planes at museum event

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Saturday,, Feb. 22, those interested in learning about the varied range of distilleries throughout Maryland will have the chance to celebrate the "Spirits of Maryland" at the Patuxent River Naval Air Museum and Visitor Center while sampling various cocktails and spirits.One of the Maryland distilleries to makes its presence known last winter at the annual event was Copper Compass, which is based in White Plains. Co-owned by Herb Banks and his cousin, April Toyer, Copper Compass handcrafts two types of rum from two types of molasses and last winter the local distillery used the outing to debut its new Lemondrop run.
"We had been talking about opening a distillery for the last two years," said Bank, who retired from the U.S. Navy n 2022 after serving for 23 years. "And it seemed like a good idea to do. If there is we haven't found it yet. I believe we make some really good spirits, but running a business is a full-time job so we're trying to be more efficient in our process."
Schmidts Spirits of Beltsville in Prince George's County, which distills gin and whiskey topped in sales annually by its Cobalt Rye Whiskey, enjoyed a banner showing at the 2024 event. Master distiller Brian J. Roan, noting the company will officially turn four on February 25, was pleased with the clientele and overall proceedings last year.
"Business was great," Roan said. "We had a lot of people stop by and sample and ask us some really interesting questions, and we solid a lot of bottles [of whiskey] so it was really fantastic. It's great to be able to take something that you enjoy and turn that enthusiasm and passion into a career."
The Spirits of Maryland will be offered at the Patuxent River Naval Air Museum, located at 22156 Three Notch Road in Lexington
The first session begins at 1 p.m. for VIP attendees with general admission opening at 1:30 p.m. and ending at 3 p.m. The second session begins at 3:30 p.m. for VIP attendees with general admission admitted from 4 to 5:30 p.m.
Tickets for the event range from $33.85 for general admission to $55.20 for VIP guests. For more information, contact the museum during normal business hours at 301-863-1900 or go to marylandspirits.org/spirits-of-maryland-events.

title: Author pens first two Western novels
author: Staff Writer
content:
Author pens first two Western novels

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 601
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland author Judy Hannigan recently released her first two novels "Lost in Prosperity" and "Everything in Prosperity."According to a news release the books are set against the backdrop of the 1875 Wyoming Territory and is a "riveting tale of a woman who longs to trust her heart to a man she doesn't remember and a man who refuses to lose the love of the woman who completes him."
The book contains some graphic language and violence.
The St. Leonard writer moved to Calvert County from Michigan 35 years ago. She and her husband stay active in the community by supporting the local St. Leonard Volunteer Fire Department, of which her husband Richard is the company's training officer.
When she's not writing, she's reading, designing her book covers, and occasionally editing fundraising letters or offering advice and encouragement to other independent authors. She is currently working on the third book in the series, which as of now is untitled.
The books are available at www.amazon.com/author/judyhannigan.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
Always a voracious reader, I drafted the first chapter of "Lost in Prosperity" while in high school, but I didn't finish the story until recently. I penned the second novel, "Everything in Prosperity," last year.
What inspires you to write?
I write historical westerns because in that era you could reinvent yourself. My characters do what's right instead of what's told, exemplifying justice can triumph. I believe honor, courage, and loyalty are the principles by which to live.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
Writing is my third career. I started as a high school and college teacher before becoming a technical editor. Now I write full-time, and every day is an adventure.
What kind of writing process do you use?
I center my stories around a major event before I begin layering in backstories and challenges. I see scenes as if watching through a camera lens, so when the unexpected happens or characters pop up I investigate the possibilities, which means I rarely stick to an outline.
Who are some of your favorite authors?
"Lonesome Dove" author, Larry McMurtry wrote one of the most beloved westerns. I want readers of his novels and fans of television shows like "Yellowstone," "The Virginian," and "The Rifleman" to experience an era in which perseverance, loyalty, forgiveness, and the enduring power of love could redeem a wounded soul. Rosanne Bittner's "Savage Destiny" and "Outlaw Hearts" series feature flawed but courageous characters that fulfill their potential when forced into the gray zone wedged between black and white.
Please include a brief description of the book
Set in the 1870s, "Lost in Prosperity" opens the series by blending adventure, romance, and suspenseful mystery to tell the story of Sam Hilliard Stone, a rich and beautiful heiress with a temper as fast as her quick draw, and Providence "Jackson" Knight, the handsome, rugged rancher determined to protect the woman he loves, as they struggle to build a dynasty in the wild, Wyoming Territory. Together, they navigate threats from an unknown enemy to uncover why events from their past are converging to destroy their future.
In "Everything in Prosperity," Sam and Jackson risk everything to protect the town citizens from a notorious gang and survive the tangled web of deceptions threatening them.
Please include an excerpt from the book
"Jackson's face was pale. He tried to brush her hands away. Failing, he grabbed her wrists and pulled her close. "Sonofabitch, Sam — even shot up, all I think about is how much I love you and ache for you to love me."
Sam's eyes filled with tears as she gently wriggled her wrists from his grasp. It wasn't difficult." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: New Chesapeake City restaurant, market taking time to create a masterpiece
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
New Chesapeake City restaurant, market taking time to create a masterpiece

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chef Nina Vietri said that she is crafting her restaurant and market like an artist creates a painting: with intuition and tender care until everything is just right; a masterpiece.When walking through the doors at 222 Bohemia Avenue, the lemon yellow walls welcome with a warm hug. The Vietri family's homemade pottery lines the wooden tables, each one unique in its own right.
"I'm looking at it like a painting...I'll open when I'm ready to walk away," Vietri said, adding that she plans to open in mid to late May, with potential pop ups beforehand.
Vietri initially planned to open her restaurant and market this past December, but is not rushing the process because she wants to make sure her first restaurant is everything she dreamed it to be and more.
"I could not imagine opening back then. Because the real, true vision, it has changed," Vietri said. She is now hiring an upholsterer for finely designed seating, hanging chandeliers and always adding more detail to bring her vision fully to life. "Rome wasn't built in a day, isn't that what they say?"
Since the fall, Vietri has also been busy as a celebrity chef both on air and filming at Bohemia Manor Winery, all while being a mom to her nearly two-year-old son.
Vietri just finished filming as a celebrity chef on Living Abundantly with Sarah Vie, a talk show by best-selling author and expert lifestyle coach, Sarah van der Steur.
They even filmed one segment with Golden Bachelor contestant, Susan Knowles.
"She cooked with me and we had a blast," Vietri said.
But it doesn't stop there, Vietri is working with producers to get her own cooking show in the future, something to look forward to.
But for now, her focus is the restaurant and market.
As both the chef and owner, Vietri aims to offer guests a one-on-one experience with her constantly changing menu, including her chef's tasting menu offered in the Tuscany Room, which seats 11 people.
Her menus will adapt with each region of Italy, offering endless varieties of flavors and dishes for everyone to enjoy. She will also have a beautiful gelato machine from Europe to spin up the best of the best Italian desserts. Everything in the restaurant and market will be locally sourced and made fresh daily.
In the back of her restaurant she will offer an authentic Italian market as well as an open space for bridal showers, weddings, and other events. In addition to various tasty treats, "boat boxes" — coolers with sandwiches, drinks, and snacks — will be available at the market just in time for summer boating season. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Gretchen's table: Miso-mustard salmon and asparagus is elegant and easy
author: Gretchen McKay Pittsburgh Post-Gazette
content:
Gretchen's table: Miso-mustard salmon and asparagus is elegant and easy

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Gretchen McKay Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | Section: Entertainment 
 
 593
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Salmon is famously heart-healthy, which makes it a popular choice for a seafood meal. The average American consumes more than three pounds a year of the fatty fish, according to the National Fisheries Institute.Who can blame us? Not only is salmon a source of complete protein, but it's also chock full of omega-3 fatty acids — "healthy" fats that have been shown to do the body good by reducing inflammation and lowering blood pressure.
The firm-fleshed fish is also pretty easy to find in most grocery stores (both fresh and flash-frozen), and can be cooked in so many different and exciting ways — you can pan-fry, roast, grill or poach the rosy-hued fillets, and also turn them into fish cakes — that it never gets boring for the adventurous cook.
In this recipe, we build a meal around chopped dates, the classic, ancient superfood featured in "Hot Date! Sweet & Savory Recipes Celebrating the Date" by Rawaan Alkhatib ( Chronicle Books, $35).
Dates — a tropical stone fruit from date palms — are known for their versatility and flavor and are naturally sweet and high in fiber and antioxidants. Here, they provide the base for a tangy-sweet marinade that offers a lovely depth of flavor.
Garlic and Dijon mustard play supporting roles, along with white miso, a paste made from soybeans that have been fermented with a large portion of rice that adds a savory umami.
Between marinating and cooking time, the dish takes only about a half-hour from start to finish, and the accompanying asparagus is roasted alongside the fish on a parchment-covered baking sheet. That means dinner is both quick and relatively mess-free.
If you don't care for asparagus, simply substitute another vegetable, such as eggplant or zucchini. You also can swap out the fish — another sweet swimmer like trout works well with the marinade, and so would cod fillets. I didn't have any malt vinegar, so substituted apple cider vinegar.
When choosing salmon, look for fillets that appear moist, with shiny skin. If you can, opt for wild-caught salmon, especially from Alaska. Atlantic salmon is typically available year-round, and has a melt-in-your-mouth texture and a mild flavor.
Miso-Mustard Salmon and Asparagus
4 skin-on salmon fillets, about 6 ounces eachKosher saltFreshly ground black pepper3 pitted dates, roughly chopped and soaked in 2 tablespoons warm water1 fat garlic clove, minced2 tablespoons olive oil2 tablespoons Dijon mustard1 tablespoon white miso1 tablespoon malt vinegar1 pound fresh asparagus, woody ends trimmed
Generously sprinkle salmon fillets all over with salt and pepper.
In small bowl, combine mushy dates and their soaking water with garlic, olive oil, mustard, miso and vinegar, stirring until blended.
Pour about half of this marinade on top of the salmon fillets and gently smoosh the fish around until evenly coated.
Let fish marinate in the fridge for 15-30 minutes.
Toss the asparagus spears in the remaining marinade and set aside until ready to cook.
Preheat oven to 325 degrees. Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper.
Place salmon fillets, skin-side down, on the prepared baking sheet and surround with the asparagus spread out in a single layer.
Bake until the salmon is just opaque and gently flakes when pressed with a fork, about 15-20 minutes. If the fish or asparagus is looking a little pale and lackluster at this point, turn the broiler on high (stay close, the marinade burns easily) until everything becomes a little more golden.
Serve with grains or greens or both to round out the meal.
Serves 4.
— "Hot Date! Sweet & Savory Recipes Celebrating the Date, from Party Food to Everyday Feasts" by Rawaan Alkhatib
Gretchen McKay is food editor with the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While health benefits of salmon are mentioned, the primary context is culinary entertainment.  The Chesapeake Film Festival (CFF) and Talbot County Free Library are launching a new monthly film series, celebrating the library's 100th Anniversary and CFF's 18th Season of Our Bay, Our World, Our Festival.The series features movies at the library's main branch in Easton. Screenings will begin at 6 p.m. for the first three screenings and at 2 p.m. for the June Saturday date, No reservations are required.
Highlights and dates March 19: "Taste of Things" — Celebrate Women's History Month with this exquisite film starring Juliette Binoche, a tribute to culinary artistry and female empowerment.
April 30: "River" — In honor of Earth Day, experience this breathtaking documentary narrated by Willem Dafoe, exploring the vital role of rivers in our ecosystem and culture.
May 21: "Conclave" — Dive into the intrigue of this Oscar-nominated film starring Ralph Fiennes and Isabella Rossellini, a gripping narrative of power and secrecy.
June 21: "Wicked" — Get ready for a wild and wonderful cinematic journey with thism theatrical masterpiece starring Cynthia Erivo, Ariana Grande, and Jeff Goldblum.
"We are delighted to partner with the Talbot County Free Library to bring this diverse and dynamic film series to our community," said Irene Magafan, president of the Chesapeake Film Festival. It's a celebration of storytelling, history, and the shared joy of cinema."
All screenings are at the Easton Branch of the Talbot Library and are free and open to the public.
For more information, please visit www.chesapeakefilmfestival.com. Or call the library at 410-822-1626.

title: Washington College opens up pub on campus
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Washington College opens up pub on campus

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 391
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Washington College has announced they have opened The Golden Goose, a pub on campus located in the former faculty lounge downstairs in Hynson Lounge.This was made known to the public partly through a Kent County Commissioner's meeting Feb. 25, when Kent Alcohol and Tobacco Enforcement Inspector Bonnie Pearsall informed commissioners the campus has requested a liquor license for the establishment. "They want to provide a safe and secure environment for their students of proper age of 21 or older to drink alcoholic beverages."
Pearsall told the commissioners the staff had some reservations regarding this endeavor, but since then Kent County Attorney Tom Yeager provided some suggestions to the college.
He suggested placing and posting signs stating nobody under 21 or older can enter, even to sit at the bar, and bringing in outside alcoholic beverages is forbidden.
"The college has provided us copies of signs that will placed throughout the pub and the sketch of the pub's layout," Pearsall said.
Commission President Ron Fithian, said if this would go through, would Pearsall be there regularly to apply the same laws as other establishments in the county. She confirmed that she would, then added that the pub is not for the public, but students are allowed two guests.
"They assured me they would be checking IDs and doing wristbands or stamps they can use a scanner with to make sure everyone is of the proper age," Pearsall said, after discussing it in a meeting with college officials.
Commissioner John Price said Washington College currently has a license for special events and catering and can open up different areas on the campus. With that, they made a motion to approve the addition of a pub area to the existing liquor license subject to specified restrictions for students under 21.
It was unanimously approved.
Fithian said now the liquor license has been approved, they will keep a close eye on the establishment. But as long as the campus abides by the law, he said, it is the school's choice.
When reaching out for additional information about The Golden Goose such as how long has this project been discussed and what governing bodies decided on it, a Washington College spokesperson said, "The campus pub is NOT open to the public and is considered a student/campus life function. Chestertown residents and the members of the public will not be permitted to enter." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Virtual horse race brings excitement for the 47th time
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Virtual horse race brings excitement for the 47th time

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A beloved Betterton tradition once again had residents racing to place their bets. Virtual horse races took place at Betterton Volunteer Fire house Saturday, March 8, sponsored by Still Pond/Betterton Lion's Club.According to Betterton/Still Pond Lions member Debi Cornelius, almost 200 Kent County residents and neighbors showed up, betting on the horse races at their 47th Virtual Race Night.
All proceeds went to the program, Leader Dogs for the Blind. Founded in 1949, this program has stood by their motto, "We serve," complements the Leader Dog mission of empowering people who are blind or visually impaired with lifelong skills for safe and independent daily travel. Millington Lions member Shelley Holland spoke in detail about the program and how people can contribute.
For those who have not had the joy and privilege of getting out to one of these races, put on twice a year, on a large screen, participants watches a DVD from the "Night at the Races," a gaming company that records real horse races. Most races are close, with photo finishes, and the joy of the winners watching is contagious. There are 12 races, sponsored by local companies or individuals.
During the action, patrons placed their bets, chatting with neighbors while they waited in line. People enjoyed beverages, adult or otherwise, munched popcorn, hotdogs and nachos, and exchanged regular money for funny money.
Winner of the 50/50 raffle this year run by both Chesterterton and Betterton/Still Pond Lions was Greg Werner, winning $647, was congratulated by announcer, Tristan Stone.
Other raffle winners received Easter baskets containing festive items.
This race is a Betterton tradition that is also a good recruiting tool for the Lions and an effective fundraiser.
"It was a really fun night!" Cornelius said, thankful for members and the community for their continued support of the Bettertown/Still Pond Lions Club. She urged folks to check out their next race on Nov. 8, a great activity to ring in the holidays.

title: Children’s book author takes young readers on a space adventure
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Children’s book author takes young readers on a space adventure

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 388
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — A mother and son journey beyond the night sky in local children's book author Morgan Glenn's latest release, "Mommy's Adventures to Space".In her second book, Glenn once again brings readers into a world of whimsy and wonder. This time, little Wyatt struggles to fall asleep, and his mother, armed with her enchanted handbag, pulls out a surprise. With a dazzling burst of rainbow energy, the duo is transported beyond Earth's atmosphere, clad in space suits and ready to explore the cosmos.
Glenn, who is expanding "Mommy's Adventures" into a series, describes the 31-page book for ages 3-8 as both fun and educational. Along the way, Mommy introduces Wyatt to the mysteries of the solar system, from the red sands of Mars to the brilliance of distant stars. They even wave to a friendly alien, igniting Wyatt's curiosity about space and science.
As NASA and SpaceX talk about space exploration —launching missions to the Moon, Mars and beyond — "Mommy's Adventures to Space" invites young readers to imagine themselves as future astronauts. The story fosters an early appreciation for science, astronomy and adventure.
The book's main characters are drawn from Glenn's own life. Mommy is based on the author, and fictional Wyatt is inspired by her 7-year-old son.
"He loves the books, though he's a little embarrassed he's in them," Glenn said with a smile. "And he'll tell you that too."
The book, which took about four months to write, was published Jan. 1 and features vibrant, playful illustrations by Ayesha Zaki, the artist behind "Mommy's Adventures". Glenn credits Zaki's artwork with bringing her stories to life while maintaining a consistent visual theme across the series.
As a cafeteria worker at Rock Hall Elementary School, Glenn has a growing fan base among young readers. She hopes to introduce her books to more students across Kent County Public Schools, though she has faced some challenges in gaining traction.
With spring approaching, Glenn is actively seeking opportunities to promote "Mommy's Adventures to Space" while planning Mommy and Wyatt's next adventure. Their first journey took them to a land of roller coasters, and now they've explored the stars. Next, they'll embark on a prehistoric romp with dinosaurs.
Both "Mommy's Adventures" books are available on Amazon by searching Glenn's name — appearing as magically as when Mommy opens her handbag.
For school reading events, contact Glenn at eglenn_23@yahoo.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland man's 1963 Chevy II 400 convertible wins national competition
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Maryland man's 1963 Chevy II 400 convertible wins national competition

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 916
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fran Bailey pays meticulous attention to detail when working on his antique cars, making sure that every part that he installs is historically accurate, that it is the correct shape and that it is exactly the right color.Bailey, 82, also puts in hard work to present a pristine-looking automobile when competing in car shows across the United States, something the Fair Hill, Maryland man has successfully done for several years.
So it's not surprising that Bailey's 1963 Chevrolet Chevy II 400 convertible recently received the top honor — the Louis Chevrolet Memorial Award — in a nationwide competition that started with a field of 2,400 automobiles that were exhibited in numerous car shows across the United States.
Then, a group of highly discerning superior judges narrowed that field to 59 hopefuls, before selecting the automobiles they believed deserved national awards in various classifications. In addition to the trophy, photos of Bailey and his Chevy II 400 appear in the Antique Automobile Club of America (AACA) magazine, along with a blurb about his special antique vehicle.
Bailey bought the Chevy II 400 about two years ago, after learning about it while attending the AACA Grand Nationals in Bettendorf, Iowa in 2022 and then arranging to take a look at it.
He acknowledged that a great deal of work already had been done on the car but, after he got the Chevy II 400 back to his private shop on the residential property he shares with longtime friend, Nancy Simpers, 81, the perfectionist immersed himself in the tasks of making the antique automobile historically accurate and making it gleam.
According to the magazine blurb, "Francis used a lot of elbow grease, along with replacing many parts and pieces that weren't correct. Amenities on the car include power steering, full wheel covers, white sidewall tires and rear radio antenna. Under the hood is the 194 cid/120 hp six-cylinder engine mated to an automatic transmission."
AACA judges are sticklers for historical accuracy, stressed Simpers, who regularly travels with Bailey when he is pulling his trailered automobiles to car shows in Iowa, South Carolina, Virginia, Kentucky, New York, West Virginia, North Carolina and few other states.
"These are not local car shows. Don't get me wrong, the local car shows are fun, but they are just that — shows, not competitions," Simpers said, before further explaining, "These are competitions, and the judges pay a lot of attention to detail. Period correctness is the big thing. Everything on the car has to be accurate."
To make her point, Simpers recalled a Kentucky car show a few years ago and how Bailey's other antique automobile — a 1967 Chevy II sports coupe — earned 1st Place. After winning the competition, Bailey offered the guy who garnered 2nd Place some advice.
"Fran told him, 'You have a round antennae and it is supposed to be oval'," Simpers remembered, emphasizing, "The car has to look good, but it also has to be period correct."
Bailey, who has been retired for 34 years after his career as an E.I. DuPont lab technician, has loved cars since childhood.
"I grew up in New Castle (Del.), and I've been interested in cars ever since I was a kid. I hung around gas stations, and I went to drag races at the Cecil County Dragway (north of North East)," Bailey outlined.
He bought his first car, a 1953 Dodge, in 1959 when he turned 16. "It was my granddad's, and I bought it from him after I got my driver's license. I had a job and I made payments," Bailey said.
Then in 1961, after he turned 18, Bailey started racing regularly at the Cecil County Dragway for the next 17 years and, competing with various vehicles he acquired along the way, he won quite often. Bailey recalls competing with a 1962 Chevrolet Impala that he also used as his everyday car.
"My best car was a '69 Chevelle," Bailey said, referring to his favorite drag-strip vehicle, which is a National Hot Rod Association record holder.
Over the decades, Bailey also dabbled in purchasing and restoring classic vehicles, showcasing them in car shows, often winning trophies, plaques and other prizes.
Bailey bought his 1967 Chevy II sports coupe in 1996, approximately 16 years before he purchased his 1963 Chevrolet Chevy II 400 convertible. Reflecting the detail-oriented restoration work that Bailey invested in those antique automobiles, the '67 Chevy II is insured for $52,000 and the 63 Chevy II 400 convertible is valued at about $30,000.
Simpers, a former teacher who still works as a real estate agent, shares Bailey's interest in antique automobiles. When she was a girl and then a young lady, she competed in thoroughbred racing, Simpers noted.
"I gave up horses for horsepower," she commented, chuckling.
Simpers is the proud owner of a sharp-looking, black 1937 LaSalle, the earliest form of the Cadillac, and it, too, has won local car-show competitions. Her grandfather purchased that LaSalle when it was new, some 88 years ago, and then Simpers bought it at his estate sale in 1967.
As for another one of her classic vehicles, a restored 1938 Chevrolet Street Rod, she gifted that one.
"I gave it to my godson for his 16th birthday. He always loved that car. I told him, 'When you are old enough to drive it, it's yours'," Simpers said.
It's perfect that Simpers and Bailey are antique car enthusiasts and, despite being in their early 80s, the couple is always rolling to pursue their hobby. This year, as in years past, they will travel to car shows in more than a dozen states. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a national car competition and antique car restoration, which aligns with 'Entertainment' as car shows and competitions are recreational events. 'Arts & Culture' is a secondary fit due to the historical preservation aspect, while 'Local Life' is less relevant as the competition is national.

title: 'Magic in the air': Singers parade at Kent's Got Talent
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Magic in the air': Singers parade at Kent's Got Talent

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The second annual Kent's Got Talent was a great way to spend a Saturday night at the Garfield Center for the Arts at the Prince Theatre in Chestertown.Sponsored by the United Way of Kent County, the March 29 show featured nine performers of all ages and walks of life, emceed by Jim Landskroener, a longtime theater member and a founding member of Chestertown's Actors Community Theater.
Contestants were Cece Bagshaw, Ashley Chapa, Lewisson Clarke, Carly Mourlas, Nicholas Ray, Clair Smith, Kiara Voss, Grace Walton and Jay Yerkes.
They performed everything from Broadway hits, soulful country, modern pop to electronica, gothic and dance music—and seemingly every other genre. There were mostly cover songs but also quite a few originals.
For instance, local singer-songwriter Nicholas Ray from Chestertown, who has toured several states, performed his original song, "Ain't Today," and dedicated it to his friend battling cancer.
Lewisson and Clarke performed as a brother-sister duo, presenting their original song, "Jungle Sounds," using looping equipment and adding comedy and crowd work.
Grace Walton, performing under the stage name Jenna L, made one judge virtually clutch her pearls as she delivered her original scary-tale songs. All music and lyrics were written by her and can be found on iTunes and Spotify under Jenna L.
Judges Melissa McGlynn, Terwana Brown and Chris Nieman had a tough job weighing in because there were no bad performances from the group.
But somebody had to win, and judges could pick their winners while audiences chose theirs throughout the night.
Judges' choice for youth was Mourlas, who stunned the audience with her powerful Broadway vocals in Barbra Streisand's "Don't Rain on My Parade."
"No one is ever going to rain on your parade. You connected with the audience and you are a rockstar," Judge Brown told her.
Judges' choice for adult was Voss, who captured the emotion behind "She Used to Be Mine," originally performed by Sara Bareilles in the musical "Waitress." Judge McGlynn said from experience that Voss's song choice was very challenging and that she performed it beautifully.
People's choice winner for youth was Bagshaw, who opened the night with a classic Janis Joplin song, "Me and Bobby McGee," setting the bar high for later performers. Judge Nieman was impressed, saying she built the performance as she went until her voice exploded with confidence.
People's choice for adults was Yerkes, who, despite having technical issues with his guitar at first, won the crowd over with his skilled performance of "In a Dream," dedicated to his wife, Lisa.
The prize winners received a trophy, $100 in Chestertown cash and, of course, important bragging rights.
Not only was it a chance for the audience to hear some remarkable local performers, but it also offered gourmet food prepared by an award-winning chef from the Food Network, Robbie Jester, owner of In Jest Events and Galena native. Local oysters, beef and bread were on the menu, followed by dessert—including ice cream courtesy of Jacqueline Lockwood of Lockbriar Farms.
At the end of the night, the United Way of Kent County raised more than $35,000, according to executive director Amy Meade.
"The money will go to nonprofits in Kent County that focus on education, health and financial stability," she said, thanking all volunteers, sponsors and participants.
"I think there was magic in the air at the Garfield on Saturday night. Not only was the crowd excited to see and hear the variety and excellence of Kent County talent, but the judges and emcee did an amazing job of highlighting the contestants' special talents—and we can't forget the incredible food sourced locally and prepared to perfection by our own celebrity chef," Meade added.
"I have to say I am humbled that all this was to raise money for the United Way of Kent County and our mission to serve those households in need. Thank you to everyone who made Kent's Got Talent so special!" 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a local talent show event ('Kent's Got Talent') featuring performers, judges, and audience engagement, explicitly listed under the 'Entertainment' section. While it touches on community aspects (Local Life), the core focus is on the entertainment event itself.

title: Garfield Center announces cast and production staff for 'A Rock Sails By'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Garfield Center announces cast and production staff for 'A Rock Sails By'

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 231
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Garfield Center in Chestertown will open its second production of the 2025 season on April 25 with Sean Grennan's play, "A Rock Sails By."The play centers on Dr. Lynn Cummings, a facts-only astrophysicist facing personal challenges. When an unidentified object heads toward Earth and she's misquoted by a journalist, she invites him to witness the object with her as it approaches Earth.
Grennan's plays and musicals have seen hundreds of productions worldwide. He has served as playwright in residence at several theaters and as an adjudicator for the Midwest Dramatists Conference.
Nic Carter, the GCA's theatre manager, directs the production. The cast includes Suzanne Thuecks as Dr. Cummings, Macy Morris as Olive Cummings, Dominic Delcoco as Jason Harper, Adrienne Wrona as the Messenger, Brianna Johnson as Haley/Taylor, Hester Sachse as the Doctor/Chancellor and Michael Tucker as Tom.
The production staff includes Stage Manager Jordan Dixon, Sound Designer Benji Price, Technical Director Butch Clark, Costume Designer Heather Robuck, Props Designer Jennifer Kafka Smith and Light Board Operator Shannon Carter. Carter is also the scenic designer.
The production runs weekends through May 11, with 8 p.m. performances on Fridays and Saturdays and 2 p.m. performances on Sundays. The lobby opens one hour before showtime, with house doors opening 30 minutes before performances.
For tickets, visit garfieldcenter.org, call 410-810-2060, or visit 210 High St. during box office hours (Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.).

title: 'Big Little Boat Festival' returning to Conquest Beach
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Big Little Boat Festival' returning to Conquest Beach

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Light Craft, the boat kit experts, will be holding the Big Little Boat Festival at Conquest Beach on the Chester River, on Saturday, May 17. The event is free and open to the public.The Big Little Boat Festival, which has run every year in various forms since 1999, celebrates small wooden boats. The event also features amateurs and professionals who have built boats from Chesapeake Light Craft's celebrated boat kits and plans.
There are hands-on boatbuilding seminars, on-the-water demonstrations, the chance to try out dozens of boats from the Chesapeake Light Craft fleet on the water, cardboard boatbuilding and racing for youngsters, and the popular "Best in Show" judging of home-built wooden boats brought by festival-goers.
The roster of boatbuilding and watercraft experts scheduled to lead seminars and demonstrations includes Chesapeake's owner and CEO John C. Harris, boatbuilder/instructors Andrew Schroeher and Jay Hockenberry, and paddling and rowing coach Nicky Stimpson.
Examples from Chesapeake's fleet of watercraft will be on display including kayaks, rowing and sailing craft, paddleboards, and small powerboats. Festival attendees will bring their own creations to launch and display. Chesapeake Light Craft's awards for amateur-built boats, some of which took hundreds of hours to build and look like exotic furniture, have been a key part of the annual small boat festivals for years. Participants have come from the UK, Florida, the West Coast, and Japan.
Conquest Beach is situated on the 758-acre Conquest Preserve between the Corsica and Chester Rivers.
Festival hours are 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Saturday, May 17. Lunch is available from a food truck on site. Overnight camping for festival participants (tents and small campers only) is available by prior arrangement both Friday and Saturday nights, May 16 and 17.

title: Nicholas Ray aint country? Could have fooled us!
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Nicholas Ray aint country? Could have fooled us!

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 872
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — On a 12-day music tour, local musician/songwriter Nicholas Ray's plans to reach California were thrown off by a snowstorm. Alone, two hours from the Grand Canyon, the snow fell so heavy it froze his headlights. Driving in the dark, fighting to keep visibility, unbeknownst to him, the nearest civilization was two hours away.Ray explained it was a Sioux Indian reservation, where they told him it had not snowed there yet until that very day. "Lucky me," Ray said, laughing, as he talked to the Kent County News inside his garage/band practice room.
He had slept in his car in the parking lot of their gas station and was awoken to coyotes rooting in the trashcans and a mountain of snow on his car. He swept it off with a broom, gave those who let him stay, a copy of his album and moved on, heading southward following the Gulf Coast to warmer weather.
Ray returned home to the farm in Still Pond, to his wife and family with even greater resolve to follow his dreams.
On his visit to major cities from Ohio, Colorado, New Mexico, Texas, Louisiana, Georgia, South and North Carolina, he collected 220 new subscribers to his Spotify and Apple Music accounts, while greeting friends on his journey.
Busking, (playing in the streets for money) was a great experience for him he said, and although he was nervous to start performing original songs in a strange city, everybody was supportive of his dreams of earning a living performing on stage.
These dreams began when he was a soldier in the Maryland National Guard deployed to Kosovo as a mechanic on Black Hawk helicopters. Hard work but during down time, he played the guitar until his hands bled, writing and singing songs.
Now he is ready for the next adventure. In October, Ray and his wife, Brandy Dorey, his biggest cheerleader and hype person, are Nashville-bound — moving on from the county to pursue his music goals.
"If you don't take chances, you never know," Ray said.
Kent County will certainly miss him, but live music lovers have an entire summer to hear him and band members, drummer Steve Toth, Rob McFarlane on bass, and Ray on guitar singing his original southern country style songs.
The 26-year-old Ray has been everywhere. He is a regular performer at Open Mic night at the Betterton Legion, the Back 50 Tavern, The Double Tap Tavern, Ram's Head Tavern, the Chancery in Wilmington Delaware, and the Kent County Fair to name a few.
He will be performing at Riley's Mill Ale Works May 17, and the next day at The Shanty Beach Bar, singing songs about battling depression, transcending love, venting frustrations, talking to God and drinking whiskey with friends.
Inspired by outlaw country greats, Waylon Jennings, Merle Haggard and the like and modern country star Luke Coombs, Ray described his music.
"It's nothing superficial. It's just the three chords of truth."
His album "Built for Leaving," certainly showcases his ability to capture his vision. He writes for those who appreciate lyrics but also provides a catchy tune for audiences to have fun with.
The crowd favorite, "Marlboro Man," is about a guy who relies on cigarettes and booze to mask his sadness. What is a somber theme becomes an excellent crowd sing-a-long with the chorus: "Light em up boys! Smoke em if you got em! I won't stop till I reach the bottom."
"Built for Leaving," laments a woman who left him. The singer is calling her back to remember who she once was. "Hold On" is a tune encouraging the subject to maintain hope through the storms of life, when there seems to be no answer. "Way Too Young" increases the tempo and calls for an escape from a mundane life.
The transforming power of love is a residing theme in Ray's album as well.
He likens his wife's love to a "Knotted Oak" a poetic song that describes her love as tough, resilient, able to bear the wind and waves. Ray expresses his gratitude for that love when he sings, "he is grateful," for her, and she is "an angel."
"Antiquity" is also a song dedicated to his love. Accompanied by clear and powerful chords, Ray sings about how she completes him, giving her a supernatural quality. "You are my antiquity, the past and the present — the air I breathe."
The album ends in an ironic, comic country song in the style of Hank Williams Jr. or David Allen Coe, in "I Ain't Country." With a growl to his voice, Ray sings, country isn't a location; it is a lifestyle. Ray, who when he is not performing, is hunting turkey, sport shooting, fishing, playing pool, drinking whiskey and riding horses, gives a brash answer to detractors who may think country music only resides in the typical southern states.
Anybody visiting Kent County for a few seconds can see it's as country as they are and Ray notes that.
In addition to his album, Ray released two singles and June 5 is releasing "That Ain't Today," a song he performed in Kent Got's Talent. That night, he dedicated it to a close friend suffering with cancer.
Ray has got big dreams, and is leaving Maryland to pursue them, but "that ain't today" so see him while you got a chance. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While Arts & Culture could be a secondary fit, the direct emphasis on music performance and entertainment industry aspects makes 'Entertainment' the best match.

title: Maryland boat club to host pair of antique boat exhibitions
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland boat club to host pair of antique boat exhibitions

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 605
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Joe Lawrence remembers accompanying his father to boat races throughout the region as a child, and becoming hooked right away.Lawrence, known as Tocky, began participating in vintage boat exhibitions while in his 60s and will strap on his helmet and start the ignition when The Southern Maryland Boat Club hosts the Piney Point Rumble on the River this weekend at Piney Point Landing and then the Leonardtown Bash on the Bay July 26-27 at the Leonardtown Wharf.
"It's a lot of fun to see the old race boats come out from the late 1950s to the 1970s and even though they're not competitive in today's environment, they put on a great show and are a lot of fun to see," said Lawrence, whose younger brothers Chris and James also run exhibitions.
The events will feature exhibitions in the Historic (built in 1945 or earlier) and Vintage (between 1945-2000) classes.
"I'm very excited," said Southern Maryland Boat Club President Jim Berry, who added 44 boats will race this year, up from 35 two years ago. "We're expanding and going to have 20% more boats show up. The schedule will be more crowded, there will be more activity on the water with less space between the heats so with the extra boats, we have to jam the heats all together and not have anything between them so it will be almost non-stop activity. This is going to be a banner year."
Berry also announced that 11 inboards — all of which are from out of state — will run exhibitions "to expand our spectator base."
"We don't want to be stagnant. We want to grow and since there's only so many outboards out there available," Berry said of the boats, which must be lifted in and out of the water with cranes, "we decided to add a different class of boats.
Berry said the inboards are modified with motors such as those used in NASCAR or on drag strips.
"It's definitely going to be more exciting," Berry said, "because there will be more water spray in the air."
The 67-year-old Lawrence said the inboard exhibitions will be "loud and proud."
Lawrence grew up in Colton's Point and took in events almost weekly with his father at places like Capt. Sam's and the Leonardtown Wharf.
"I grew up in the heyday of the 60s and 70s when boat racing was all around Southern Maryland and dad was an avid boat race fan, so we attended pretty much every race that was within driving distance. We were hooked," Lawrence, who now lives in Virginia, said.
But as he got older, boat racing started to fade away until the club was resurrected in 2015. His brothers jumped into exhibitions right away and Lawrence volunteered as a patrol boat driver, but his brothers kept telling him he needed a boat.
He finally relented and purchased a derelict 1959 Glasspar G3 and rebuilt it with a 70 horsepower Evinrude and has raced the past 4 years.
"I was more excited than anything else, not nervous at all," the 6-foot, 235-pounder said of his first exhibition. "I'm a big guy, so a big guy in a little boat I'm not as fast as everyone else. I just enjoy it. I'm just out there running."
Berry said the club hosts two events a year at separate locations for a reason.
"We're trying to carry on history," he said, referring to the eight to 10 events per year when competitions were held in the 1960s. "There are also different viewing areas, different regulations and we can also draw boaters from different areas. We're trying to be more responsive to keeping things fresher instead of the same old, same old." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: MusicLife spring recital and scholarship honors Sam Scalzo
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
MusicLife spring recital and scholarship honors Sam Scalzo

 June 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 451
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — On May 28, at their spring musical showcase, MusicLife at 241 High Street, awarded the Sam Scalzo scholarship to young, local musician Ben Gilbert and a second scholarship to Kylie Griffith.Gilbert has been accepted to the Blackbird Academy in Nashville, Tennessee where he plans to study music production.
Griffith, a skilled pianist, performed "Lord I Need You" that night; she plans to have music play an integral part of her life.
MusicLife offers instrument rentals and sales, lessons, sheet music and more.
This year's recital was emotional since it is the first year Scalzo, an accomplished musician offering his time, energy and talents to area schools, has not been there personally to deliver the award to recipients. Scalzo is in hospice care and a tearful playing of "Shall We Gather" ended Wednesday night's program reflecting on his many contributions.
Owner of MusicLife Bill Drazga played the piano and delivered the heartfelt vocals portraying a distant land beyond pain, suffering and death.
"Yes, we'll gather at the river," he sang. "The beautiful, the beautiful river. Gather with the saints at the river, that flows by the throne of God."
The recital reflected Scalzo's passion for music by showcasing musicians of all ages and styles singing and performing numbers in rock, classical and everything in between.
To some students such as Auden Unsworth this was their first recital, encouraged by the teachers, performing in a creative and fun environment while proud instructors looked on.
Scalzo too, would have been pleased.
Better known as "Sam, the Italian Music Man" in Rock Hall, he spent his entire life in music, beginning at a young age and learning from the First Clarinet Player at the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra. When he was not performing, he was fostering young musicians in Kent County High School Jazz Band, tutoring elementary students, practicing weekly with general band students or cheering on the marching band.
Drazga said in the 25 years of knowing Scalzo, "I think he is the only person on earth that loves music more than I do."
Drazga came up with the idea of the scholarship to honor the many contributions Scalzo has made to music education in Kent and Queen Anne's counties over the years.
"Mr. Scalzo has shown his dedication to cultivating young people's musical education through his countless years of work in Kent County schools and beyond."
The scholarship was established in 2019 by MusicLife, in partnership with family and friends and awarded annually to a local graduating high school senior.
Past recipients are Sarah Parker (2019), Jane Godfrey (2020), Claire O'Brien and Isabella Williams (2021), Corrina Boyd (2022), Jade Lee (2023) and Aaron Saunders (2024).
Anyone wishing to make a donation to future scholarship awards can find more information at musiclifedelmarva.com or by calling at 410-778-7010. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Artists inspire other artists' at the Academy Art Museum
author: BROOKE ENSMINGER
content:
'Artists inspire other artists' at the Academy Art Museum

 July 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BROOKE ENSMINGER | Section: Entertainment 
 
 535
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Local musician Kentavius Jones broke the barrier between performer and audience member with an intimate public recording session in the Academy Art Museum on Saturday.Taking inspiration from an exhibit in the museum, Jones and his band gathered in the Performing Arts Room to record material that would go on his second album. The Academy invited several artists, from painters to pastel artists, to set up their canvases and let the music guide them to their creative destination.
Jones said he did something similar with the art museum for his first album, "Bohemian Beatbox." However, that session was not in collaboration with other artists.
"For this one, I was like, 'man, we should add a component where there are actual people, where there are actual artists there creating too,'" Jones said. "Artists inspire other artists."
Jones took inspiration from Richard Estes' exhibit "Urban Landscapes," which is featured in the museum until Aug. 3. A photorealist painter, Estes' work showcases the reflective surfaces of the city. The exhibit's focus on reflections serves as a reminder that artists are reflections of their lived experiences and of each other, according to Jones.
Ellie Christiansen, of St. Michaels, was one of the painters at the recording session. She decided not to arrive with an idea of what she wanted to paint. Rather, she took a walk around the gallery and viewed other pieces of art to get color inspiration. Upon returning to the room, she said she let the music inform her painting decisions.
"I think that it's a beautiful, inspiring event that can bring together community members and artists who can be inspired by the music," Christiansen said. "I don't think you get a chance to do that very often."
Painting during a live music recording session was not an opportunity she's had before, she said, but she enjoyed it.
"If I could do this every Saturday, I think I would because it's always nice to be around fellow artists, especially listening to amazing, inspirational music," Christiansen said.
The quiet, dimly lit room created a relaxing environment. Guests could walk around freely and engage with the performers and artists.
"Good scenery, good visuals and good sounds," said Kentavius's mother, Lois McCoy, describing the ambiance of the event. McCoy said she was excited to experience her son's recording process, something she's only heard about.
Throughout the session, Kentavius and the band switched between improvising and recording, allowing audience members to experience the raw recording process.
"The musicians, they were somewhat familiar with some of the songs, but some of the songs they never heard before," Jones said. "I wanted people to see it unfold live."
Jones said the experience felt organic for him, and he was grateful for the opportunity to make his art even more collaborative. He often took breaks from performing to engage with audience members. At one point, he individually greeted and introduced himself to each person in attendance.
"To have folks there a part of the recording process, it just further builds that relationship, that connection between me as the creator and folks as the audience," Jones said. "It was magical for me."
Some of the music recorded at this session will be performed at Jones' public outdoor concert at the Academy Art Museum on Aug. 2. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a musician's collaborative art event at an art museum, emphasizing live music, artistic inspiration, and community engagement. While 'Arts & Culture' is relevant, the explicit mention of 'Entertainment' in the section header and focus on musical performance align most directly with the 'Entertainment' topic.

title: Moving to the music
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Moving to the music

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 748
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ten students in Ashton Mooday's modern band camp in Chestertown received an unexpected thrill to close out their class, Friday, June 27. They got to record in a professional studio, a privilege and honor many musicians do not get the chance to have.The 28-year-old singer/songwriter, teacher and owner of Mooday's Music LLC, teacher said it was beneficial for her students to see the hard work behind the making of music while developing pride in their accomplishments.
Mooday explained that Ken Schweitzer, associate chair of the Department of Music at Washington College, had received a grant to record small independent artists at their studio. Schweitzer, knowing about Mooday's music, asked her to record something. Mooday was honored but did not have any new songs at the time.
However, she did have students which the grant also allows for, Schweitzer pointed out.
After learning three favorite and popular songs: Michael Jackson's "Beat It", "OK Not To Be OK" by Marshmello and Demi Lovato and "Best Day of My Life" by American Authors, students of Mooday's week-long class decided to go with the latter to record.
On 9 a.m. that Friday, students Mason Poulson, Abbie Donophan, Emma Christophel, Whitley Sparks, Micah Christophel, Hannah Sadler, Quinn Greenwell, Asher Sadler, Adah Sadler and Jezzy Greenwell stepped into the studio prepared.
Washington College audio engineer students Stevie Lyles and Mariana Kilman got the equipment set up to record the students choice "Best Day of my Life." Mooday, with assistance from guitar teacher Matt Wirtz and drum set instructor Emily Holden, said the tune was fun for the kids to learn. "It's just catchy with two chords and a simple, fun drum pattern," she said.
The class recorded in parts. Micah Christophel posted up behind the drum set establishing the beat first. Next, Wirtz guided students on guitars and helped lay out the licks (musical phrases). Mooday assisted her kids on the ukuleles as well as vocals. All the while, she insisted they participate as much as possible which they were eager to do.
"All the kids played played a part in the process which was really cool. Every student sang when it came to lay down the vocals track as well."
Mooday said it was also important for them to see the hardworking people in the background behind some of their favorite songs. They were eyewitness to the engineers mixing the track, adding some reverb to their vocals and were amazed at the finished product.
Mooday took joy seeing the kids' confidence grow in the studio.
The entire recording, mixing and production process was efficient. They were in and out in two hours, Mooday said. The engineer students delivered the finished track to her in time to develop a slideshow to be presented to parents and students later that day for a final performance.
That same afternoon at Mooday's Music, the kids performed two songs, the one they had recorded and also "OK Not To Be OK," receiving applause for their hard work and dedication.
Mooday was elated, appreciating the timing of Schweitzer's offer coordinating with her class schedule. "It worked out so nicely," Mooday said. "They are so young and for them to have this opportunity was amazing."
Now in her sixth year teaching, music changed Mooday's life and at an early age she desired sharing that with others.
Mooday followed that passion, using some bleak times in her life to shape her faith and music. She has a B.S. in music education and B.A. in flute performance and Masters degree in music education with a certificate in modern band at Lebanon Valley College.
The intense years of music study allowed her to live out her dream, owning her own music classroom, passing on the lessons music taught her.
"I really enjoy the private lessons setting because it gives me a chance to work individually with a student, meeting their needs and helping them grow to not only play their chosen instrument, but also grow a love for music. I have a passion for working with students with higher needs and challenging myself to find what works best for their learning processes."
And in the future, she will have more space to do that, adding on an extra 2,000 square feet, enabling her team to conduct two summer camps a year, with more room for private lessons, kid classes, and to teach homeschoolers.
Learn more about Mooday's Music LLC by visiting her website, moodaysmusicllc.org, and be sure to check out all of her work, which includes albums, singles and EPs that date all the way back to 2017 on Spotify. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While education and arts & culture are tangentially relevant, the primary context of music production and student performance aligns most strongly with 'Entertainment.'

title: Great Mills resident wins Miss Maryland pageant
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Great Mills resident wins Miss Maryland pageant

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 364
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maria Derisavi has a community service initiative titled Seize Your Opportunities, and June 21 in Hagerstown she did exactly that when she was selected as Miss Maryland.The 22-year-old is the first Iranian-American Miss Maryland in the organization's 104 year history, and the first from St. Mary's County to win the award.
"I competed against 18 of some of Maryland's [most] accomplished, community-driven young women, so it was really an honor to be selected among those really incredible girls," said Derisavi, who also won Miss Teen Maryland USA in 2021. "I was shocked when I won, but of course so grateful. You definitely go into these competitions to win, but at least for me you never expect to win, you just hope for it but I prepared my best."
She will represent Maryland when she competes in the Miss America competition which will be held in September in Orlando, Fla.
The Great Mills resident won the crown following a week of competition which included interview, fitness, on-stage question, talent and evening gown.
"Each contestant worked extremely hard and put their best foot forward at the Miss Maryland Competition," 2023 Miss Maryland and board member Kennedy Taylor said, adding that Derisavi "captured the judges' hearts in all categories."
For the talent portion, Derisavi performed a speech about her story of immigration to the United States from Kuwait at the age of 9.
The first runner-up was Alaysia Bookal (Miss Potomac), followed by Jaclyn Davis (Miss Northern Maryland), Allie Wolfe (Miss Montgomery County) and Elle Miles (Miss Baltimore).
"We are always blown away by the level of talent at the Miss Maryland competition," Taylor said.
Since 2021, Derisavi has championed her community service initiative titled SeizeYourOpportunities, a research-backed resilience development program that has already reached thousands of students across the state of Maryland through school seminars that empower students through goal setting and self-efficacy workshops.
"Coming from a low-income background myself, I know how important it is to have some sense of resilience, especially when you go through adverse experiences," she said. "What my programming does is it's research and educator-informed, so I work with social worker professionals and educators to create a workbook that talks about resiliency and teaches skills like goal-setting and perseverance."

title: Caroline Summerfest slated for Aug. 15 and 16
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Summerfest slated for Aug. 15 and 16

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline Summerfest is on the horizon. The two-day event is scheduled for Aug. 15 and 16 from 5 to 9 p.m.According to Caroline County Recreation and Parks Director Jamie Beechey, nonprofit organization in the county benefit the most from Caroline Summerfest.
"It is one of their biggest, if not biggest, fundraisers of the year," Beechey said. "So, by virtue of the sales that they do have, they're able to provide for the residents of Caroline County the services that they they can provide and because of that fundraising during Summerfest."
Summerfest is a free family entertainment festival featuring two stages of regional and local entertainment hosted on the Caroline County courthouse lawn and parts of Main Street in Denton.
On Friday, there will be a car show and multiple groups and soloists singing on the Courthouse Stage and the West Lawn Stage.
Saturday will feature a fireworks show, strolling performers, artisans, free activities, games and food vendors.
Also on Saturday, Summerfest includes the Rivah Run, a 2-mile paddling event including kayaking, paddle boarding and canoeing for people of all ages. Children must be accompanied by an adult.
Caroline County Recreation and Parks holds 100 slots for the Rivah Run, and each year the 100 slots are filled. Pre-registration is at 8 a.m., and launch is at 9 a.m. at Martainak State Park.
Each paddler stops at a series of five dealer checkpoints to receive a playing card. At the finish, the best five-card poker hand wins the first pick of prize options with a cash value of $750. Local businesses contribute prizes for other winning hands.
For more information on Caroline Summerfest, visit carolinesummerfest.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it includes cultural elements and local community aspects, the primary focus is on entertainment events like stages, car shows, and fireworks.

title: Pirates raid Rock Hall for annual festival
author: WILL BONTRAGER wontrager@chespub.com
content:
Pirates raid Rock Hall for annual festival

 August 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 826
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Avast me hearties! Buccaneers and landlubbers of all ages flooded to Rock Hall for their annual Pirates and Wenches festival over the weekend sponsored by Main Street Rock Hall.They took to Main Street, Sharp Street, Ferry Park Beach and Watermen's Crab House meshing fun with history and entertainment.
Voted Best Tourist Attraction by local media, the festival celebrated its 18th year.
Co-organizer, Suzanne Einstein originally dreamed up the pirates concept, happy to see it expand.
"We came up with the idea while at Waterman's Crab House on Halloween after seeing so many people dressed up as pirates! We thought, how fun would it be to have a Caribbean style party on our public beach, a decorated dinghy flotilla in the harbor, and a Buccaneer's Ball! It was clear to us that our little waterfront town on the Chesapeake was the perfect location to host such an event!"
She was right. Eighteen years later the party is in full effect, drawing people of all ages.
Jim Rich, chairperson for Pirates and Wenches Committee noted the weather was absolutely perfect to bring people out.
He said that for two days restaurants, bars, shops, hotels and Airbnb's were filled. Business in the area thrived, including some new businesses that just opened: Rock Hall Brewing Company, The Green Heron and Nauti Blu Cottage to name a few.
Down the street and avenues, joyous pirates and charming wenches peddled their wares to locals and visitors alike while music played along Sharp Street and kids' laughter and joy filled the air.
In typical pirate fashion, much could be experienced from deer-antler weapons, to spicy pirate blend pickles to wooden pints as big as a giant's fist to artwork and beautiful jewelry. Some vendors were local or nearby, but others came as far as Florida like author historian, Robert Jacob.
With four buses shuttling people to and fro, it made for a safe, relaxing weekend with no incidents, reported Brian Jones of Rock Hall Volunteer Fire Company.
The party kicked off Friday night with rum tasting at Haven Harbour South and sea shanty sing-alongs at American Legion Post 228 at 7 p.m.
On Saturday, a Lions Club sponsored kids treasure dig at the Ferry Park public beach at 10 a.m uncovered fun followed by a rolling flotilla low speed vehicle parade at 11 a.m. along with pirate poker run from noon to 2 p.m.
After that, pirates and wenches took to the coast for a beach party with live music from noon to 4 p.m.; and Buccaneers Ball from 7 to 11 p.m. at Waterman's Crab House where winners of the raffle were announced.
Also on Saturday, mysterious mermaids waved to audiences from their watery chambers, stilted individuals stalked merrily through the crowd and planners of the pirate events had a ball showing people how to participate in the multitude of activities.
As of last year, cannon fire shot off at intervals throughout the weekend from the Skullduggery Crew based out of Baltimore. The group stayed two days in tents, truly roughing it.
Music from The Brigands and other bands got people toe-tapping and twirling.
Rich said everyone has fun at Pirates, especially kids, with even more activities for them than last year.
The HoCo Pirate Adventure Treasure was a hit with families, participating in a treasure hunt that encompassed the entire festival area.
Another activity, kids could hunt down the "most wanted pirates" and be rewarded with prizes as well as a chance to win a movie party at Flagship Premium Cinemas.
Fortune's Folly Pirate Show got kids laughing and watching in wonder.
Near Gunpowder Cove, the dunk machine drew a big crowd said mom and PTA member, Laura Wirth. Her daughter Lina Wirth happily volunteered to be dunked. All proceeds went to Rock Hall Elementary School.
A new attraction from Master Ship builders Lisa Sasser and George Barnett guided kids to make their own sailboats, testing them on the rough waters of the kiddie pool. Sasser was pleased to see so many children enjoying it.
History buffs were entertained as well.
The author, Robert Jacob regaled the crowd, knocking down some past prejudices of Black Beard and conducted a lecture about pirates in the Chesapeake.
The street was open for creative swashbucklers and maidens greeting people with warmth and cheer.
Woody McKay better known as Captain Gray Fox handed out good doubloons.
"I love this! Every year I meet such interesting people," he said.
As he said that, award winning actress, Smithsonian scholar Mary Ann Jung introduced herself as her character, Grace O' Malley the Pirate Queen.
Good grub was to be had as well from pizza, burgers, barbecue to smoked meat on a stick. And if the sun was too much for people, they even had a mist tent cooling people down.
Rich lauded Pirates a success, estimating the event drew 4,000 people to the town.
He thanked everyone on the committee who started planning around February.
"From my view we pulled off what can be a complicated event with a lot of moving parts. We showed people Pirates in Rock Hall is a friendly, family-oriented weekend." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a festive pirate-themed festival with entertainment elements like parades, music, vendors, and family activities. While it involves local community engagement and cultural aspects, the primary focus is on the event's entertainment value and recreational activities.
